PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care for the Elderly
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that,
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older.
if open not-for-profit health Funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, they need to share these costs equitably.
some health insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to,
take the necessary action to reverse rising cost trends and provide positive incentives to encourage all health funds to share the cost of health care for sick and elderly Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament; the humble petition of the undersigned showeth:
That Kingsford-Smith Airport is becoming increasingly congested and existing facilities are inadequate to handle the number of aircraft or their passengers.

The Federal Government's plans to divert aircraft from Mascot to Bankstown and/or increase landing charges for peak periods will do little to relieve congestion and will place enormous financial and other burdens on commuter airlines and their passengers.
We therefore call on the Federal Government to take heed of airline and travel industry warnings and-
1. give immediate approval for the construction of a third runway at Mascot.
2. upgrade existing radar and other traffic control facilities to enable Australia's high safety record to be maintained.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray;

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Romania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia expresses their concern about the situation in Romania, where, after decades of repression and human rights abuses, the bulldozing of 7-8000 villages is imminent.

The wilful destruction of hundreds of thousands of homes, thousands of churches, historic monuments and cemeteries while unprecedented will erase also the cultural heritage of Romania's sizable minorities, among them that of approximately 2.5 million Hungarians from their erstwhile homeland.

Your petitioners humbly request that the Senate shall issue a strong note of protest to the Romanian Government and shall urge the Australian Government to exert utmost pressure on the Romanian Government to abandon the totalitarian plan and to adhere to the international agreements and covenants of which Romania is a fellow signatory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT (TAX AGENTS' FEES) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Watson) agreed to:

That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to make deductible expenditure incurred for the preparation, by a registered tax agent, of information required by or under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.
Motion (by Senator Watson) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.
SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to make a minor amendment to section 69 (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to permit a taxpayer to receive a deduction not only for the cost of the preparation of a tax return but also for the fees charged by a tax agent for the preparation of additional information required under the Principal Act and under the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act.
Self-assessment
Self-assessment is now a major part of the Australian taxation system and it has radically altered the basis for the preparation of tax returns.

Post-assessment checks, whether by way of a desk audit or a field audit, have become a regular part of the assessment process. In addition, objections and appeals are also now an intrinsic part of the self-assessment system.

Accordingly, it is reasonable to allow a deduction for the preparation of additional material required under the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act as part of the assessment process.

Provisions have been included in this Bill to deny a deduction of costs incurred through a registered tax agent in circumstances where the taxpayer has been engaged in a tax avoidance scheme under Section IVa of the Principal Act.
Provisions have also been included to preclude the amended Section 69 being used in contesting a dispute or resolving a disagreement through the courts.
The Reason for the Bill

Traditionally, fees paid by clients for services of taxation professionals, when directed towards their business activities, have been deductible against the assessable income of the taxpayers concerned, tax litigation excepted.

Doubts regarding the deductibility of fees for income tax return preparation caused by the decision of the High Court in 1950 in Green v Federal Commissioner of Taxation were overcome by the introduction, in 1963, of Section 69 into the Income Tax Assessment Act.
More recently, however, doubts have been raised as to the scope of deductibility of fees for professional taxation services in certain situations by particular court decisions.

Further concern has arisen as a result of what appears to be inconsistent approaches to the deductibility of fees for professional taxation services that have been taken by officers of the Australian Taxation Office following routine tax audits.

This amendment Bill has been made even more current by a judicial decision of 29 March this year. In the case, His Honour Mr Justice Northrop of the Federal Court overturned an Administrative Appeals Tribunal decision where the taxpayer claimed legal advice in the preparation of a notice of objection on the basis that the essential character of the expense was to obtain a reduction in the amount of tax assessed and therefore this legal expense incurred was not deductible under section 51 of the principal Act. Accordingly, inconsistencies appear to exist in the deductibility of disputation fees as they relate to income tax assessments and fringe benefits tax assessments even though the payment of both income tax and fringe benefits tax is non-deductible. My amendment Bill seeks to remedy this anomaly.

I believe disputation fees are deductible irrespective of whether they are incurred in respect of income tax assessments or fringe benefits tax assessments, except where they involve State, Territory or Federal Court action. Expenditure relating to professional tax fees incurred through a registered tax agent should be wholly deductible except to the extent to which it is private, domestic or capital in nature. As the recipient of professional tax fees will return those fees as assessable income so the payer should correspondingly obtain a full tax deduction in respect of the payment of those fees since, in reality, such outgoings cannot readily be described as expenses of a capital, private or domestic nature.

In summary, the Australian taxation environment is in a very different state to the position in 1963, when section 69 of the Act was introduced. In particular there has been a move to a system of self-assessment. The Commissioner no longer relies on the tax return as lodged and has instigated and upgraded measures seeking to ensure taxpayers properly meet their liabilities. Those most obvious to honourable senators will be desk audits and field audits. The new system of self-assessment increases the importance and time attributed to compliance, planning and, on occasion, tax disputation.

The importance of the role of tax advice in legitimate business administration and strategic planning has increased significantly. Today, tax is just one of the many important costs of operating a successful business. There now exists a much broader tax base, particularly with the inclusion of foreign source income and capital gains and there has been added further tax burdens, including fringe benefits tax. There is a recognition by the Australian Taxation Office of the co-operation of tax agents in the administration of the Income Tax Assessment Act and the very substantial role played by tax agents in assisting taxpayers to meet their obligations and, indirectly, to assist in the revenue collection process.

It is interesting to note that statistics show over 50 per cent of appeals against decisions and assessments of the Australian Taxation Office are resolved in the taxpayer's favour. Several other jurisdictions permit deductibility of taxation fees for taxation services. These include the United States, Canada, West Germany and Japan. The circumstances that 25 years ago initiated the limited concession embodied in section 69 no longer prevail.

I would like, in closing my remarks, to express my thanks to officers of the Taxation Institute of Australia, the Australian Society of Accountants and members of individual accounting firms for their valuable advice on this Bill. Although many accountants and lawyers would like the amendment to be wider than I have proposed, I think the Bill before the Senate will address many of the anomalies that have been identified. I earnestly believe that this simple Bill will remedy an anomaly which exists in the complicated area of taxation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRADE PRACTICES (INTERNATIONAL LINER CARGO SHIPPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to reform the outdated legislative framework under which Australia's international liner trade is carried by sea. The Bill will repeal and replace Part X of the Trade Practices Act.

Liner shipping is characterised by the carriage of mainly containerised cargoes on defined trade routes. In 1986/87 Australia's liner exports totalled 8 million tonnes valued at nearly $13 billion. In the same year our liner imports totalled over 6 million tonnes and were valued at over $21 billion. In total around 50% of Australia's foreign trade will be transported under commercial conditions coming within the framework of this Bill. Australia's liner exports are mainly primary commodities such as wool and meat and liner imports are mainly high value manufactured items such as industrial machinery and equipment.

The changes embodied in this Bill will encourage a more competitive shipping environment for the benefit of Australian shippers. At the same time Australia's exporters and importers will continue to have access to the benefits of frequent and reliable sailings provided by liner conferences. These reforms are part of the Government's strategy for overall micro-economic reform and complement our efforts in the national shipping and waterfront sectors.

An international feature of liner shipping is the organisation of ocean carriers into so-called liner conferences. These conferences are in fact cartels combining resources and restricting competition among themselves in order to provide high quality, integrated shipping services. Liner conferences continue to carry the majority of Australia's liner cargoes with participation levels between 50-80% on Australia's trading routes. Non-conference or independent ocean carriers transport the remainder and their competition with conference carriers provides exporters with alternative freight rates.

The benefits to exporters and importers of access to reliable, efficient and frequent shipping services have been recognised by governments of all major trading countries. Where ocean carriers have associated to offer these services as a liner conference the necessary exemptions from national laws regulating anti-competitive practices have been provided. Australia is no exception, and conferences for many years have received full exemption from Part IV of the Trade Practices Act, which prohibits anti-competitive and exclusive dealings in exchange for complying with the regulatory provisions of Part X.

Nevertheless, there has been strong concern within the shipper community that the exemptions were too broadly based and while there were benefits in the conference system, conferences were overly protected to the disadvantage of shippers and non-conference operators.

The Government shared this general concern and established the industry task force to review Australia's liner shipping legislation. Shipper, ocean carrier and union interests were represented on the task force. Following consultations with some 50 industry and government organisations, the task force presented its findings and recommendations in 1986 in the ``Liner Shipping Report''. The report was circulated to all members of Federal Parliament at that time.

The task force was strongly of the view that Australia's overall interests would best be served by regulation that is directed to the promotion of a fair, competitive environment which would ensure access to the market for all ocean carriers on equal terms and which would penalise and eliminate abuses of the system and anti-competitive practices. It has been the focus of much public debate and comment. The report and industry reaction to it formed the basis of the Government's consideration of the reforms which are now embodied in the Bill that we have before us.

The overall thrust of the Bill is set out in the ``objects'' section and is aimed at creating a more balanced, competitive liner shipping industry to enhance Australia's trading interests. Australian exporters' access to conference services has been retained with appropriate safeguards against abuses of conference power. This will be achieved through three key mechanisms incorporated in the Bill, namely:
a transparent registration procedure which requires conference agreements to be publicly available and contain minimum standards
permitting only partial and conditional exemption from Part IV for anti-competitive and exclusionary practices
requiring conferences and ocean carriers with a substantial degree of market power to negotiate with representative shipper bodies.

In enhancing shippers' negotiating positions with conferences the two stage transparent registration mechanism will give shippers advance notice of proposed carriage arrangements, permit shippers to participate in negotiations regarding minimum service levels before the conference agreement is finally registered and provides and early opportunity for registered agreements to be investigated by the Trade Practices Commission on complaint by an affected party.

The Bill seeks to limit the exemption from Part IV to the minimum necessary for the continued provision of conference services to Australian exporters and provides that breaches of Part X be enforced by the provisions contained in Part VI. The Bill is therefore an integral part of the Trade Practices Act while recognising the uniqueness of the liner shipping industry. The resultant complexity of the Bill can better be understood by dividing its major provisions into seven broad categories.
1. Limited exemptions for conferences

The Government has accepted industry arguments that there are benefits in the continued operation of the conference system. However, in future, conference exemption from Part IV of the Trade Practices Act for the provision of services to our shippers will be restricted to section 45 (anti-competitive agreements) and section 47 (exclusive dealings) and then only to the extent necessary for the provision of rationalised services.

The Bill provides the exemption for both inwards and outwards liner conference shipping services for the ``blue-water'' and foreign land based components only. The exemptions do not extend to stevedoring operations and the transport of cargo by land or air in Australia which will now be exposed to Part IV. However, the government has accepted that the fixing of door to door service freight rates and the determination of common terms and conditions for bills of lading which could breach Part IV are of benefit to Australian shippers and will be given limited exemption from Part IV. In order to minimise potential conflicts of law with other countries the additional safeguards and regulations of registration and negotiations associated with the exemptions are confined to outwards liner shipping services.

For outward liner shipping services the exemptions will limit conferences to practices such as the charging of common freight rates by their members and entering into loyalty agreements with shippers. However, for conferences to gain an exemption for practices not specifically identified in the Bill, the additional practices will have to be necessary for the effective operation of the conference and have overall benefits for shippers.

Section 46 (misuse of market power) will be expressly applied to all conference operations. The Government cannot accept the situation where conferences continue to be exempt from the Trade Practices Act's provisions concerning misuse of market power. The Bill also contains a provision modelled on section 49 (price discrimination) which prohibits discrimination between similarly situated exporters.
2. Minimum standards for conference agreements

An important condition attached to the exemptions I have outlined is that conference agreements in our export trades must meet certain minimum standards. Most importantly, the agreements must contain details of minimum service levels such as frequency of sailings, ports of call and cargo carrying capacity, which conference members undertake to maintain. The Bill ensures that conferences will be required to negotiate minimum service levels with a shipper body designated by the Minister.

Conference members will also be required to provide for the resolution of disputes in Australia in accordance with Australian law rather than be able to utilise some other procedure. The Minister will be empowered to waive this requirement where particular circumstances warrant.

Conference agreements will have to provide for the withdrawal of a party to the agreement upon reasonable notice without penalty. This recognises that over time an ocean carrier should be in a position to respond to changing market circumstances by being able to withdraw from a conference without undue delay.
3. Transparency

Under the regulatory scheme contained in the Bill, the secrecy provisions of the existing Part X will be swept away. In future, all outwards conference agreements will be entered onto a public register. Details on the register and copies of the agreements will be publicly available. To ensure our shippers have an opportunity to examine and challenge such agreements, all conference agreements will have to remain on the public register for 30 days before coming into effect.

Provision will, of course, be made to protect commercially sensitive matters contained in conference agreements where this is justified and does not disadvantage Australian exporters. Even in circumstances where a request for confidentiality is granted, an abstract of the relevant matters must be provided for the public record.
4. Enhanced Shipper Rights

The Bill encourages shippers to associate to act as a counterbalance to the cartel powers of conferences and the negotiating powers of ocean carriers with substantial market power. The Minister will be able to declare a shipper association, which represents Australian shippers generally, to be a designated peak shipper body and certain association, which represents the interests of a particular group of shippers, to be a designated secondary shipper body.

The designation of a peak shipper body or the nomination of a secondary designated shipper body will empower that body to negotiate minimum service levels. Such bodies will also be able to require conferences and non-conference operators with substantial market power to negotiate, whenever reasonably requested, over arrangements for and the terms and conditions of carriage in our export liner trades. The parties to the conference agreement will have to have due consideration to matters raised by the shipper body and exchange such information as is reasonably necessary for the purposes of the negotiations.

The Bill grants appropriate exemption from Part IV of the Act for designated shipper bodies to exercise the powers which I have just indicated. In addition, all designated shipper bodies will receive exemption to negotiate and enter into loyalty agreements with ocean carriers.

The Bill overcomes a deficiency of the existing Part X which permits ocean carriers to unilaterally impose freight rate increases without negotiating. In future ocean carriers regulated by the new legislation will need to provide 30 days notice to the relevant designated shipper body before freight rates and service levels can be varied. This period of advance notice can, with the agreement of the designated shipper body, be reduced to meet commercial circumstances.

Shippers will have access to the Trade Practices Commission to resolve problems which may arise between themselves and ocean carriers. The provisions of conference agreements and the way they are being applied will be able to be challenged before the commission on the grounds that the shipping services are not efficient or economical or are not being provided at the capacity and frequency to meet the needs of affected shippers. Complaints in regard to loyalty agreements will also be able to be referred to the Commission.
5. Non-Conference Operators

With the exception of the requirement to have an agent for the purpose of official communication, most non-conference operators will not be regulated by the provisions of the Bill. In other words, the pro-competitive provisions of Part IV of the Trade Practices Act will apply. However, where non-conference operators are deemed to have substantial market power they will be required to negotiate with an appropriate designated shipper body over arrangements for and the terms and conditions of carriage.
6. Unfair Pricing
The Bill provides for allegations of unfair pricing by ocean carriers to be referred through the minister for consideration by the Trade Practices Tribunal.

The provisions concerning unfair pricing are a safeguard measure to help ensure the long term stability of commercial shipping services. They will not provide protection from fair competition for inefficient ocean carriers. It is not in our national interest to discourage any genuinely low-cost commercial operators from offering competitive services to Australia's shippers. The Bill provides minimum criteria which have to be met in order to sustain allegations of unfair pricing and ensures that our national interest is taken into account by the tribunal.
7. Australian Flag Shipping

The Bill continues the existing policy whereby conference and non-conference operators with substantial market power will be prohibited from hindering an Australian flag operator from engaging efficiently in outwards liner cargo shipping.

Australian flag shipping will, in the event for example of its operations being unreasonably disadvantaged by other carriers on non-commercial grounds, have access to the Trade Practices Commission for investigation of the complaint. Australian flag shipping accounted for the carriage of some 7% of our liner exports and 9% of our liner imports in 1986/87. The Government has made strenuous efforts to encourage Australian flag shipping to be more efficient and we are not prepared to stand idly by and allow our operators to be discriminated against on a non-commercial basis.

Against the background of the major provisions I have just described, the regulatory framework embraced by the Bill represents a substantial change from that with which the liner shipping industry has become familiar over the last 20 years.

In relative terms the position of shippers will be significantly strengthened while the conferences will lose a good deal of the immunity from Part IV of the Trade Practices Act which they enjoy under the existing Part X. In order to enable the necessary negotiations to take place and to ensure a smooth change is made to the new regulatory regime, the Bill provides a six month transition period during which the business of carrying our exports can continue uninterrupted while agreements are submitted for registration.

Liner shipping, like any other sector of the international economy, is constantly evolving. While there is some flexibility in the provisions of the Bill to take account of change in the market place, the Government is determined to ensure that Australia's liner shipping legislation remains relevant in the light of future developments and is achieving its objectives. Therefore, it is the Government's intention that this legislation should be the subject of a review which will commence no later than seven years after it enters into force.

Finally, the legislation being proposed makes no specific calls on the revenues of the Commonwealth. Similarly, the fees to be prescribed under appropriate provisions of this legislation will do no more than offset costs incurred in administering the regulatory process.
I commend the Bill to the Senate. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray ) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill proposes new legislation, the Bounty (Ships) Act 1989, to provide bounty assistance to Australian shipbuilders from 1 July 1989 to 30 June 1995.

The Bill incorporates changes in policy announced by the Government in November 1988 following the Government's consideration of the Industries Assistance Commission's (IAC) report ``Ships, Boats and Other Vessels'' dated 29 June 1988.

The current legislation, the Bounty (Ships) Act 1980, provides for a cash limited bounty assistance scheme to shipbuilders who commence construction of vessels prior to 30 June 1989. The proposed Bill will continue this form of assistance, at rates which will be phased down until June 1995, when the bounty assistance is proposed to cease. The continued assistance for that period is considered essential so that this industry can continue to build on the significant gains in efficiency and competitiveness it has achieved over the last few years.

The Government's 1984 decision to extend bounty payments to include those built for export and to tighten registration regulations for bounty purposes has led to an export orientation on an unprecedented scale. Currently export orders amount to $300 million. Recent orders include two unique high speed catamaran car and passenger ferries for the Irish Sea.
Ten fishing trawlers are being built for an Indonesian company and two luxury motor yachts worth more than twenty million dollars left Australia in February for the United States.
This is a significant reorientation for the industry. Over half the vessels completed in the first half of this year have been for export whereas in 1984-85 only one ship was exported from Australia.

This success has only been achieved by the industry investing heavily in marketing, capital equipment, new technology and training. However, although the need for bounty assistance for the shipbuilding industry is reducing as the industry becomes more vibrant, withdrawal of assistance at this stage would be premature as the cost of entry into the international market has resulted in trading losses for many firms in their initial years.

Accordingly, the government favours a continued period of assistance and believes that a bounty is the most appropriate form of assistance considering the impact that a tariff would have on ship users' costs and the contraction in local demand for ships. The IAC has also concluded that a bounty was its preferred form of assistance.
The government therefore proposes in this Bill to introduce a new bounty scheme with the following elements:

To be eligible to receive bounty under this bounty scheme, clause 4 provides that a vessel will have to be between 150 and 10,000 gross construction tons, and be both self propelled and navigable. Other floating structures, such as floating hotels, Sydney Harbour tunnel sections and other non self propelled floating structures, will not be bountiable. There is no special provision for commercial fishing vessels in this bounty scheme such as exists in the 1980 Act, as this was originally introduced to coincide with a manning level which is now no longer relevant.

Clause 5 of the Bill provides that bounty will be paid on the costs incurred by a shipbuilder in producing a bountiable vessel at the rate applicable when the costs are incurred rather than paying bounty on the cost of the vessel at the rate applicable when the vessel is commenced, as occurs under the existing bounty scheme.

Bounty will be paid on the production of ships regardless of whether they are for export or domestic use. Such a bounty, unlike specific export subsidies, is not proscribed by Australia's obligations under the GATT treaty; indeed the proposal to phase out the shipbuilding bounty is in accordance with the spirit of the GATT to remove all production subsidies for manufactured goods. The only exception is that in accordance with the Australia New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement (ANZCERTA), Subclause 9(1) of the Bill has been included to exclude from eligibility for bounty vessels exported to New Zealand after June 1990.
Clause 10 of the Bill proposes the phased bounty rates to provide bounty assistance in the following manner:

For bountiable costs incurred between 1 July 1989 and 30 June 1991: 15% of the eligible costs of constructing or modifying the vessel (plus 20% for overheads) will be paid as bounty to the shipbuilder completing the construction or modification of the bountiable vessel;
For costs incurred between 1 July 1991 and 30 June 1993: 10% of the eligible costs (plus 20%) will be paid as bounty;
For costs incurred between 1 July 1993 and 30 June 1995: 5% of the eligible costs (plus 20%) will be paid.
No bounty will be paid on any vessel completed after June 1995.

To be eligible to receive bounty, shipbuilders must meet the clearly defined registration criteria proposed in Clause 17 of the Bill. These criteria have been introduced so that assistance is channelled towards those shipbuilders who have the potential to be world competitive. We have valuable empirical evidence of the effects of a laissez-faire approach to manufacturers' ability to seek shipbuilding bounty-this system operated during the 1980 to 1984 period and the net result was a moribund and severely fragmented group of 91 part-time shipbuilders who were primarily engineering ``jobbing'' shops and fishermen or ferry operators seeking to minimise the capital replacement costs via bounty.

In 1984 the Government targeted the assistance to shipbuilders with a long-term commitment to their particular industry. The aim then, as it is now, was to create a world competitive industry capable of exporting and capable of long-term survival with lowering levels of subsidy.

A number of changes have also been made to administrative provisions of this Bill, to further streamline the scheme's operation. For example, the method of overhead allocation has been significantly simplified. No longer is it appropriate to base assistance around protection as was done in the 1980 Act. This Bill positively encourages higher utilisation of overheads whilst recognising the need for a sound core of what may be loosely termed indirect costs or overheads before a shipyard can genuinely become a world competitor. The criteria requiring applicants to employ 40 persons arises from our analysis of these aspects. Evidence shows that firms with fewer employees simply do not have the capacity to meet the aims of this package.

Analysis of data on the position relating to new entrants to the industry since the introduction of registration criteria is also revealing. More than 40 firms have been registered since 1984 while at any one time there are normally around 20 active builders. Many of today's success stories emanate from firms new to this industry over the last five years.
This Bill is designed to maintain the momentum achieved by this industry, while finally reaching a point where direct assistance is no longer required.
Financial Impact Statement
It is anticipated that the cost of this bounty will be $145 million over the life of the scheme, based on November 1988 dollar values.
The initial outlay for 1989/90 will be $24 million rising to $33 million in 1990/91. Thereafter it will gradually decline.
I commend the Bill to the Senate, and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Jones, for Senator Cooney) agreed to:

(1) That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry and report: Debt recovery under the Social Security Act and the Veterans' Entitlements Act.
(2) That the committee report on or before the last sitting day in 1989.
Motion (by Senator Jones, for Senator Cooney) proposed:
That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry and report:
(a) The extent to which, if at all:
(i) the due administration of companies and securities legislation and the Trade Practices Act,
(ii) the rights of third parties under state legislation, and
(iii) the operation of efficient, informed and competitive markets for corporations, securities and futures, and goods and services,
have been prejudiced by the operation of the doctrine of `shield of the Crown';
(b) the continuing relevance of the doctrine;
(c) the consequences of the differential application of the doctrine in relation to:
(i) the Crown in right of the Commonwealth and the Crown in right of the States,
(ii) the Crown in its non-commercial capacities and when carrying on a business and
(iii) departments of state and statutory authorities; and
(d) the status of bodies or persons dealing with those who might be entitled to invoke the shield of the Crown.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes this reference, which is a matter of significance. I wish to make a few brief remarks about the necessity for the reference and the areas that I hope the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs will address. It has long been a matter of academic concern that the shield of the Crown is so vaguely understood and defined. Indeed, it has been a fairly arcane notion over the years, but it has come into particular focus in recent times with the increasingly commercial activities of both Commonwealth and State governments, and in particular the introduction into this Parliament in recent months of a package of Bills relating to government business enterprises. It has become clear from scrutiny of those Bills that there have been differential provisions in relation to the shield of the Crown to the extent that some Bills have mentioned the doctrine, others have not, and the ones that have mentioned it have done so in different terms. It is still very much a matter of statutory interpretation and objective assessment of what is known as the control test as to whether any particular enterprises are entitled to claim Crown immunity.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that it is currently a matter of practical concern at Commonwealth level, but it has been a matter of particular concern at State level where there have been a number of egregious instances of State governments adopting what can only be described as a cavalier approach to the issue. I wish to put on record at this stage one example which I consider to be flagrant. It relates to evidence given by the Victorian Treasurer, Mr Jolly, to the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation in Melbourne earlier this year. Mr Jolly said:

I would be very reluctant, to say the least, to support the removal of the shield of the Crown, given the fact that you are required to meet a number of other requirements above what is required for private sector organisations.
Senator Short asked:
What are the additional checks and balances that apply to, say, the VIC the VEDC or VET that do not operate in the private sector?
Mr Jolly's response was:

For a start, you have reporting requirements to Parliament, and secondly you have the scrutiny of Parliament itself and the potential for various committees and other forms of inquiry to occur at relative ease, I would suggest.
I asked Mr Jolly:

Why should a State instrumentality engaged in commercial operations not be subject to the same disclosure requirements that apply to all other corporations? It should not, surely, be a matter of whim. You may say, `We will comply with the spirit', but when it comes to the crunch and you do not want to cooperate with the NCSC, and you have the numbers in the Lower House, there is not going to be any parliamentary inquiry.
Mr Jolly said:
In the ultimate, the electorate will decide what it will do in those circumstances.

I regard that as a thoroughly unsatisfactory response. It is clear that the Government in that instance is putting the operations of statutory authorities above the law. Indeed, when one peruses the prospectus of the Victorian Equity Trust one finds the same general attitude being adopted. I think that is something that the Parliament can no longer tolerate.

If we look at the activities of the State Government in Western Australia we can safely say that Mr Alan Bond was very fortunate to escape a finding of unacceptable conduct. That was simply because there was a very real concern on the part of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) that the State Government Insurance Commission (SGIC) of Western Australia was entitled to invoke the shield of the Crown. Indeed, there are authorities to the effect that those who have commercial dealings with a government agency entitled to the shield of the Crown are themselves protected. In that situation the NCSC felt that it had little option but to reach a commercial settlement with both Mr Holmes a Court and Mr Bond. I think that is a very undesirable state of affairs. I believe that the Commission should have gone further than merely forming a tentative finding of unacceptable conduct and should have made the actual finding on the evidence that was available to it. One of the principal reasons it did not was that Mr Bond was able to shelter behind the shield of the Crown. That is not a situation that should be tolerated.

The SGIC made it very clear in correspondence with the Australian Stock Exchange that it regarded itself as not bound to comply with the provisions of the take- overs code. That is an intolerable situation. There are very many commercial activities of government now that must be conducted on a level playing field. Organisations such as Telecom Australia are increasingly entering into joint ventures and other commercial arrangements. There is absolutely no reason why they should not be forced to comply with the same legislative and other statutory obligations. The Trade Practices Commission should have no fears about its power to intervene in circumstances where it would intervene in the private sector, and the shield of the Crown in relation to commercial activities of Government business enterprises would seem to be an increasingly outmoded and irrelevant notion. I think that needs to be tested.

People have written on the question and the sooner a committee of inquiry such as the one chaired by my good friend Senator Cooney has the opportunity to investigate these matters at some length, the sooner we will be able to judge whether the sorts of responses that we have heard in recent times from State Premiers are much more than subterfuges. I hope that we can ultimately devise a test which can be applied across the board instead of having to resort to this tortuous case by case assessment of the control test and ultimately that we will be able to see that commercial operations of government are not put in any privileged position.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Puplick moving forthwith the motion relating to Antarctic mineral resource activities.

The reason for the move to suspend Standing Orders is quite simply that I believe that the Senate should have the opportunity to express an opinion on this matter before the Government comes to a final determination of its position.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) is of the opinion that:
(i) the Antarctic continent should be protected as fully as possible from threats to its unique environment,
(ii) it is incompatible with the above to allow any mining activity to take place in the Antarctic, and

(iii) the proposed Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities is flawed in a number of respects including being an inadequate vehicle for the proper protection of the Antarctic environment; and
(b) as a consequence, calls upon the Australian Government to:
(i) refuse to sign and ratify the proposed Minerals Convention,
(ii) take steps to convene a meeting of the Antarctic Treaty parties to develop an effective regime to prohibit mining in the Antarctic, and
(iii) increase its own level of environmental and scientific activities in the Antarctic.

The Antarctic environment is unique. On that proposition there is no disagreement anywhere around the chamber or, indeed, anywhere in Australia. It is a unique environment in terms of its terrestrial life. It is unique in terms of the effect which developments in the Antarctic may have on global climate and weather patterns. It is unique in that some 70 per cent of the fresh water resources of this planet are actually contained in frozen form in the Antarctic continent. The situation in terms of sovereignty and political arrangements in the Antarctic is also unique. The Antarctic continent is regulated by a series of extraordinary international arrangements which mix aspects of claims of sovereignty with policies of states which either have not made claims or actually reject the validity of such claims.

The continent is subject to a number of international regulatory operations and conventions. Among these, for example, are the original 1959 Antarctic Treaty, the 1964 Agreed Measures for the Conservation of the Antarctic Flora and Fauna, the Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Seals adopted in 1972, the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources which was adopted in 1980 and aspects of Australian domestic legislation, the Whale Protection Act 1980. All of these are similar in the respect that they share a common philosophy, namely, to limit and control exploitative activities and in some cases to prohibit absolutely certain behaviour or practices which may occur elsewhere in the world. For example, there is a total prohibition on military activity taking place in the Antarctic and on the introduction of nuclear weapons and nuclear facilities into the Antarctic.

These arrangements have been carefully developed over a number of years. Indeed, many people in this chamber have participated in some of these developments. For example, in 1980 I was actually one of the delegates from the Australian Parliament to the final negotiating sessions dealing with the development of the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources. Mr Jacobi, then a member of the House of Representatives, and I signed that Convention on behalf of the Australian delegation.

Australia, of course, lays claim to some 42 per cent of the continent. We reasserted that claim in the provisions of the Antarctic Treaty Act 1960. That is an area of approximately 6.1 million square kilometres. We maintain three permanent bases-Casey, Davis and Mawson-and, in addition, there is a permanent station on Macquarie Island and four temporary summer bases in the Larsemann Hills, the Bunger Hills, on Heard Island and at Commonwealth Bay and a new summer field camp is proposed in the Prince Charles Mountains.

Discussions first took place in the 1970s about the possibility of there being some exploitation of the mineral resources of the Antarctic. It was in 1970 that this issue was first put on the international agenda. In 1975 it was proposed by New Zealand that a convention be adopted to prohibit entirely any mining in the Antarctic. At that stage this proposal did not find a great deal of favour in the international community. It is fair to say that a number of developments have occurred since 1975, particularly in relation to our understanding of the impact which activity in the Antarctic may have on the international climate and the control of the atmosphere.

Negotiations on a proposed mineral regime began in earnest in June 1982 and they have certainly been extraordinarily complex. Over the years, a series of about a dozen meetings have taken place, under the chairmanship of Mr Chris Beeby, an official from New Zealand. Critical meetings in the development of this Convention were, for example, those held in Washington in January 1984, in Tokyo in October and November 1986 and Montevideo in May 1987. Arising from these a convention was developed and eventually a final text agreed upon. That convention is entitled `The Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities'.

The Government presented the text of this Convention, together with certain other supporting material, to the Senate on 22 November 1988. It indicated at that time that there ought to be a period of public discussion about this matter and that it would eventually come to a decision as to whether it should or should not sign and ratify that Convention. This is a point of considerable importance. The Convention cannot come into place unless all of a designated number of countries become signatories to it. To come into force, the Convention requires ratification by the 16 Antarctic Treaty consultative parties, including Australia. Virtually all of those parties, except Australia and France, have now indicated that they will become party to the Convention. If Australia and France become signatories, the Convention will come into force. However, a decision by either country not to enter into the Convention will mean that the Convention itself will not come into force. Unanimous consent is required in that regard. Therefore, both Australia and France are in the unique position that they now hold a virtual veto over whether or not the Convention comes into force.

The motion which I have moved in the Senate today on behalf of the Liberal and National parties asserts that it is the opinion of the Senate that Australia should not enter into the Convention and should, therefore, bring about a situation in which the Convention itself does not come into force. The motion says that the Senate believes that the continent needs to be protected as fully as possible and that mining activity is incompatible with that necessary degree of environment protection. It therefore calls on the Australian Government to refuse to sign and ratify the Convention and, indeed, to go further by taking steps to convene a meeting of the Antarctic Treaty parties to develop an effective regime to prohibit mining in the Antarctic. It must be conceded that at the moment there is no formal prohibition on mining activity taking place in the Antarctic. An informal moratorium has been in place for the best part of 10 years. As a result of that, no significant mineral activity has taken place.

Those who defend this Convention do so on the basis that if we do not have a convention there will be some sort of unregulated scramble for mineral and hydrocarbon development in the area and that as a result a regulatory arrangement is now necessary. We on the Opposition side believe that quite the contrary is the case. We believe that the Convention, as drawn, effectively encourages and facilitates mineral activity to take place in the Antarctic. In the absence of this Convention, we say that mining activity will not take place in the Antarctic for a number of reasons, including economic, political, technical, and scientific reasons. Because that unregulated scramble will not take place we will have time to move to turn that informal moratorium on mining activity into a formal regime which prohibits mining activity in the Antarctic.

Catherine Wallace is a lecturer in the Faculty of Commerce and Administration at the Victoria University of Wellington. In an article entitled `The Antarctic Minerals Convention-Environmental Protection or Pre-condition for Development' she states:
. . . an unregulated scramble-
that is to say, an unregulated scramble in terms of mineral activity-

is inherently unlikely, because without security of tenure projects will be unbankable for either private or public sector enterprises. By removing obstacles to development, the impact of the convention would be to facilitate mining.

That is a point of view that we endorse. Because I am conscious of the time constraints in the debate today, I therefore turn to the areas of criticism that the Opposition has of the Convention. Before doing so, may I say that it is a matter of public record that there are divisions within the Government on this particular matter and divisions of opinion within the Cabinet and, indeed, within the Caucus. We know that, on 21 September 1988, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) wrote to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in terms which indicated that he had reservations. In his letter he said:
I do not believe that Australia should sign the Convention until we attempt further to negotiate provisions that better protect our national interests.
He said elsewhere:

. . . signature would mean we would, in effect concede our economic claims over Antarctica for virtually nothing, forfeiting our sovereignty over Antarctica and opening up the possibility of subsidised production competing with Australian mineral producers. . .
Mr Keating continued:

Serious contention may have been avoided in Antarctica for over 30 years but I suspect that this is because the basic question of who benefits from resource exploitation in Antarctica has previously not been addressed very seriously.

He indicated in his letter that the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) shares the same point of view. It is known, for example, that Senator Evans has expressed the view that there should be signature of this convention for the reasons that I have outlined, that Mr Duffy as the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and Senator Richardson, on 2 June 1988, issued a joint media release in which they welcomed a successful conclusion of negotiations for a convention to regulate any future mineral activity in the Antarctic. On 14 April 1986, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) opened a meeting of the consultative parties in Hobart where he expressed general support for the development of such a regime. Therefore, as I say, we know that there are some divisions within the Government over this matter.

For example, we know from some reports that Mr Keating apparently is attracted to the idea of the Antarctic as a world park, a concept which I think Senator Evans once described as something having attraction only for the sort of people who believe in elves and fairies. I think that is a correct recollection of what Senator Evans said on that occasion. It is like his other pronouncement that Kakadu stage 3 was basically `clapped-out buffalo country'. May I say that Senator Evans is quite correct on both counts and is extremely perceptive in his observations about Kakadu stage 3 and now a proposal for a world park in the Antarctic. The Opposition does not support the concept of a world park in the Antarctic. We believe that Australia should continue to maintain its claims of sovereignty. I am yet to be persuaded that that is compatible with the world park concept as it is primarily advanced by Greenpeace and a number of others. It is for that reason that the Opposition has not advocated a world park approach but rather the development within the existing Treaty framework of an anti-mining-a prohibition on mining-regime taking place in the Antarctic continent. When this matter was debated last in the Senate that was the point which I made-that the Opposition was not in favour of the world park concept but nevertheless I believed that the environmental protection guidelines under the Convention were not adequate.

I know that Senator Sanders has made some comments in the media basically pointing out that, on the last occasion on which this matter was debated, the Opposition indicated support of the minerals regime. That is not correct. The Opposition has never publicly given any indication of support. When this matter has been debated during the last few months, the Opposition has consistently said that the matter was being discussed by the shadow Cabinet, as indeed it was, on the basis of a paper which I put forward in my capacity as shadow Minister for the environment, and shadow Cabinet came to a decision on that matter. That decision was endorsed by the joint Opposition parties at their meeting yesterday.

May I therefore turn to the basic objections that we have to the Convention. First, the Opposition asserts that the Convention is fundamentally inconsistent with underlying principles of the Antarctic Treaty itself, in that it is exclusive, exploitative, and majoritarian. Further, it introduces an element of competition and commercial rivalry which is totally at odds with the whole spirit of the original Treaty.

Secondly, we believe that the Convention itself establishes potential for conflict. As the Treasurer rightly observed in his letter, the harmony of the Antarctic regime has in part no doubt been based on the fact that the issue of who benefits has not previously been raised. This Convention will destroy that and will, no doubt, lead to international disputation over the issue of money. If, for example, one looks at an article in the Australian newspaper of 23 January 1986 headed, `Mineral search threatens to melt Antarctic Treaty', that makes the point quite clearly. Thirdly, we believe that the Convention introduces an unnecessary element of secrecy into its operations. Articles 37 (11) and 37 (12) of the proposed Convention provide for commercial secrets to be maintained by the sponsoring states. This is the first time that any Antarctic instrument has contained secrecy provisions. All others specify that all information must be open and made available to all Antarctic parties and to the international scientific community. The Opposition regards this as a very dangerous precedent.

Next, we believe there is a genuine question of the loss of sovereignty. If the Convention is enacted in its current form Australia will not be able to decide which mineral activity takes place in its own claimed area. We will lose our veto over activity within our own territory once the minerals resources commissions have passed power to the Regulatory Commission, which will make final decisions in the matter. In our opinion, it would lead to a free-for-all within our own sovereign territory once an explorer has been granted a permit by the Minerals Resources Commission. The Convention even gives the regional regulatory commissions, which Australia cannot control, power to override the expert and independent advice of the scientific, technical and advisory committees which are set up under other aspects of Antarctic law.

Next, there is the question of the associated loss of revenue. No royalty is payable to Australia for mineral activity undertaken in our territory. Again, the Opposition regards this as a bad precedent. The revenue surplus which may accrue to the Commission from payments by licensees does not, on one interpretation of the relevant article-namely, article 35 (7) (b)-have to be shared in any particular fashion so as to recognise Australia's claim to benefit from activities taking place within the Australian Antarctic Territory.

Then there is the question of subsidised mining. The analysis of the history of the Convention will indicate some very significant problems as far as this is concerned. When one looks at the original Chairman's draft, a document entitled MC/17 REV-V, the following point was included under proposed article 2 (Objectives):
(f) follow orderly mining practices and act in an economically rational manner;

This was deleted from the final text at the insistence of the United States of America. In its place a mere statement appears in the text of the final act of the consultative meeting of 2 June 1988 to the effect that `unfair economic practices', including subsidies, `should be addressed in the context of the relevant multi-lateral agreements'. Given the recent experiences which we have had with the United States and others with our trade subsidies I believe that this is a clear indication that the United States, Japan, perhaps Germany and other parties would proceed with a regime which includes subsidised mining in the Antarctic.

One must consider that the greatest threat is not so much physical mining activity taking place on that 2 per cent of the continent which is ice free, but rather drilling and prospecting in the offshore waters and on the continental shelf of the Antarctic for oil and hydrocarbon resources. Given the fact that the Japanese have enormous financial surpluses available to their Government to subsidise these sorts of activities; that they have a program for deliberate support of private sector companies, the so-called NEDO programs, which are involved in seeking alternative sources of fuel and energy for Japan, and that the Japanese, as we know, are chronically short of their own oil resources, I believe there is a very real risk, despite the technological difficulties and the economic costs concerned, that the Japanese would want to and would be attracted to subsidised activity in the search for oil in the Antarctic, with the potential for all of the disastrous consequences of a version of the Exxon Valdez problem or the blow-outs which have been seen in oil operations in the Gulf of Mexico in recent years. Of course, we know of a couple of recent oil spills in the Antarctic region involving both an Argentinean vessel and a Peruvian vessel.

The next point in terms of our criticism of the Convention is that we believe that the provisions establishing the liability of operators for the consequences of their failure to observe proper environmental standards are inadequate. Article 8 (4) of the Convention provides for a limitation on liability of an operator for environmental damage which `could reasonably have been foreseen'. Given just how disastrous the environmental consequences of a major disaster in the Antarctic could be, the Opposition regards this as quite unacceptable. It is only if operators are subject to a strict international regime of full liability that they will ever take the care which is necessary. The failure of nations such as Poland and the Soviet Union to take due care in matters such as observing fishing quotas, especially for krill, gives no cause for confidence; even less so does the clear track record of major companies of a nation like Japan, which will no doubt be in the forefront of oil exploration. The issue which I have previously raised about the subsidised search for oil in the Antarctic is of particular relevance.

One could make a number of other criticisms. I have focused on some of them. From Australia's point of view there will undoubtedly be a diversion of resources into control or monitoring of mineral activities. We spend little enough as it is in establishing our proper claims in the Antarctic. We spend little enough as it is in pursuing the proper scientific and environmental work which ought to be undertaken. I do not believe that we should divert resources for this purpose.

Environmental concerns include those which may occur as a result of natural disasters which could be precipitated by such things as seismic activity undertaken as part and parcel of an exploration or mineral development program. I refer also to the impact of additional activity on areas such as the very limited emperor penguin rookeries and the impact on scarce fresh water supplies. For instance, the Davis Base has already drained Station Tarn Lake to provide regular supplies of water to a small station. Unnecessary problems have been caused by a failure to manage garbage disposal properly in the Antarctic. There are major questions about infrastructure concerns, such as the potential for building solid runways for heavy aircraft-an already controversial matter having regard to French activity at Dumont D'Urville which has been condemned by the Opposition, and which was condemned by Senator Brownhill in his capacity as acting shadow Minister for the environment in a press release which he issued on 19 January this year. Certainly, we should consider the loss of that aesthetic quality of the Antarctic wilderness which is very important and which has always impressed those people who have had the opportunity actually to visit the Antarctic.

I know that the immediate response to this debate by Senator Gareth Evans will be to make all sorts of accusations of improper motives. He will undoubtedly wave a copy of Ian Warden's article in today's Canberra Times which he has in front of him at the moment and make all sorts of claims that this is a matter which has been raised only because of political considerations. He is entitled to make any such claims that he likes, but people who have followed this debate, including all of the representatives of the conservation associations-the Australian Conservation Foundation, the Wilderness Society, the various Southern Ocean coalitions who have had discussions with me and with Mr Howard over a number of months-will know that this is a matter which we have been pursuing and that we have kept them fully apprised of the work being done by the Opposition back bench committee chaired by Don Dobie, MP, and by me, within the resources available to me as the shadow Minister.

They will know of the extent to which they have provided information which has been drawn on very heavily in the discussions which have taken place both in the shadow Cabinet and in the joint party rooms. They will be in a position to make a judgment as to whether what I have been saying to them, what Mr Howard has been saying to them and what the Opposition has been saying to them over a period of some months about the way in which we were attempting to resolve this sits well or does not sit well with the claims that Senator Evans or anybody else might make that this is purely a political stunt. They will be able to judge that in exactly the same way as they will judge what political stunt may be pulled by any political party in dealing with environmental matters.

Nevertheless, we have consistently said, as we did in the debate on Senator Vallentine's motion, that we were developing a position on this matter, that we were not ready to vote on the matter until it had been properly considered by our shadow Cabinet and in our party room. That process having been in train for a considerable period, and having now been completed, the Opposition parties make it quite clear that their concluded view is as expressed in the motion-that Australia should neither sign nor ratify the proposed minerals convention, that we should take steps as a nation to convene a meeting of the Antarctic Treaty parties to develop an effective regime to prohibit mining in the Antarctic and that the Australian Government should take steps to increase its own level of environmental and scientific activities and commitment to the Antarctic.

I hope that by the passage of this motion today, the Government will be given an indication of the view of the majority of the Senate and that the Government will be able to take that on board when it seeks to reconcile the conflicting opinions which exist within its own ranks. I hope that at the end of the day this debate will have made some contribution to persuading the Government to adopt precisely the position which the motion puts down and to make a significant contribution to the protection not only of the Antarctic environment but, indeed, of the environment of planet Earth as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government strongly agrees with the first leg of Senator Puplick's motion in so far as it commits us to the proposition that the Antarctic continent should be protected as fully as possible from threats to its unique environment. Equally, in the second paragraph, in its reference to mining activity, I can certainly say unequivocally that the Government would need a very high level of persuasion before it was prepared to accept the proposition that mining activity of any kind in that unique environment would be compatible with protecting that unique environment.

SPEECH.PARA: But there are a number of other aspects in the motion which are much more arguable. Certainly we would find it quite premature to endorse that part of the motion which urges us to refuse to sign and ratify the proposed minerals convention. The Government is considering whether we should do just that. The argument that we have to wrestle with-and I do not honestly think that Senator Puplick wrestled with it-is that signature of this convention may well prove to be unquestionably the best way of protecting that unique Antarctic environment. Certainly, that is the kind of thing which is very strongly arguable for reasons I will come to in a moment. Certainly it is the view that Government negotiators have adopted to date in seeking to get the best possible content into that convention and certainly it is a view that we are going to have to take very seriously into account.

Senator Puplick demonstrated some untoward sensitivity in the latter part of his speech, anticipating as he did that his motives would be somewhat brought into question as a result of moving this motion. Methinks Senator Puplick doth protest too much. There are all sorts of reasons for thinking that what we are confronted with today is the emergence of a quite remarkable new phenomenon in this place. Mr Ian Warden in the Canberra Times captured with considerable precision and deftness the dimensions of that phenomenon. We really ought to share Mr Warden's contribution with the rest of the Senate as Senator Puplick was kind enough to mention it in his own speech. Mr Warden said:

We all thought we knew where we were with the Liberals on environmental matters and felt comfortable in taking some of our own political bearings from their horrid ideas on the luscious mineability of everything, everywhere. And so it is that ringing declarations from a Liberal-
he was referring, of course, to Senator Puplick's putting down of the notice of motion yesterday-

about the environmental sanctity of Antarctica have an incongruous and perplexing quality about them, as though a legendary anti-Semite had suddenly found virtue in the Jews or as though a Pope had spoken out in favour of abortion.

It would be churlish to speculate that this is token greenness on the part of the Liberals and that they have chosen to become green-tinged about a far-flung and penguin-infested place, which, while it may be dear to the hearts of environmentally aware voters, is not itself divided into electorates and hence does not present any of the difficult and vulgar jobs versus-conservation issues presented by environmental issues in Australia. Churls will say that for the Liberals, Antarctica is so far out of sight and out of mind as to be no more real and immediate to them than one of the rings of Saturn.

There is lots more in the same vein but I think that is sufficient to capture the flavour. I often say that there are two kinds of people in the world: those who find Ian Warden funny and those who do not. I suspect that Senator Puplick may well have been in the former category but I cannot blame him this morning for being in the latter.

In any event, be that as it may, what is the substance of this proposition that we are wrestling with? The Government is wrestling with it, I hasten to say, very seriously indeed. We are not being cursory or dismissive in our reaction to the arguments that are coming forward from Senator Puplick and others. To understand where we are at on this whole matter it is necessary to go back a step or two to the Antarctic Treaty system itself and Australia's aspirations and role in relation to it. Over the years successive Australian governments have maintained six different objectives in respect of Antarctica: first, to maintain the Antarctic region free from strategic and political confrontation; secondly, to preserve Australia's sovereignty or claims of sovereignty over the Australian Antarctic Territory; thirdly, to protect the Antarctic environment; fourthly, to take advantage of the special opportunities it offers for scientific research; fifthly, to be informed about and able to influence developments in a region geographically proximate to Australia; and, finally, to derive possible economic benefits from the living and non-living resources of that Territory.

The Antarctic Treaty system has been seen, I think quite sensibly, by successive Australian governments as the best vehicle-in fact the only conceivable vehicle-for pursuing these various objectives. We were one of the original signatories to the Treaty which was concluded in 1959 by the then 12 nations which had maintained Antarctic stations during the International Geophysical Year in 1957-58. The Treaty came into force in 1961 and since then the number of Treaty parties has grown to 39. Included in this number are the so-called consultative parties, now 22 of them, so designated because they are engaged in substantial scientific research in Antarctica. These are the parties which actually manage the Antarctic Treaty system.

The Treaty itself has been supplemented by additional instruments for the management of Antarctica, including the Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Seals, the Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources and now, in that context, the proposed Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities. Collectively, these instruments and activities taking place under them have come to be known as the Antarctic Treaty system. I think it has to be said that in terms of advancing those various objectives, not only on Australia's behalf but in terms of the world's interests in maintaining a stable strategic and natural environment down there, the Treaty system has been tremendously important in keeping together what could otherwise be a very messy situation.

The need for a convention governing the possible exploitation of minerals became apparent to the Antarctic consultative parties in, as Senator Puplick said I think, the mid-1970s. It was recognised then that failure to put in place some agreement on mineral exploitation activities could lead to an unregulated scramble for resources with resulting conflict over claims and damage to the fragile environment. This prospect directly threatened then, as it does now, the whole fragile Treaty system. In fact, it was more a concern to preserve the Antarctic Treaty system than a concern with the distant prospect-and it still is distant-of possible economic benefits which, in 1982, led to the start of negotiations for a minerals convention. Those negotiations have been very protracted, as I think again Senator Puplick has indicated, with 12 sessions of negotiations over six years culminating in the adoption in June last year of a final act, a formal document, recording the state of agreement, thus far, and a convention. It was also agreed, as has been said, to continue a moratorium on mineral resource activities pending timely entry into force of the Convention. One of the real issues we have to wrestle with is whether, failing the entry into force of a convention within a reasonable time, that moratorium will be able to be sustained. It cannot be assumed that it will be.

The decision then to commence negotiations for this Convention-which I rather wish in retrospect had been called an environment protection convention rather than the name it was given because essentially that is what it is about and I think it would have saved us a lot of trouble in the process-was influenced not by a concern to get access to and economic benefit out of it but by a concern, as I have said, to preserve the Antarctic Treaty system by avoiding the disputes which would be likely to arise from any unregulated attempt which might be made to engage in mineral activities. The point has been made by those closest to this affair over the years that, failing entry into force of this sort of convention, the prospect of such a scramble and such a breakdown of this house of cards-the Treaty system itself-is very real. The Chairman, Chris Beeby of New Zealand, noted in a recent paper:

In the worst case the result could be a breakdown of the Treaty, the loss of the disarmament regime that it contains and, more generally, of the stabilising effect that it has had on the entire area south of 60 degrees south latitude.

So much for the background to the minerals Convention. Let us come back to the proposal that is before us. Throughout the course of the negotiations we have argued vociferously, vigorously and, for the most part, pretty effectively for environmental protection provisions in this Treaty which have been far-ranging and of really significant impact in their character. We wanted strict liability; we wanted unlimited liability; we wanted narrow defences for anyone who might engage in such activity and cause environmental damage in the process; we wanted strict threshold requirements to be satisfied before people could get in there and do anything at all; we wanted an effective enforcement mechanism; and we wanted a substantial role for the countries with actual territorial claims as distinct from those which are just drifting around the edges, so as to enhance our capacity to impose this sort of regime. I think it has to be said that, overwhelmingly throughout negotiations, we have been successful in achieving these various objectives. When the text was adopted by consensus back in June 1988 it contained most of the provisions that we were seeking to put in it.

The Convention is a very long and complex document but it is based on a set of objectives and principles set out in the document itself which are structured in this way and it is important to appreciate this: the Convention prohibits mineral exploration and development unless it is judged, based upon assessment of adequate information, that those developments would not cause a significant adverse impact on the environment, on living resources and on weather patterns. Again, mineral exploration activity and any subsequent development are prohibited unless technology ensure safe operations. Again, these activities are prohibited unless the capacity exists to monitor key environmental and ecosystem parameters and to respond effectively to accidents.

The Convention is not one that is premised on the assumption that mining will take place or that it should take place. The Convention provides a framework for deciding, based on environmental and other information, whether mineral exploration may take place and, if it is ever approved, for closely regulating it when it occurs. In fact, it provides that mining shall not take place unless it is clear, as I have said, on the basis of objective criteria, that mining will cause no significant environmental harm. It may be that, judged against these criteria, the Convention will operate in practice to effectively rule out mining altogether. All of those things need to be understood because an enormous amount of argument that we have heard in public and in this chamber from conservation groups and from those speaking along those lines is based on the premise that the Convention equals mining in Antarctica, that the Convention is somehow premised on the assumption that mining will occur, must occur and should occur and that the whole Convention is, by its very character, structured in such a way as to advance that as an objective.
