That is not the objective at all of the Convention and it is tremendously important to appreciate that right at the outset. I think a failure to appreciate that colours and prejudices looking at the Convention calmly and objectively on its merits.

Of course, two basic positions are becoming evident in the public debate on the question of signature of the Convention. Firstly, there is the view that, if there were no Convention, there would be no mining. Secondly, there is the view at the other end of the spectrum that the Convention is an appropriate way to seek to ensure proper regulation and environmental protection. I have been seeking to make it clear that the Convention, as drafted, certainly contains within it the elements enabling proper regulation and proper environmental protection. Certainly it is not premised on any assumption that mining will occur. It may be that there is some halfway house between those two positions. It has been argued by a lot of people that, if some appropriate leverage is exerted, the Convention can be improved in a number of ways. That is something that remains to be seen. It is certainly something that we will continue to look at very carefully, although certainly not everything that we wanted ended up in the Convention. It is certainly the case that there are additional machinery clauses, in particular relating to the liability regime, which remain to be negotiated in the subsequent protocol. It is certainly arguable that maybe some of those negotiations can and should be brought forward so as to run in tandem with the implementation, the coming into force, of the Convention itself.

All of these issues will be ones that we will consider very closely in the period ahead, particularly since it has now become apparent that Australia is not the only country that has a continuing debate going on about the signature of the Convention. Such a debate is now very obviously going on in France as well. This is very interesting since France, throughout the course of the negotiations, was one of the industrialised countries that was most keen to have a limited liability regime and less than formidable environmental protection provisions. The atmospherics in that country have changed and that may make it possible for some of these things-in particular, the terms of the liability protocol which remain to be negotiated-to be strengthened.

But the basic point that I want to repeat is that, without going so far as to say that I believe that signing the Convention is the only way forward at this stage, certainly it is arguable, from everything that I have said to date, that a convention with the regime that I have described is the only way of ensuring that proper threshold barriers are placed against mining activity and that, as a result, the environment is fully preserved. It should be noted in this respect that quite a lot of the opposition to signing the Convention does not come only from the left wing, the environmental lobby, but also from the right wing, the mining industry. It is based on the view that the environmental protection provisions as they presently exist make it too difficult to exploit such mineral resources as may exist in the Antarctic.

We keep on coming back to the issue. We have common objectives, namely, the protection of the Antarctic environment. What is the best way of getting there? Is it through a convention of the kind that is on the table before us, or is it through a course of action which would lead to the obstruction of the coming into force of that convention and a hope that there could be an extension of the absolute moratorium that now prevails? This is the nub of the question we now come to. It has to be said that without a convention in place containing the elements that I have described, the way could be open for unregulated mining, with no coherent provisions at all for protecting the environment.

In the absence of a convention a claimant country, let us say for the sake of argument Argentina, could make an important mineral discovery in its Antarctic territory and decide to go ahead and mine. Some non-claimant industrial majors, for example the United States, Germany, Japan, could themselves combine to mine perhaps in the unclaimed sector, perhaps in a sector which is claimed by somebody else given that the sovereignty claims of all countries with claims in Antarctica are pretty fragile. The example of the reciprocal arrangements which have been entered into between some major industrial countries which did not sign the United Nations Law of the Sea Convention is relevant here-the kind of industrial partnerships that it is possible to imagine occurring and being implemented in practice in various parts of the Antarctic continent.

There is at present an informal moratorium on mining in Antarctica. The 33 negotiating states at the Wellington meeting on the minerals convention agreed that this should continue pending the Convention's timely entry into force. But what is a timely entry into force? What degree of patience will have to be exercised by those countries with an interest in getting to work on the ground? There are unquestionably some of them with that gleam in their eye at the moment. It must be said that if the Convention goes into limbo, does not come into force, we could see an end to this present commitment to restraint, which has always itself been a rather fragile affair. It cannot be assumed that it will continue indefinitely.

Senator Puplick said that he and the Liberals are not running the idea of a world park, which has a great deal of appeal to all sorts of other people and obviously has an intuitive emotional appeal. Nonetheless, he expresses enthusiasm for the concept of an ongoing moratorium. In practice, though, I have to say that the concept of an ongoing, open-ended moratorium on resource development activity in practice would produce a result that is very much akin to that which is involved in a world park concept where mineral resource activity would be prohibited forever. Because they are parallel concepts, exactly the same considerations have to be addressed. Will a moratorium stick? Will the argument for the forswearing of any possible future interest in resource development of the kind that is involved in a world park concept be attainable? They are different ways of asking the same question, and it is a question addressing to the realities of the international environment as we find it.

In that respect we have some useful evidence already on the table as to what the likely reaction of the international community may be. The world park proposal has had a run in the past. It was put forward by New Zealand in 1975 when the minerals issue was at a very early stage of consideration. It was rejected out of hand, not because there was any immediate interest in mining in Antarctica, but because Treaty parties were not prepared to foreclose the possibility that, should exploitable resources exist there, they might one day be extracted, albeit under stringent regulation, and albeit subject to the proviso that such activity was first found to be safe and environmentally acceptable-in other words, subject to the conditions contained in the present convention.

Treaty parties faced with the reality of that kind of response, which unquestionably continues to be the response of all the major industrialised countries, and most of the claimant states as well right through to the present, then went about pursuing what they perceived to be the realistic alternative of negotiating a convention to establish mechanisms for deciding whether areas of Antarctica should be opened up to mining and for regulating it if it should occur. The environmental standards which have been established are arguably the toughest that exist in any international agreement.

The other dimension that needs to be mentioned is the notion that Australia somehow can credibly go it alone-that we could at least proclaim a national park in our own territorial claim area in Antarctica and perhaps set some moral or practical example of forbearance in regard to development activity in that segment of the country. But to make that kind of suggestion and to build upon it any of the other notions about a world park or a moratorium by the territorial claimants to Antarctica at the moment is to fail to appreciate yet again the fragility of the claims. I am not making any great public confession of a point that is not supremely obvious to all those who are familiar with this area when I refer to the fragility of Australian and other claims to territorial sovereignty. Our own claim is based on exploration activity, occupation, variety of legislative and administrative acts and a long course of scientific activity. The Australian claim has long been challenged by a number of countries. It has only been expressly recognised by four countries, the United Kingdom, New Zealand, France and Norway. It has not been recognised by the United States or the Soviet Union, the two countries which have engaged in the greatest exploration and activity within our sector.

As to our claim, I do not want to get into all the labyrinthine legal arguments about what constitutes occupation and so on under international law. Nothing we have done has, any more than is the case for any of the other claimant states, the kind of universal, international recognition which would give us an absolutely rock solid claim to the kind of tenure which could exclude activity by other countries. The whole Antarctic Treaty system, which I began by describing, while ostensibly preserving the position of various territorial claims that have been made has set a trend of emptying asserted claims to sovereignty, Australia's among them, of any real practical content. The Antarctic Treaty initially provided for this by demilitarisation and freedom of movement for the purpose of scientific research. The Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources involved giving up the right to national regulation of marine resources in maritime zones surrounding Antarctica. So, in successive incremental ways, sovereignty claims are, in effect, continuing to be undermined by this generalised regime of which we are enthusiastic supporters. It is about the only way that we can continue to sustain any kind of credible toehold on the Antarctic continent.

The fascinating point about the minerals convention is that it stands alone among the various Antarctic Treaty system documents-all those I have mentioned-in expressly recognising a special position for claimant states such as Australia. It does this in providing for representation on the key institutions of the Convention, the regulatory committee, the commission and so on, and in according claimant states special voting rights. Given the trend of events since the negotiations for the Antarctic Treaty back in the 1950s, this concession by other countries-a concession to a point that was strenuously argued for and fought for by Australia-is a major achievement and all we could realistically hope for in that respect.

I make the point in yet another way that this Convention does offer advantages for Australia and for the sorts of principles that the Australian Government has been traditionally trying to espouse, environmental protection principles pre-eminently among them, which may simply not be attainable under any alternative approach. There is the vacuum approach which just says, `Abandon the convention and keep your fingers crossed that there will not be a scramble'; the approach which says, very optimistically, as Senator Puplick has done, `Let us argue for a continuation of a moratorium'; and the approach which argues, even more optimistically, for the creation, through some sudden universal conversion to values which have not hitherto been obvious, the sudden commitment to a world park. Those alternatives-at least the moratorium and the world park alternatives-have obvious attractions. But the huge question all of us have to confront and ultimately answer is whether they offer any better chance of protecting the environment than what is contained in this Convention. One is entitled to suggest, as many people have within the Government-although it is not an issue that is yet finally resolved-that the minerals Convention does offer the best way forward in preserving those values and advancing those causes in which I think all of us in this chamber share a common belief and a common commitment.

For that reason it is far too premature, far too robust and far too pre-emptive an approach to try, as this motion does, to commit us right now to refusing to sign and ratify the proposed minerals Convention. In going down that course we may be cutting off our nose to spite our face. It may not be the most appropriate way to go about achieving the objectives that we all want to see implemented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The presentation by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) takes me back to the Vietnam War days when an American military officer said, `Well, we had to destroy the village in order to save it'. Senator Evans is trying to get us to believe that we should put in place a mining convention in order to protect the environment. What an extraordinary line of logic. What he has stated basically is that, rather than having an unregulated scramble, he favours a regulated scramble for the minerals in the Antarctic. I note that the Minister is leaving the chamber. We sat quietly and patiently listening to his presentation.
—I'll read it in Hansard.
—He says that he is going to read it in Hansard, but he does not do us the courtesy of listening to our presentations.
—I am here listening on his behalf. You're right; you have the ear of the Government.
—I note that Senator Cook is in the chamber. I am sure that he will keep an open ear to the proceedings.
—The wisdom of the Democrats.

—To `the wisdom of the Democrats', as my learned colleague informs me. I am afraid that Senator Evans and the Government are completely out of touch with the real world. I hesitate to say this, but I think at the moment the Liberal Party and the National Party are more in tune with what is going on in the real world and in the minds of the people than is the Government.
—To get that from you is very worrying.

—Senator Hill says that it makes him worried. As Ian Warden would say, we are all worried when Senator Puplick makes an environmental statement, so I guess that is fair. The fact is that the situation has changed. Senator Evans said, `Well, the world park concept was rejected in the past; it is not realistic'. Yes, it was rejected in the past, but the times have changed. They have changed so much that Margaret Thatcher of all people is now professing to be a greenie.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government, living in its rarefied atmosphere, with its bunker mentality and its ministerial offices and the big white cars, does not realise that the times have changed. They have changed largely because of the greenhouse effect, which has brought home the environmental situation, the parlous state of the environment, to many people around the world. On my recent trip to China I found that the main topic of conversation was environmental pollution. Around the world this is a major issue. The Government does not recognise that the public opinion around the world would support and does support a world park in the Antarctic. It is operating in the past; it is putting its faith in treaties. In the past treaties have been worthless in the Antarctic; they have not done a thing for it. The only thing that protects the Antarctic from exploitation and development is economics. At this time it is simply uneconomic to mine for minerals there; it is simply uneconomic to drill for oil. It is not because of any treaty or any agreement; it is because it is uneconomic. When the economies get viable, treaty or no, the developers will be in there open slather and no minerals convention will stop them.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a philosophy of despair, isn't it?

—It is a philosophy of despair. This world is in parlous trouble. It is in deep trouble with ozone problems, the greenhouse effect, and pollution of the water and the air because of the lack of effectiveness of the law, of treaties. We have to take a new look, a new step. We cannot rely on these treaties. What have treaties done to protect the Antarctic cod, the krill or, indeed, anything else in the Antarctic? The treaties have done nothing; it is economic pressure and public pressure that are important. Public pressure is becoming more and more powerful. The whaling stopped not because of any treaty but because of the activities of organisations such as Greenpeace and others which put the pressure on, which focused the public attention, leading to public pressure. Public pressure, not treaties, is what is important here.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans informs us that under this treaty no mining would take place unless it could be proven that there would be no significant damage. The Antarctic is the most fragile environment on earth. Anything that happens in the Antarctic will affect that area. The mere presence of human beings upsets the balance. That is why we call for the proclamation of a world park. Senator Evans also said that the treaty would call for the best available technology. In my previous incarnation as a university professor at the University of California in Santa Barbara, I spent six years studying and working on the problems of offshore oil development, watching technology develop and watching what happened when the technology failed. Scientists still have not been able to ensure blow-out free offshore drilling. They still have one blow-out for 1,500 wells. There is no way in which their technology can get any better than this. I predicted at the time of the North Sea oil development-in fact I wrote the cover story for the New Scientist-the disasters which happened in the North Sea. I worked with the Norwegian Government in framing legislation to try to avoid some of those things. I was also a violent opponent of the Alaska pipeline and I foresaw what happened a month ago in Valdez. I predicted that along with many other people.

The oil companies will always say that they have the best available technology. They will always say that no accidents will happen, but they will. Does the Government think that the oil companies are not looking at that area right now? In the Bulletin about a month ago there was an obscene photograph, or a montage, showing an iceberg with a drilling rig right next to it. Of course if this iceberg shifts its position-and they do; they float-it would wipe out the drilling rig. This is really an advertisement for an Australian rig building firm called Eglo Engineering Pty Ltd. It states:
When you look at Eglo, what you see is only the tip of the iceberg.

The company says that it can build rigs all over the world, even in the Antarctic. It is looking at the area and, as is obvious from this advertisement, has absolutely no concept of the problems involved there. It must be stopped at all costs.

Members of the Opposition have turned green. I welcome them. Ian Warden was mentioned at great length by Senator Evans. I would like to bring to the Senate's attention that other magnificent contributor to the Canberra Times, Mr Pryor, its cartoonist, who has a cartoon in today's paper. It shows Andrew Peacock with green leaves and stems coming out of his head and holding up a sign saying, `Keep the miners out'. John Howard also has plants growing out of his body and is holding a sign which says, `No mining in the Antarctic'. Senator Puplick, minus his bow tie but wearing a double-breasted suit-he is dressed very stylishly indeed-is carrying a sign saying, `Hands off the frozen continent'. Two individuals who look like public servants are walking by and saying, `Worst case of election fever I've ever seen'. That may be so; but, as I said earlier, I welcome the Opposition's support. If the Opposition realises the depth of the feeling in the community about the Antarctic and wishes to capitalise on it, more power to it; good on it.

I wonder, though, whether the Opposition realises that it may be the force which can kill this treaty completely. I do not know that it realises this. I hope that it does. I hope that its action is not merely a churlish and cynical act to gain political support. I hope that the Opposition is not just going to let this motion die. It probably will pass and that will be the end of it. I hope that the Opposition does not feel that that is the end of it. I hope that it realises that this whole issue may come back before the Parliament and it may have the opportunity to vote yea or nay on this treaty.

I refer to the document entitled the Australian Treaty List put out by the Department of Foreign Affairs in Canberra. It is part of Treaty Series 1971 No. 1. It says, under the heading `Ratification':

Some treaties become effective upon signature. Others require ratification, that is, formal confirmation by a signatory State. Ratification again is an Executive act and the approval of the Governor-General is accordingly necessary before any international agreement in inter-governmental form is ratified by Australia. Matters of this nature are normally placed before the Governor-General in Council by the Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, and when approval for ratification has been given, the appropriate instrument of ratification is executed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Although ratification is an executive act, in practice agreements of major political significance are frequently submitted to Parliament for approval before ratification. Reference to Parliament is, of course, necessary where legislation is required to put into effect within Australia the terms of a treaty. State Governments are also often consulted . . .

It looks as though this may in fact come back before the Parliament as a Bill. When and if it does, I sincerely hope that the Opposition will remember the strong words that were spoken today against this treaty. I sincerely hope that the Opposition will join the Democrats and the Independents in defeating this treaty once and for all. If Australia led the way in the world in defeating this treaty, it would give strength to the other nations to actually push ahead for a world park concept and we would be able to preserve the Antarctic in perpetuity and not merely have a moratorium on mining that the Opposition would like to have but have perpetual care for this last great wilderness area on earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be able to support a `green' motion from the Liberal Party of Australia as it stands. But I agree with Senator Sanders that it does not go far enough. I believe that the second part of my original urgency motion should be added to it.
—The coalition. It is a coalition matter.
—I beg your pardon; it is not just the Liberal Party but the coalition.
—It is important because the Nationals are part of this `green' decision.

—It is wonderful that the National Party of Australia is in on it as well. Part of my original urgency motion that came before the Senate on 12 April was to promote the formulation of a comprehensive conservation convention for the Antarctic based on the concept of a world park.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter was subject to debate on 12 April when Senator Puplick moved an amendment to my motion which called on the Government not to sign the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities (CRAMRA). Senator Puplick's amendment, in effect, called only for more discussions. Although I agree that more discussion in the community has been necessary, it was very obvious at that stage that the Liberal Party was not willing to vote against and not sign CRAMRA. I am very glad that the Liberal Party has come to that position in the past few weeks.

Obviously, the Liberal and National parties are responding to community concern on this subject. I would say that they have been lobbied very conscientiously. A lot of that lobbying has probably come from their own members who are genuinely concerned about this very important environmental issue and also they have no doubt been successfully lobbied by the Australian Conservation Foundation, which is doing a sterling job to preserve this unique wilderness for the world community.

Of course there are votes in this issue and perhaps the Australian Labor Party will recognise this soon, as the coalition has. Let me remind Senator Puplick, the coalition and the people of Australia of what was said here on 12 April by one of the Liberal Party spokespersons who entered the debate. That was Senator Crichton-Browne. He said:
. . . if Senator Richardson thought there were any greenie votes to be got out of not signing this thing, he certainly would not be signing it.

A little later he accused the Australian Democrats and me of having drawn ourselves together `in pursuit of whatever irresponsible leftover greenie vote there is'. That comment was made only a few weeks ago and he has obviously been proved wrong. I am very glad that the parties are bigger than the person in this case.

It is not an irresponsible vote. It is very sensible and very sane. It is certainly not a leftover greenie vote. It is a growing greenie vote. I am very glad that the coalition parties are responding to that. Senator Crichton-Browne also said that Australia's signature of CRAMRA was irrelevant. He said:
Whether or not the regime is signed by Australia will in no way affect whether or not there is mining in Antarctica.
That is a totally illogical statement. He also said:
The truth of the matter is that Australia will be able to make no contribution if it is not a signatory of the treaty.
I am very glad that his Party's more carefully considered position has shown his judgment to be wrong.

When we look at the Government's position we find that Senator Evans this morning has reiterated the Government line that CRAMRA will limit and monitor mining and that this is not based on an assumption that mining will occur. Whom is he kidding? It is not based on any logic at all. One does not stop something by regulating it. The Government is opening the door for mining to occur, albeit under scrutiny. The fact is that enormous pressure would be applied, once CRAMRA was in place, for the scramble for minerals in Antarctica as soon as it was seen to be economically viable, which Senator Sanders has already pointed out.

We can stop mining by not allowing any opportunities for that to occur by putting in place a creative alternative like the world park. The current moratorium on mining should be extended while a comprehensive conservation convention is worked out. Obviously, that will take quite some time. Senator Evans doubts whether a moratorium would stick while those discussions were in place. In other words, he has contradicted his own argument because what he was saying by implication was that as soon as CRAMRA is signed the countries and companies that have been waiting patiently all this time will immediately move ahead with their plans for mining. He knows that that is what will happen. I do not believe that we should be giving miners that chance. We should let them know now that Antarctica is off limits. We should let them psychologically adapt to that reality.

What the people of the world want is a world park to preserve the wilderness and the species which are at immediate risk if development is allowed to interfere with their lifestyles. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has publicly dubbed conservationists speaking on this issue as pixies and elves. It shows how out of touch the Minister is with the breadth and depth of feeling about the Antarctica. There must be millions and millions of pixies and elves who would like to see this last vestige of nature's magnificence relatively unspoilt by human activity.

There are not many untouched places on earth, which is why so many people are rallying to the sensible and popular cause of keeping Antarctica free and absolutely free of mining. It is not only mining that puts Antarctica's fragile environment at risk. Tourism is also a concern. That was mentioned, but not in any great detail, in the debate on 12 April. Limits to the kinds of tourism that would be allowed there should also be worked out in the context of a world park. If CRAMRA were signed the international cooperation of scientific teams also would be jeopardised. It has been a success story in research opportunities which are not limited by political considerations. That would disappear, too, because CRAMRA would turn Antarctica, like the rest of the world, into a competitive arena rather than a cooperative one, which it is, by and large, at the moment.

Australia has a special opportunity to make a stand on this issue. It would be a welcome change to be in the company of France. But it would be a great tragedy if the present Government squandered this special opportunity. I know that many Government members will not be happy about having to vote on party lines against this motion. I strongly encourage the Government to have the guts to do what the Opposition has done, which is to respond to popular opinion on this subject-to preserve Antarctica free from the ravages of mining.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by reflecting on the Opposition's response to the motion which Senator Vallentine moved a little over a fortnight ago in this chamber. I remind the Senate that Senator Vallentine's motion stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Australian government to refuse to sign the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities (CRAMRA), and instead to promote the formulation of a comprehensive conservation convention for the Antarctic, based on the concept of an Antarctic World Park.
On that occasion, Senator Puplick, who spoke for the Opposition, successfully moved, with the support of the Government, to amend that motion. He moved:

Leave out all words after `urgency:', insert: The need for the Australian Government to promote adequate public discussion of all of the issues arising in relation to whether or not Australia should become a signatory to the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities (CRAMRA).

In other words, a little over a fortnight ago we had the spectre of the Opposition strongly opposing the principal thrust of Senator Vallentine's motion. Now, a little over a fortnight later, the Opposition has turned around and is seeking to gain political mileage by supporting at least the first part of Senator Vallentine's motion, although I must reiterate-and I would like to speak later on the Opposition's second point-that it is not supporting the world park as an alternative.

We are very concerned that the Opposition in no sense understands the main thrust of conservation. Its basic program is still one of exploitation. Nonetheless, for political reasons on this occasion the Opposition has seen it desirable to support the rejection of CRAMRA. Like Senator Vallentine, I have to welcome that support because, hopefully, it will mean that when the Government introduces legislation, which I believe it should do before it can ratify CRAMRA, the Opposition will join with the Australian Democrats and the independent senators to reject that legislation. The Government would therefore have to reconsider an alternative to CRAMRA.

It is interesting that we have this image of a party as a whole turning around in a little over a fortnight. This indicates again the stupid instability of the party system which locks in members. I am sure that a fortnight ago many members of the Opposition were opposed to what Senator Puplick was saying, as there are probably members of the Opposition who are now opposed to what Mr Howard said recently in Queensland-comments which seem to have given the Opposition a new green tinge. Nonetheless, we have this flip-flop arrangement because of the operation of the party system which, clearly, is in nobody's interests.
All members of the Parliament would recently have received a letter from Jacques Costeau whose comments are a useful point at which to begin this debate. He writes:
Antarctica, a peaceful land, rich in opportunities for scientific research, is threatened. In spite of the best intentions of the nations which adopted the Wellington Convention-
he is referring there to CRAMRA-
. . . any attempt to exploit Antarctica's minerals carries serious hazards.
He then made an appeal. He said:

On the behalf of the 300,000 members of the Cousteau Society and its sister organization in France, Foundation Cousteau, we appeal to you, the members of the Australian Parliament, to oppose the Wellington Convention.

He has asked us to oppose CRAMRA. As I indicated in the debate here in this place a little over a fortnight ago, the Antarctic provides a very useful object lesson for us. It is always important to point to the conditions of which the proposed exploitation of the Antarctic is merely a symptom, rather than dwell on the symptom alone, as the debate so far this morning has done. I point out again that human beings, as a separate animal species, have been around for about six million years. We believe from cosmological evidence that we may be around for another 500 million years if we look after our environment. We have had some one per cent of our life on this planet so far; we are a very young animal. Yet already, in just 200 years of industrial exploitation of the planet, we have apparently got to the stage where we need to wreck the last continent on earth in exactly the same way as we have wrecked every other continent in seeking the last few resources which will prop up this industrial so-called civilisation.

Surely our desperation for resources after such a short time should give us an indication that something is wrong with the way in which industrial civilisation is exploiting this fragile planet. Rather than seeking to get a few more years supply of oil, copper, iron or anything else out of the Antarctic, we should bear in mind that our descendants into the distant future have a right to call on those resources. We should be doing something far more substantial in relation to adopting more conservative ways of approaching the planet; in other words, we should be living with the environment instead of living against it.

As Senator Sanders pointed out earlier, we have abundant evidence of the serious damage that we are doing on a global scale. There are serious problems of ozone depletion, particularly over the Antarctic. There are major changes in the composition of the atmosphere, with a whole range of greenhouse gases coming from our industrial activity. We do not yet know how to turn that around. We have serious resource depletion in many areas. We are slaughtering tropical rainforests and other forests at a prodigious rate. Surely we should be saying to ourselves, `Look, there is something wrong with the way we are proceeding. We should not be going into places like the Antarctic. We should not be seeking just to get a little more of a resource for a few more years'. Clearly, sooner or later, we must change and now is the time to bring about that change.

As several other speakers have pointed out, the Antarctic treaty has persisted and worked remarkably well for nearly 30 years. It has achieved a demilitarised zone and prohibited nuclear explosions, the dumping of nuclear waste and nuclear testing in that region. It has guaranteed the freedom of scientific research and the free exchange of scientific information based on that research. I point out that that position will not obtain if we see a minerals exploration-exploitation regime implemented in the Antarctic. Under such a regime, information which is gathered by companies will not be freely available to others.

The Antarctic has been used for these scientific and peaceful purposes and there has been a temporary hold on territorial claims. This has certainly worked well for quite a long time. It is intended to set up under CRAMRA a regime for controlling the exploration and exploitation of minerals in the Antarctic. Currently, activities in the Antarctic are covered under the existing treaty whereas, under CRAMRA, Australia would totally lose its right to control those activities of exploration and exploitation in that Territory which it claims as its own. However, at this stage, Australia is in an extremely strong position to control the direction of CRAMRA or any alternative treaty which might replace it. Under CRAMRA, those nations which claim territory in the Antarctic have a right of veto over CRAMRA. In short, if Australia refuses to ratify CRAMRA, CRAMRA does not come into operation.

Unfortunately, the motion moved by Senator Puplick does not really put anything in its place. I certainly join with Senator Vallentine and say that Australia should immediately take a lead not only in refusing to sign CRAMRA but also in bringing the Antarctic nations together to negotiate a new treaty aimed at establishing a world park in the Antarctic.

I totally disagree with Senator Evans. I agree with Senator Vallentine and Senator Sanders in believing that Senator Evans apparently is not aware of the enormous change in understanding and public opinion since 1975. The world is now aware of problems such as the greenhouse effect and the decrease in the stratospheric ozone, problems which will persist for centuries. At the recent Greensborough by-election, the poll showed that the four most important issues were environmental issues. That was not so in 1975, but it was the case this year. Also, it is not only in Australia; it is a worldwide phenomenon. It is against that background that we could now successfully move to negotiate an alternative treaty which would reject exploration and exploitation of minerals and put in place an alternative internationally agreed world park convention.

The supposition that we can proceed safely to explore and exploit minerals is based on the view that these conventions can be made to stick, that somehow there are technical devices that can be put in place that will ensure that harm will not occur; but it is quite clear that every really major accident in recent times was due not to failure of technology but to failure of the human technology interface; humans had failed. The Three Mile Island accident, the results of which are still being cleaned up years later at a cost of billions of dollars, resulted from human failure in the control room, an inability to understand the technology. At Chernobyl, again those in the control room were unable to understand properly what was going on in the reactor. Most recently and most relevantly in the Exxon Valdez disaster in Alaska, the skipper was evidently drunk and incapable of taking charge of the vessel, and the vessel, proceeding along a channel 16 kilometres wide, ran onto a rock and spewed oil over a very important area, something that the oil companies said would never happen.

There are numerous examples in the Antarctic in which the terms of treaties have led to a failure because of the inability of people-not the treaties-to cooperate. In 1977, the Antarctic Treaty nations gathered and signed the Convention on the Conservation of Marine Living Resources which was designed to regulate fishing in the region. All decisions under that convention had to be reached by consensus, and the nations agreed. But that crippling concession has shown that the conservation measures adopted can only be as strong as the most reluctant and shortsighted members. Between 1977, when it was signed, and 1983 it became clear that Antarctic fish stocks were being dangerously over-exploited and at least three species of fish had been so overfished in some areas, particularly around the island of South Georgia, that less than 10 per cent of the original stock remained. The attempt to control what was happening was thwarted and those proposals had to be put in place again by a consensus process.

Greenpeace found on Deception Island 47 barrels of fuel several of which were leaking their contents into the ground near a beach frequented by penguins, fur seals and several other species and birds. Some of these people in the Antarctic simply showed a total disregard for conventions. So it is human failure.

It is certain that if CRAMRA comes into place, with the best intentions in the world there will be accidents in the Antarctic which will do irreparable damage, because what is quite clear from the Exxon Valdez accident is that, even where a large population was in the near vicinity and presumably a number of facilities were already available, there was a complete inability to deal adequately with the oil spill. If something similar happened in the Antarctic there would be a total inability to cope with the damage. So we simply cannot afford to go down that road. We cannot afford to have exploration or exploitation of minerals in the Antarctic.

I mentioned earlier the problem caused by the change from the openness of scientific data, as applies now under the Antarctic Treaty, to the confidentiality of data under such an exploitative regime. It is quite clear that this would cause conflicts between competing nations, and the Antarctic would progressively descend from being a place of peaceful scientific exchange to one of conflict and competition between nations.

The Antarctic is a very important source of data for monitoring the global environment. One could reflect again on the very important work in the Antarctic in understanding the mechanism for ozone depletion in the stratosphere. The mechanisms of chemical reaction in the stratosphere, which were predicted in the early 1970s by Rowland and Molina, have substantially been confirmed by work in the stratosphere over the Antarctic. In view of the greenhouse effect and the cooling of the stratosphere, an understanding of that mechanism may become absolutely vital to a possible extension of that stratospheric ozone depletion to the rest of the world should the temperatures in the stratosphere over the rest of the world descend to those that obtain in the Antarctic. From ice core samples taken in the Antarctic, a picture can be built up of what the global atmosphere was like over almost the last 200,000 years and also what the global temperatures have been. That gives a very important fix on what is being done to the atmosphere at present. That type of work is likely to be interfered with very seriously if the exploration and exploitation of minerals are allowed to proceed in that area. It is a very important area from the point of view of getting that base data on the environment.

Senator Puplick and others have pointed out that only approximately 3 per cent of the Antarctic is not ice-covered. Of course, if exploration and exploitation go ahead that is precisely where buildings, runways and various other structures would preferentially be put. Again, that is precisely the area where many of the seals, penguins and other creatures of the Antarctic which can go on to the land build their nests and carry out other functions important to their life cycle. Even with a continent as vast as the Antarctic, there is an immediate conflict concerning the areas which it is important to protect, because only a very tiny part of the land surface is available for such biological activity and the sorts of activities which humans might want to carry out there.

The Australian Democrats support the motion put up by Senator Puplick, but we would prefer to extend it beyond merely calling for Australia not to sign CRAMRA but to seek an international agreement which would extend the limitation on mining exploration and exploitation. We would seek to extend it, as Senator Vallentine has already indicated, to the point at which Australia would take the lead and seek immediately to engage other nations in the establishment of a world park. I point out again, and this must be stressed, that Australia has been very reluctant to take a leading role. Australia seems to have adopted the mentality that it is a third-rate power. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) talked about a banana republic some time ago.

Let us stand up and be counted. We have an enormous opportunity here. As a claimant state we have an ability to veto CRAMRA. Let us do that, as the first thing. As the very next thing let us proceed down that same road and use that opportunity to establish a mechanism which would put into place a world park concept. Let us engage other nations in a dialogue which will lead to a new convention and which will see a world park established in the Antarctic. I would like to conclude with an appeal from Sir Peter Scott in which he said:

In my view, Antarctica stands at the crossroads. If the minerals convention is signed and brought into effect in its present form, it will mean that human greed, the desire for short-term profit, the urge to conquer new frontiers at whatever the cost to the environment, will have triumphed yet again. It will mean that the devastation brought over virtually the whole of the rest of the globe is likely to spread to the last wilderness. Antarctica represents the last chance we have of proving that we really will change our ways and begin living in harmony with the planet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Australian Democrats are not prepared to acknowledge the usual convention in these matters of one speaker a side, it is necessary for me to take a few minutes of the Senate's time to answer some of the matters that have just been put by the last speaker. Whilst there is much with which we would agree, where the last speaker failed was to acknowledge the leadership that has been taken by Senator Puplick and the Opposition in this critically important area. Therefore, I commence by reminding the Senate that this is a motion of the Opposition, reflecting its now announced policy in this area. Senator Puplick has this day moved:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate.
(a) is of the opinion that:
(i) the Antarctic continent should be protected as fully as possible from threats to its unique environment,
(ii) it is incompatible with the above to allow any mining activity to take place in the Antarctic-
that is clear and unambiguous-

(iii) the proposed Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities is flawed in a number of respects including being an inadequate vehicle for the proper protection of the Antarctic environment; and
(b) as a consequence, calls upon the Australian Government to:
(i) refuse to sign and ratify the proposed Minerals Convention,
(ii) take steps to convene a meeting of the Antarctic Treaty parties to develop an effective regime to prohibit mining in the Antarctic, and
(iii) increase its own level of environmental and scientific activities in the Antarctic.

In effect, the Opposition is indicating to the Government that it is our view, after legitimate debate within the parliamentary and political process, that the Government should now make a stand, take the lead within the world community and acknowledge that perhaps positions that have been taken in relation to the prospect of mining in the Antarctic are flawed, and that this Convention should not be ratified. Furthermore, as I have indicated, we advocate positive steps to be taken by this Government particularly in the area of lifting our environmental and scientific activities with the Antarctic, which have been much criticised as far as this Government's performance is concerned.

The Government should go one step further and not only say that it will not ratify this Convention, but draw the parties to the Treaty together to look at the first steps of putting in place an effective regime to prohibit mining in the Antarctic. I would have hoped that the members of the Australian Democrats would have applauded that position without qualification. Rather, they have sought today again to demean the debate in political terms by asserting that this motion is a populist act on behalf of the Opposition. That is clearly offensive to Senator Puplick who, I think, is accepted widely as having taken the lead in this debate for a long time and who has maintained a consistent position.

There was criticism that while the political process was taking place and our position was being debated within the party room it was not possible to support certain motions in this place. That is quite a legitimate position to take. It does not mean in any way that there is a change of attitude. The Opposition is proud of the leadership it is showing in this area and it is hopeful that the Government might respond positively to that leadership, now knowing that the parties which obtained more than 50 per cent of first preference votes in this country in the last Federal election are of the view that the Government should not ratify this Convention.

One of the reasons why the Opposition has reached this decision is that it seems to us to be inconsistent to say, on the one hand, that we are opposed to mining within the Antarctic and, on the other hand, that a convention which sets in place a regulatory mechanism for mining in the Antarctic should be ratified. Again this morning the Minister tried, to some extent, to argue that that simply was not so. It seems to us that one cannot maintain credibility in an argument in opposition to mining if one accepts a regime for mining. The Opposition stresses to the Government that if it is to go back to the consultative parties to the Treaty and maintain and promote an argument against mining, it cannot do so having ratified this Convention.

I do not underestimate Australia's role and influence in this area. I suspect I am one of the few senators who have actually played a part in the consultative party meetings in New York, when I had the privilege, two years ago, to be a parliamentary adviser to the Australian mission to the United Nations. I am well aware of the influence that Australia has, having been an original consultative party and having sought to maintain a lead in the Antarctic debate over the years. I repeat, that that is a lead which is becoming harder to sustain while this Government is not prepared to give the commitment that is needed, particularly in the scientific area in the Antarctic, to justify our continued assertions to sovereignty. Nevertheless, Australia is regarded as a leader within the Antarctic debate, and from that position of strength could be doing a lot more to promote a regime to prohibit mining than has been sought by this Government to date.

What we really find, I regret to say, is a government divided on the issue. In public statements, some Ministers advocate signing the Convention and some are opposed to it. One can only suspect that the Government's objective is again to attempt to give the impression that it is really opposed to the Convention and to mining in the Antarctic whilst, in the end, saying that it had little choice but to ratify the Convention. I reiterate what others have said: Australia and France are the two parties which still have the power to halt this process by refusing to ratify. We hope that the Government will take the lead that we have set today.

It is important to put the debate in context. When negotiations for this Convention started nearly a decade ago there was a different world attitude as to the safety of mining in areas that are environmentally fragile. Through many experiences in the meantime, the world community is now much more doubtful about our capacity to avoid very serious damage from unexpected side effects of that mining. We had one very recent tragic example-the Exxon Valdez vessel off Alaska. The world community has now changed its attitude a great deal. We are now seeing it in the debate that is taking place in Europe and in the United States as to whether this treaty is really the right way to go. That is indicative of the fact that if the Convention negotiations were to start today, rather than a decade ago, they would be of a very different nature. They would be, rather, along the lines of that which we advocate-a regime to prohibit mining and to protect the environment, rather than a scheme to regulate mining within Antarctica.

I do not think that there is anything wrong with Australia recognising that fact and saying that our attitude, together with that of most of the world community, has now changed. It is not too late to change our minds and say to our treaty partners in the Antarctic forums in New York, `We have changed our minds. We recognise that the world attitude to mining within fragile areas such as the Antarctic is very different today, and we want to approach this issue from a very different point of view'. I think that that sort of leadership would hold Australia high in international esteem. Having experienced attitudes within the world community in New York, you will be well aware, Mr Deputy President, that those who have a special privilege in relation to the Antarctic-sovereign claimants, claimants by virtue of their scientific endeavours in the Antarctic, and the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, which are also involved in the consultative process-are somewhat envied by the rest of the world community. While the rest of the world community will tolerate the special privileges we have in relation to the Antarctic, it nevertheless expects a great deal of us. It expects leadership, and I think that it has shown that in this debate we are heading in the wrong direction. Basically, that is our rationale in coming to the conclusion that this Government should now act, that at this belated stage it should show leadership by acting as we have set out in this motion.

I conclude by briefly putting our position in the context of our record on the environment. We have heard a lot of nonsense this morning from both the Australian Democrats and, in more moderate terms, Senator Vallentine, who said that this is some sort of last-minute greening. Sometimes the coalition's record in relation to environmental matters during its years in government has been understated, perhaps because we do not promote ourselves and our achievements as effectively as does the other side. Let me briefly put this decision on the environment in the context of our record in relation to parks. I refer to the proclamation of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park by our Government; our prohibition of sandmining on Fraser Island; the proclamation of the Kakadu and Uluru parks; the proclamation of the Christmas Island national park; and the proclamation of the marine nature reserves which were established under the Coral Sea proclamation.

The coalition had so many environmental firsts. I mention briefly those relating to the Antarctic. It was our Government that put in place the Antarctic Treaty Act 1960, the Antarctic Treaty (Environmental Protection) Act 1980 and the Antarctic Marine Living Resources Conservation Act 1981. It was our Government which secured the listing on the World Heritage List of the Great Barrier Reef, and Kakadu stage 1 in 1981, and which secured the listing of the Willandra Lakes. It was our Government that initiated proposals for the listing of the Lord Howe Island group and the Western Tasmania Wilderness National Parks in 1982. One could go on. If I were to take the time of the Senate I could refer to the Acts that we passed to prevent and to reduce pollution. All I am saying is that this is not a sudden greening. Anyone looking objectively at our proud record in relation to environmental protection over many years will see that this decision is but an extension of that record. Therefore, we have moved this motion in the genuine hope that the lead that we have shown will be taken up by the Government and that it, on behalf of all Australians will give the appropriate lead to the world community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to support the motion that has been moved by Senator Puplick. I am certainly very well aware of what the Opposition has done in relation to the environment in the past, and I am appreciative of those areas in which I consider that it has made considerable advances towards preserving the Australian environment. I am very pleased that this has emerged from the Opposition at a time when Australians of all political complexions are becoming very aware of the importance of preserving the environment. Through the excellent Australian Broadcasting Corporation program Four Corners, they have become aware of a place that they had never been to, namely the Antarctic, and the potential for devastation that is occurring there right now as well as the potential for devastation if the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities is signed and ratified. In the past, of course, this treaty was negotiated largely in secret. The negotiations began in 1981, and this Convention replaces the voluntary moratorium on mining that has been in place since 1977.

SPEECH.PARA: If ratified, the Convention will facilitate the exploitation of mineral deposits in the Antarctic. I and the Opposition, and, I think, the Australian Democrats, disagree with the Government on this matter. The Government claims that if the Convention is signed it will provide a mechanism for protecting the Antarctic and that the way will be clear for instituting some control, but I think it is very clear, from the way the French have already been behaving in the Antarctic, even without any controls in place, and from the terms of the Convention, that there is no way we could guarantee that mining would not occur in the Antarctic. It is my belief that the only way we can prevent that is by refusing to sign and ratify the Convention.

When Senator Evans tabled the document he drew attention to Australia's primary objectives in the Antarctic. He summarised them as follows: to maintain the Antarctic region free from strategic and political confrontation; to preserve Australia's sovereignty over the Australian Antarctic Territory; to protect the Antarctic environment; to take advantage of the special opportunities that Antarctica offers for scientific research; to be informed about and able to influence developments in a region geographically proximate to Australia; and to derive possible economic benefits from the living and non-living resources of the AAT. Yet we need to question whether this Convention, which is the most recent to be negotiated by the Antarctic Treaty nations, will be in either Australia's interests or in the interests of the Antarctic continent. If it comes into force it will change forever the nature of the continent and Australia's place in it.

Senator Evans also drew attention to the need to maintain the political and strategic stability of the Antarctic region as well as Australia's position as a claimant state. The Antarctic Treaty was negotiated in 1959 as a result of United States initiatives. Those initiatives arose from concerns about geo-political tensions which were generated by competing sovereignty claims in the area and by a desire that was engendered by the Cold War to prevent a dominant Soviet influence in the Antarctic. When the Treaty finally came into force in June 1961, the Antarctic was established as a zone of peace. That meant that it could not become the scene or object of international discord. Military activities are prohibited under the Treaty, as are nuclear explosions and the disposal of radioactive materials. Thus it was established as the world's first nuclear free zone.

Seven states lay claim to part of the Antarctic. Australia's claim of 42 per cent, as we have heard, is the largest. Other states claiming sovereignty over the continent are New Zealand, the United Kingdom, France, Chile, Argentina and Norway. The claims of Chile, Argentina and Britain overlap and in the past have been a source of conflict. Another 15 per cent of the continent is unclaimed. The United States and the Soviet Union maintain a basis of claim, that is, they maintain the right to lodge a claim at some time in the future.

The nature of these claims is complicated by the fact that they are not mutually recognised in international law by all the other Treaty states or by the non-signatories. Australia's claim, for example, is recognised by Britain and New Zealand and, in turn, Australia acknowledges the legitimacy of the claims of those two countries. However, article 4 of the Treaty puts all claims on ice, so to speak, so that all parties, whether claimant states or not, are able to maintain their position regarding those claims and therefore avoid open conflict. Thus, the Antarctic Treaty system has become an excellent example of international cooperation.

This could all now be changed with the signing and ratification of the minerals convention. I will not go into any further details now as I covered them earlier in an adjournment debate, but I point out that the Antarctic has already suffered considerable devastation from human intervention. Oil spills have already had a great effect on the ecology, the wildlife and the very sensitive environment of the area. Much of the wildlife in the area has already been overexploited and will have an effect on the ecological systems right around the globe.

The Treaty is intended to protect the environment, not to destroy it. It seems to me that in the lack of a provision for unlimited liability there is a great danger of nations destroying the environment and not even having the opportunity or being forced, under the Treaty, to clean up the mess. Even in the face of some provision for limited liability, one might ask: to whom could liability be directed for the destruction of the unique environment? That is one of the fears of conservation organisations around Australia and, indeed, around the world.

There is an obligation under the Convention to clean up the damaging effects of mining but there are still no specific details for the rehabilitation of the environment. Yet we could ask: how can such a susceptible and fragile environment ever be returned to its original state? We only have to look at mining in Australia to see how an even sturdier environment has been affected. It is true that the nature and extent of the mineral deposits in the Antarctic are not yet known but surely for once, given the importance of the Antarctic to the health of the entire world's climate and to its ecosystems, we could refrain from preventing any exploitation of an area upon which the future of all of us depends.

The Government has been very disappointing in not taking a leading role in this area. It has not given some commitment to its supposed stand on conservation matters by renegotiating the Convention. It has not taken an international lead by refusing to open the way for any kind of exploitation of the Antarctic and pointing out the sorts of things that we have heard today from the Democrat speakers and from Senator Vallentine-that is, that it is a region worthy of preservation, not only for its own sake, its beauty, its unique wildlife and its unique ecosystems but also because we do not know what sorts of effects damaging this environment will have on the world. We can be sure, however, that the effects will not be good.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Earlier this morning Senator Jones moved two motions on behalf of Senator Cooney to refer two matters to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. It was intended that two statements relating to the proposed references be incorporated in Hansard. I now seek leave to incorporate the statements in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statements read as follows-
DEBT RECOVERY UNDER THE SOCIAL SECURITY ACT AND THE VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS ACT

In order to give some guidance to persons and organisations who may be considering making a submission to the Committee on this matter, I would like to make some brief comments on the proposed reference.

Both the Social Security Act and the Veterans' Entitlements Act contain various provisions relating to the recovery of money from recipients of benefits under these Acts. These provisions principally deal with the recovery of overpayments, which are deemed to be debts due to the Commonwealth. For example, section 246 of the Social Security Act deals with recovery of overpayments by reason of false statement or representation, or because of failure or omission to comply with any provision of the Act.

Recovery under section 246 is by way of deduction from any future benefits. The section also provides for the payment of an additional sum by way of penalty. The Committee is interested in examining the operation of the section, particularly its impact on persons whose benefits are reduced in accordance with the section.

Section 162 of the Social Security Act allows the Department of Social Security to garnishee money that is due or payable to a person indebted to the Commonwealth. It covers situations where, for example, that person has money in a bank account, is entitled to wages from an employer or is entitled to a lump sum payment under a contract or, more likely, a damages settlement.
Subsection 162 (7) provides that if there is any precondition to the payment of the money, then for the purposes of the garnishee process the precondition is deemed to have been fulfilled.

This covers situations where, for example, the signature of the person is required before the money can be released. The provision could also conceivably operate to prejudice someone who has a contract with the person for goods and/or services. For example, the performance of work by the person could be said to be the precondition to the payment of his or her wages. Theoretically, the Department could deem that this precondition has been met and garnishee the person's wages without any work being performed. Similarly, the provision of goods by the person under a contract could be deemed to have been fulfilled and the contract price then garnisheed by the Commonwealth.
Section 205a of the Veterans' Entitlements Act operates in a similar way.
Both provisions carry significant sanctions if a person or organisation fails to comply with a garnishee order.
The committee is concerned that the sections may operate otherwise than as intended, to the detriment of third parties, and intends to look into and report on the operation of the sections.

Section 164 of the Social Security Act and section 128 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act give the Secretaries of the relevant Departments extensive information gathering powers in relation to persons indebted to the Commonwealth. In the course of the committee's recent inquiry into the proposed national ID system and the tax file number, these provisions were the subject of some criticism. It was suggested to the Committee that the provisions were unduly intrusive on the privacy of the persons concerned.

Section 164 has subsequently been amended in such a way as to alleviate some of the concerns communicated to the Committee at that time. Nevertheless, the Committee intends to examine the operation of the provisions in more detail than was possible in the course of the previous reference and assess whether these concerns are justified.

Section 251 of the Social Security Act gives the Secretary of the Department of Social Security the power to write-off or waive debts owing to the Commonwealth. Recent amendments to the Social Security Act have given the Minister for Social Security the power to issue directions on how the Secretary is to exercise his or her power. The Committee is concerned about the type of directions which could be issued by the Minister. Particularly, the Committee is concerned that the Secretary's discretion could be restricted by such directions to the extent that there was no longer any real discretion with the Secretary. Accordingly, the Committee believes that this matter warrants further examination.

Finally, I note recent media interest in relation to a proposed code of practice governing, among other things, the actions of banks in relation to the accounts of social welfare beneficiaries. The initial focus of concern was a proposal that banks be entitled to deduct up to 14% of a social security benefit paid into a customer's account if the bank believed that the customer owed it money. The banks and the Department have subsequently agreed on 10% as a more appropriate figure.

The Committee's concern in this matter is two-fold. First, there is the question of whether, in the light of the fact that section 249 of the Social Security Act declares that pensions, benefits and allowances are `absolutely inalienable', such a deduction is possible as a matter of law. Second, there is the fact that there is no requirement for the bank to actually prove the debt to the satisfaction of, say, a court. The recovery action relies solely on the banks' belief that the person is indebted to them.
The Committee intends to seek submissions from all interested parties and to report to the Senate by the last sitting day of 1989.
SHIELD OF THE CROWN

The Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation, which recently tabled its report in this place, recommended that the matter of `the shield of the Crown' be referred to a parliamentary committee for further examination. It became clear to that Committee, in the course of its enquiry, that the doctrine of the shield of the Crown was now a matter of some importance, given the growth in the number and activities of public corporations.

Whilst the Parliament has recently enacted legislation to establish corporate structures for a range of government business enterprises, there has been no uniform legislative approach to the shield of the Crown doctrine. In any event, there exist many statutory authorities whose ability to invoke the doctrine needs to be assessed on a case by case basis. In the State domain there are a number of statutory trading enterprises which have invoked the doctrine in recent times. It is therefore desirable to attempt to identify a common approach to this vexed question. This is what the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee will be doing under these terms of reference.

The Committee will shortly be calling for submissions. In doing this, it expects to have the benefit of a range of informed views when it comes to deal with the matters raised by the terms of reference.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the following matter be referred to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters for inquiry and report: The method and practice of the first A.C.T. election.
(2) That the Committee review the electoral system and the election process with a view to recommending changes which might improve the process and expedite the count.

(3) That the Committee particularly examine whether the deposit required to be paid by candidates is adequate and whether the cut-off level for unsuccessful candidates is set at the most appropriate level.

The Australian Capital Territory has recently completed its first election. Perhaps `completed' is a slight overstatement, but it certainly has had an election under the legislation that this Parliament passed late last year. I said that might be somewhat of an overstatement because it is now some eight weeks since the poll took place and yet the ultimate result has not been declared. It is clear that there have been problems in relation to the election process. It is not as clear where those problems lie and what is the best solution to improve the electoral process and perhaps the electoral system for the future.

I think it is fair to say that this first election, like all first elections, should not necessarily be treated as a norm for the future. A large number of individuals and parties stood and, no doubt, an element of novelty was involved in the first election for self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. The matter was further complicated by the fact that, in many ways, the election process clearly became a referendum on the subject of self-government itself and that referendum type approach to the election distorted the ultimate outcome. That is a reasonable political position to be taken by candidates who oppose the self-government process for the ACT, but it certainly has had the effect of distorting the result as a number of no self-government candidates have been elected to a government which is in existence. They are now in the interesting position where, despite their pledge to bring self-government to an end, they are about to take their seats in the governing body. So the extent to which these somewhat extraneous factors have complicated the first poll in the ACT is unclear, but it is clear that, not having had a result after eight weeks and with the degree of public concern about the whole electoral process, this Parliament should address the concerns that have been expressed within the ACT since the election.

It seems to us on this side of the chamber that the most appropriate vehicle for examining these questions is the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Electoral Matters. The ACT self-government has been formed out of Federal legislation, and the Federal Parliament is the only body with the capacity to change the ACT electoral system. The Joint Committee of this Parliament has now had experience in dealing with these matters. It has built up a certain expertise and it certainly has an interest in matters of this nature. There are the alternatives of setting up yet another select committee or attempting to send the question off to some outside body. They seem to us to be unnecessary whilst we have a body within our establishment specifically designated for such purposes.

As I said last night, that Committee has other work on its plate, which is not unusual in this parliamentary process. In fact, it still has three current references which were given to it in 1988. But I am sure that it will expedite consideration of this matter with the haste that it deserves. Of course, putting that in context, a four-year term of parliament was set up for the ACT. It is, therefore, unlikely that there will be another election for a number of years. So there is some time to address quietly and sensibly the result, the practices and the processes of this election and, as I have set out in this motion, to look at ways of improving the practices and processes for the future.

Much of the debate has addressed the unique electoral system for the ACT that this Parliament settled upon late last year-the so-called modified d'Hondt system. For many of those who have been opposed to self-government, the modified d'Hondt system has been a handy vehicle to blame for the delays and complications that have occurred. We all have different views on whether that is a valid criticism. I do not wish to limit this Committee in any way from considering the application of this modified d'Hondt system in practice; I think it should do so. Therefore, I hope that Senator Jenkins did not get the impression last night that, in some way, we were trying to exclude that. This is the unique system that has been settled upon for the ACT; it exists nowhere else in the world. Its basic format is common within Europe but there are variations and, as far as the variations concern a greater capacity to express preference in the latter stages of the count, it is unique. The Committee should look clearly at the one practical application of that system that we have-that is, the immediate past election-to see whether it should be further modified or varied.

I think the Australian Democrats would rather re-examine all other possible electoral system options which have been available since the ACT self-government debate started. Certainly that would be possible, but one wonders what it would achieve. It really amounts to a political debate which has been gone over many times over a number of years. I note that in the motion Senator Jenkins has on the Notice Paper she again wants consideration given to the possibility of implementing a Senate-type proportional representation system for the ACT. Consideration can be given to that, as it has been given over a number of years, but I fear that the same political obstacles will be encountered that have been encountered in the past. No doubt the Government would like to look again at the possibility of single member electorates because it is fair to say that, at the moment, there is some considerable political advantage in that system operating in the ACT.

I know that various calculations have been made since the election but my information is that, on that system, the Australian Labor Party would have won every seat in the ACT. Surely that would not have been a fair reflection of the vote which was cast at the last election? Apart from the fact that it would not reflect the vote of the Opposition parties here, it would in no way reflect the very significant vote that was given to the Residents Rally and other community groups within the ACT. That is the reason why we have objected to the suitability of a single member electorate system for the Australian Capital Territory. It simply does not seem to fit the unique city-state environment for which we have had to form an electoral system.

Of course, the Senate system is possible but I fear that the result would be even less stability than we are finding at present, in that the chances are that a greater number of individuals or small parties would have been elected. We have accepted all along that, in some ways, the system for the ACT is a compromise between democracy and stability. I think we have the democracy and a system designed to provide greater stability than the Senate proportional representation system. So far we do not have stability for the ACT and it will be a challenge to those who have been recently elected to offer that stability in difficult circumstances. I assure those elected that there will be nothing worse for the Australian Capital Territory at the moment than to force upon it another election in the current environment. I hope that they will be big enough to provide that stability and the good government that the Australian Capital Territory needs.

For those reasons I doubt the value in again going back and analysing the various alternatives of single member electorates or a Senate-type proportional representation. The same political hurdles will be met that were met before, which have to be answered in the only way possible and that is by political compromise. Political compromise resulted in the system that we have today. Nobody says that it is perfect and I am sure that it can be improved. I hope that when the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matter looks at the application of the system it will make recommendations for improvement.

I do not want to speak at length, but there is one other interesting facet that I wish to mention.
