I found it fascinating that the d'Hondt system was blamed for the fact that it took six weeks to count the first votes and check their validity. It seems to me that that exact process would have had to take place if there were a Senate-type proportional representation system and that not one hour would have been saved. In no way can I see how that time can be blamed on the d'Hondt system. It may be blamed on the physical difficulty of dealing with massive ballot papers, or I suspect that the process could have been helped by a little more planning in the Electoral Office. However, I await the parliamentary Committee's view on that.

I am not interested in apportioning blame. I am interested in improvements within the system to expedite the count in future and to improve the voting process at the next election. In other words, I am not so interested in looking to the past but rather to the future. Therefore, I have expressed the Opposition's motion in broad terms. I have moved that the Committee should review the electoral system and the electoral process, with a view to recommending changes which might improve the process and expedite the count.

I specifically mention two questions-not in an attempt to limit that consideration, but rather because I think they are specific matters that should be addressed. The first is the level of deposit that is imposed on prospective candidates. The deposit level is designed, in part at least, to dissuade mischievous candidates from standing and unnecessarily complicating the procedure. I would hate to see a deposit level dissuading a genuine candidate from standing because that would conflict with the democratic objective that I would seek. Nevertheless, it is designed with the purpose of ensuring that candidates are at least serious in the process. Democracy is a serious concept and in some ways a fragile one, as we see throughout the world, and should be respected. I have asked that the Committee look to see whether the deposit level should be varied for future elections. I think at present it is only $100 for the ACT which in terms of the damage that can be done to the process by candidates who are not genuine is very low.

The second question that I ask in the motion that the Committee specifically consider is the cut-off level in the d'Hondt system under which candidates cannot be successful but as to which their next preference can be distributed. That figure was determined more by a convenient formula rather than by anything else. It varies throughout Europe. In some places it is a stated percentage figure rather than a formula. There has been some criticism in the ACT that perhaps it was set too high. I think that an objective, bipartisan parliamentary committee should examine specifically that question and advise the Parliament whether it believes the formula that has been adopted sets the percentage at the most appropriate level.

With regard to Senator Jenkins's motion, I have no concerns with the parliamentary Committee looking at the previous advice given by the Australian Electoral Commission to the Government on the d'Hondt system and the difficulties that it saw in the system. I regret that that advice was not before the Parliament at the time we debated the Bills, though I wonder whether it would have changed much. What was finally decided was a political compromise and in many ways what seemed to be the only political compromise open. Nevertheless, all information is useful in debate. It would have been useful to pursue the Electoral Commission on its assertions to see whether in the opinion of the Parliament they were well founded. Therefore, I am happy for the Committee to examine those matters and I do not think that our motion restricts the Committee from so doing.

In the application of the existing system the Committee will have to look in some detail at the modified d'Hondt system. If it does so now with the hindsight of experience and forms the view that it is unworkable, as some have asserted, no doubt it will say so. If it comes back with a report of that nature to the Parliament, the Parliament will have to address it. I shall be surprised if it does so because, apart from one small variation which it seems will take only a few days in the count, it is a well-tried system within Europe, although it is somewhat new to Australia.

Some day, when I have nothing better to do, I would like to go out into the community and ask all those who say that they do not understand how the d'Hondt system works to explain to me how the Senate proportional representation system works. I shall be surprised if I get more than 5 per cent of the community who can explain that to me. That emphasises in my mind that it is the d'Hondt system that has attracted the blame, but I think that the problems may lie elsewhere. However that is for the Committee to find. I move this motion in a constructive way and in the hope that in due course it will provide for the Parliament recommendations that will improve the electoral system and process in the Australian Capital Territory, which can only benefit the total Australian Capital Territory community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has little difficulty in supporting either this motion or part of Senator Jenkins's motion. But I should place on record the fact that last week I was sent a draft reference by Minister West, who is responsible for electoral matters, to refer the very things that Senator Hill and Senator Jenkins have been considering to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. I informed him yesterday that there were two motions before the Senate and that is the only reason he has not proceeded as a Minister to refer these matters to that Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall not go through the sorry litany of events that have surrounded self-government and the different electoral systems which have been considered for the ACT other than to say that the choice of the d'Hondt system and then a modified d'Hondt system was the fourth preferred choice of this Government. Quite clearly, we preferred 17 single member electorates, or as a second choice nine single member electorates and eight elected by proportional representation a la the Senate system. Our third choice was a pure d'Hondt system, and finally our fourth choice forced upon us was a modified d'Hondt system.

I do not agree with the criticism of the Australian Electoral Commission as to the time it has taken to do this count. It takes eight weeks to do a New South Wales Senate count with 45 candidates. Here we had 117 candidates, with as many below the line votes as one has in a New South Wales Senate election. It takes one or two weeks to strike a quota. There is no point in putting inexperienced staff on these matters or in having existing staff working weekends and over Easter. In that process they will simply make mistakes and one will have to start all over again. The Electoral Commission has tried as hard as it can, within resources but also within the possibilities of doing this count, to have it completed.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister for Finance. Now that Australia's foreign debt is exceeded only by those of Brazil and Mexico, do the Minister and the Treasurer, whom he represents, hold to the story that Australia's budgetary and financial position is `steady on course'? At what stage will an effort be made to take remedial action to reverse this disastrous position?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what definition Senator Archer is using when he quotes foreign debt, but a very common and misleading way of presenting foreign debt is to quote only the gross debt. The net foreign debt in Australia is of the order of $95 billion and as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) is somewhat lower than it was 12 months or so back. I have made it very clear publicly on many occasions over the last few years that I see that as a real problem, but measures are being taken to address it. They have been taken over a number of years. For a start, we are now in our third successive year of declining real government outlays and the fourth year of declining real government outlays is approaching. That has never happened before in Australia. We brought in a significant Budget surplus last year, there will be a Budget surplus this year approaching 2 per cent of gross domestic product, and there will be a Budget surplus of similar size next year. No previous Australian government produced a Budget surplus at all. I suspect that Senator Stone, in his many years in the Treasury, would never have even contemplated the prospect of any government producing a Budget surplus. So at Federal Government level a great deal has been done about those matters which are directly under the control of the Federal Government.
—By huge tax rises.

—There has been a lower level of expenditure as a proportion of GDP this year than in any year of the Fraser-Howard regime. We heard a lot from Mr Fraser and Mr Howard about restraining Government expenditure; all we ever got, though, was the rhetoric. We never got any reality, as demonstrated by the previous Government's record. In every Budget that John Howard brought down Government expenditure as a proportion of GDP was higher than it is this year or will be next year.
—We never had an overseas debt like you lot have.

—We have one of the real lightweights of the back bench now making her contribution to misinformation and ignorance on this subject. The Federal Government has done a great deal. I believe that the State governments have done less than they ought to have done. One of the few things under the control of the Federal Government which impinge on this is the Commonwealth Budget outcome and, to a lesser extent, the public sector borrowing requirement. Matters which are not directly under the control of the Federal Government have also been addressed in a variety of ways, not the least of which is the present round of award restructuring and productivity increases.

ANSWER.PARA: I wish briefly to make two other comments. The first is that the current level of the current account deficit is contributed to very significantly by the investment boom, again the largest level of investment as a proportion of GDP that has ever been recorded. In the short term that has aggravated the current account problem. The final point is that there is one way of overcoming the current account problem-the New Zealand way. The New Zealand current account is expected to move into surplus in the first quarter of 1989. That is being done, however, by pushing up unemployment a full six percentage points and not counting the extra per cent or so that New Zealand exports to Australia annually. That is one way of overcoming it. It is not the preferred way of this Government and, indeed, it should not be the preferred option for any government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Australian Government's view of the latest developments in the Central American peace process, particularly in the light of recent raids in El Salvador which resulted in the arrest and detention of an Australian resident, Ms Eve Scarfe?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government very much welcomes the new atmosphere of cooperation and reconciliation which has become evident in recent weeks among the major players in the Central American conflict, with one area of exception only, which I will come to in a moment. At their summit on 13 and 14 February, the Presidents of the five Central American countries-that is, Nicaragua, El Salvador, Costa Rica, Honduras and Guatemala-agreed on a comprehensive program for peace in the region. On 24 March the Bush Administration undertook to work with the democratically elected Central American leaders and expressed support for a non-military solution to the crisis in Central America. On 5 April in a speech to the Cuban National Assembly, we had Mr Gorbachev calling for an end to foreign interference in the affairs of sovereign states.

ANSWER.PARA: Certainly, the Australian Government welcomes those expressions of political goodwill by the five Central American Presidents and by the Unites States of America and the Soviet Union to support a negotiated non-military settlement of the conflict in the region. We consider that only a genuine commitment to reform in the political, social and economic instabilities of this troubled region will resolve the continuing tension and conflict which exists there.

We call, as we have in the past, on all governments who share the objective of peace, stability and democracy in Central America to demonstrate their support for the peace process. It is in this context and against that background of some very positive developments that we view with concern the increase in violence in El Salvador following the elections on 20 March, which violence has included, among other things, the assassination of that country's Attorney-General. It, in turn, resulted in raids on church and human rights groups in San Salvador on 19 April in which a British citizen resident in Australia, Ms Eve Scarfe, was arrested and detained overnight by El Salvadoran authorities. Ms Scarfe was released unharmed on 20 April and is now understood to be in Costa Rica. The Australian Embassy in Mexico City has been asked to investigate the circumstances of these arrests, particularly the case of Ms Scarfe, and to make appropriate representations to the El Salvadoran authorities.

We note President-elect Cristiani's stated intention to honour the peace accords of the five Central American Presidents to open the political process to all parties and to pursue negotiations with the FMLN. We believe that a process of negotiation with respect to human rights of all Salvadorans is a necessary first step towards national reconciliation. We have made a number of representations on human rights cases to the El Salvadoran authorities and will certainly continue to raise our concerns about issues as that is appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to the amazement expressed in the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) report on Rothwells Ltd about the $400m price tag put on the proposed petrochemical plant in Western Australia at the time the State Government, under Mr Peter Dowding, decided to buy into it and bail out Mr Laurie Connell. I ask the Minister: Is it not a fact that the investment of $175m by Western Australian taxpayers bought a share in a project whose most valuable asset, as the NCSC notes, was the State Government's own approval to proceed with the project? Given the Commonwealth's outrage and threats of fund cutting retaliation against other State governments and in particular its reaction to the New South Wales proposals to raise taxes to carry out essential public works to rescue the environment, what is the Government's attitude to the extraordinary dealings of the Western Australian Government over the petrochemical plant? Will the Government take any action against the Dowding Government, or will it continue its double standard of attacking non-Labor governments and letting the likes of Mr Dowding and Mr Cain get away with financial murder?
—Every other crime in the book, but not murder yet.

—Senator Stone has indulged us with great charity by way of interjection. I am not familiar with the NCSC report in relation to Rothwells. I really cannot answer any part of that question, but I will endeavour to obtain an answer about the matter. Senator Walsh has already indicated in answer to an earlier question today that State governments, for a variety of reasons, should bear a greater burden of the nation's international debt problem by adjustments in Commonwealth outlays for the States, and I agree with that. So far as I am concerned, that should be approached with equity for all States.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his partial reply and ask him to provide the rest of the reply as soon as possible. In light of the Minister's comment in his answer that the State governments should bear a greater share of the burden of adjustment to our international debt, I ask the Minister: Is a payment of $175m worth of taxpayers' money for a non-asset in any sense a contribution towards improving our international debt or our competitive position, or is that in fact just an additional burden on the Australian community which is likely to make that problem worse?
—I have already said that I do not know sufficient about that matter. I will find out about it.

—Has the Minister for Resources seen an article in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald headed `How can we stop the land blowing away?' in which Peter Fray details the serious dimensions of the problem of soil degradation? Does Mr Fray point out that `failure to deal with it', that is, land degradation, `threatens the very backbone of the nation's economy for generations to come'? Can the Minister tell the Senate how the Government intends to ensure that this threat to our economy can be dealt with?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first question is yes, I have seen the article. The answer to the second question, whether Mr Fray points out that failure to deal with soil degradation will threaten the very backbone of the nation's economy, is yes. I have seen that quote and the other quotes from the article. In answer to the question about what the Government's program is, I advise the Senate that last Thursday week I took part in a national television hook-up with all the State Ministers for agriculture to launch the national soil conservation program. That is a program which will enable the Commonwealth, in consort with the States, to put in $45m over the next three years to conduct a national strategy to preserve Australia's land, water and soils. The national conservation strategy is aimed at meeting four particular needs: supporting community land care support groups; helping public awareness, education and training; assisting research into the area; and supporting major programs which are demonstration programs to show that success can be achieved if we work cooperatively in this field.

ANSWER.PARA: I might say that the article that has been referred to by Senator Beahan is a very useful one. It is one of a number of articles which have begun to appear in Australian newspapers and periodicals over recent months. Just last weekend the Weekend Australian had a feature piece in its insert magazine. The West Australian some six weeks ago had a major feature piece on land degradation in Western Australia and the rising problem of salinity in that State. The Sydney Morning Herald, over several days, had a series of articles on land degradation. Peter Fray, along with the other journalists who have been associated with giving long, detailed and thoughtful consideration to this problem, are to be commended because they are doing Australia a service. This is not just something for country Australians. This is something for urban Australians to understand so that they may support the efforts that are being made by the joint governments of this country to resolve the matter.

I have talked in this chamber-I do not propose to go over it again-about the dimensions of this problem. It is a serious problem for Australia. It is fundamentally our most important environmental issue. The prime focus of the campaign we launched last Thursday week is to encourage land-holders to modify or change their attitudes about the management of the land in their care so that it is farmed within its capability and so that the husbandry and farming practices engaged in are ones which enable the land to be passed on to successive generations of Australians as land able to sustain our agricultural output while preserving its en- vironmental position as well.

I conclude my answer by saying that I believe we now have the strategy in place. We now have the key part of the funding in place. We now have the focus on changing attitudes among those who care for the land operating reasonably effectively. As we proceed down that track, much more will be achieved in real outcomes so that we can expect that the problem of land degradation, which is the most serious problem, will come under control.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It is made in the context of Vice-President Quayle's recent assertion that United States agricultural export subsidies are not affecting Australia's economy and Mr Quayle's warning that protection was still immensely appealing to members of the US Congress. What specific new steps is the Government intending to take in its representations to the US Administration, and particularly to Congress, to ensure that Australia's interests are not harmed in the forthcoming US farm Bill? In addition, will these steps consist of an all-party parliamentary delegation to the US to convey to leading congressmen, particularly those from the urban electorates who are paying the bill in the US, Australia's concern at export subsidies and the importance of a free market approach in the ongoing discussions and eventual vote on that farm Bill?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's and indeed the country's concern about the impact of the export enhancement program (EEP) on Australian agriculture, and wheat farmers in particular, although not acknowledged by Vice-President Quayle when he was here, is something of obvious impact in Australia. It is something we are all concerned about and we are very concerned to continue to get that message across in a variety of ways.

ANSWER.PARA: As we all know, a primary objective of the EEP was to enable the US to win back market share from subsidised agricultural exporters. While this has happened in some markets at the expense of the European Community (EC), overall the cost has fallen on unsubsidised exporters such as Australia and other members of the Cairns Group. The statistics bear repeating: Australia's share of the world wheat and flour market has declined from 19 1/2 per cent in 1985-86 to an estimated 11.3 per cent in the current financial year. Meanwhile the US share of the market has increased from 28.7 per cent in 1985-86 to an estimated 42.9 per cent in 1988-89 while at the same time the European Community, against which the EEP has allegedly been targeted, will have increased its share from 17.4 per cent to an estimated 20 per cent or very near to it.

Further damage has occurred through the price depressing effect of the EEP on world markets, which has in turn further reduced grower returns. We are monitoring the Budget debate in the US on the future of the EEP. We certainly welcome ongoing US Department of Agriculture and General Accounting Office (GAO) reviews of the program's operation. We are making an input into the GAO review process through a quite substantial document which is presently in process of preparation, spelling out with as much precision as we possibly can the way in which the EEP has operated to Australia's disadvantage and without advancing, we would argue, the cause that it was originally put in place for.

A number of further representations will be made at different levels within the US Administration on this subject in the period ahead and particularly in the context of the renewal of the farm legislation which is proposed over the next year or so. It may well be that another delegation by an all-party parliamentary committee of the kind that Senator Macklin, I know, has been previously involved in would be a useful contribution to that process, particularly in sensitising a number of senators and congressmen who tend, as do many people in the United States, not to look beyond the boundaries of that country, or in their cases their own constituencies, in determining the economic impact of measures of this kind. It may be that an effectively led, managed and briefed delegation of this kind could make some impact again in sensitising the US Congress and Administration to our concerns. I will certainly pass on that proposal to the Prime Minister. We will discuss it, no doubt, in the period ahead as one of a number of statagems that we need to put in place to advance the cause.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications been drawn to reports in various media of an incident-for example, an article in the Age of 1 May, headed `Jet liners within minutes of mid-air crash'? Was the circumstance one which could fairly be described as a near miss? Is the Minister aware that, in response to a question from me during the hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, a senior officer of the Civil Aviation Authority advised the Committee that he believed that if no action had been taken the aircraft would have missed each other by 25 miles, but as a result of the actions of Sydney air traffic control, they in fact finished 10 miles apart? Is this a fair description of the situation?

—I am advised that the Civil Aviation Authority has investigated claims that an air safety incident was alleged to have occurred over south-western New South Wales shortly before 5 a.m. on Saturday, 29 April, involving an Air New Zealand B767 en route from Perth to Auckland and a Qantas 747 en route from Singapore to Melbourne. The aircraft were cruising at the same altitude of 37,000 feet and their projected flight paths crossed approximately 30 nautical miles north of Wagga. As the Air New Zealand aircraft was not in normal communication with Sydney air traffic control, the Qantas aircraft was radar vectored by Sydney air traffic control away from the flight path of the Air New Zealand aircraft. There was no breakdown in separation and no threat to the safety of the aircraft, as the altitude data displayed on the radar screen alerted the controller to the potential conflict. The occurrence is subject to scrutiny by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation and a report can be expected within the next couple of weeks. That might give us an opportunity to explore further the latter parts of the honourable senator's question.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications will know that the Australian public has been alerted to the problems facing Qantas Airways Ltd. I refer, in particular, to the shortage of skilled maintenance staff which, over a period of 18 months, has required Qantas to cut some flights and place contracts for servicing 747 and 767 aircraft with six overseas airlines. First, can the Minister advise the Senate whether the standards of those overseas airlines embody the same stringent maintenance criteria as do those of Qantas? I note that one of those airlines has experienced both loss of life and other flight mishaps in recent times. Secondly, are inadequate and uncompetitive salary levels in Qantas a major cause of the falling number of maintenance staff? Finally, to ensure that safety is maintained, has the Government taken, or will it take, steps to financially assist Qantas to attract additional engineers or to provide training that will produce qualified engineers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Qantas is acutely conscious of its fine safety record and reputation. I am sure that there is no question of its entering into overseas maintenance contracts in circumstances other than those that would continue to absolutely guarantee that reputation. When things happen, as they sometimes do, Qantas's reaction, unlike that of some other airlines, is not to sack its public relations staff but to go to the root cause of the problem and resolve it. The fleet that is being maintained by Qantas is one of the most modern of any airline in the world and its reputation, as we know from recent academy award winning movies, among other things, is second to none in the world. I will see whether Qantas or the Department wants to answer that part of the question about the overseas maintenance arrangements in any more detail, but I am totally confident in Qantas's capacity to get that right.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the underlying problem which has produced the situation to which Senator Panizza refers, the Government recognises, as it has to, that the aviation industry is currently experiencing shortages of skilled labour in the maintenance and engineering sectors. In consultation with other parties, we are progressing award restructuring packages, training and skill enhancement strategies and overseas recruitment. Further overseas recruitment will take place this year which will assist in relieving the immediate shortage. I know that is taking place with the very active cooperation of Senator Robert Ray and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs so far as all levels of that recruitment are concerned. In addition, Qantas is expanding its maintenance facilities and increasing its intake of apprentices. Again, I think it is doing everything conceivably possible to relieve that shortage. Qantas is still expanding its services, but at a reduced rate. This is a temporary measure during the off-peak period which will relieve the pressure on maintenance staff and maintain Qantas's high standards. The introduction of the 747-400s, which is presently under way, will also relieve the situation by providing greater capacity and flexibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Government received any new indications that support for its micro-economic reforms is broadening? How is that support being obtained and from where is it coming?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any government that is serious about pursuing micro-economic reform has two major problems. The first is the one of simple ignorance, that is, failure by a lot of people to understand what is going on and what the proposed changes are. The second is vested interest. We have an example right now of both of those problems with the Government's legislation to deregulate wheat marketing. There is a great deal of ignorance. There is misunderstanding about the effects that the Government's proposals would have and there is a lot of vested interest, principally by the National Party of Australia. But one of the superficially encouraging things about Australian politics is that both the major parties-I use that term deliberately-have become more receptive to micro-economic reform in recent years than either of them was before. However, a third party has a vested interest in perpetuating the status quo and, indeed, in perpetuating ignorance. Recently, we saw the Leader of the Opposition, for reasons of cosmetic unity, having his wishes on the Victorian Senate ticket accepted by the National Party. However, there are disturbing indications that there was a secret trade-off in that-that is, the Opposition's ostensible commitment to micro-economic reform in respect of wheat marketing will be emasculated by a string of amendments that the National Party will move in the Senate.

ANSWER.PARA: National Party senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —They are admitting to it. They are confirming my diagnosis. For reasons of cosmetic unity on an agreed Senate ticket in Victoria, John Howard has secretly sold out his own Party. He has secretly sold out his beliefs and caved in to the Neanderthal views of the National Party, just as the Liberal Party has always done. I welcome the confirmation from various members of the National Party opposite of my diagnosis; I welcome their confirmation on this specific point.

ANSWER.PARA: In particular, it has been reported in the press-I do not know whether it is accurate-that the National Party will move an amendment to remove from the Government's legislation the overriding of State government marketing regulations. If that is correct, the Opposition's amendment will emasculate the deregulatory aspects of the Bill. The Opposition has neither confirmed nor denied that. Perhaps its members do not know yet. Perhaps the National Party has not quite succeeded in mugging John Howard properly. This particular example is a very good demonstration of the difficulties in having micro-economic reform accepted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts and Territories to Mr Robert Yeomans's assessment of Christmas Island mining proposals, which recommended that the Government negotiate with Elders Resources Ltd. Did Mr Yeomans's assessment acknowledge that a consortium of substance, the Booth consortium, was offering the same net payment and more in royalties than Elders Resources? Is the Minister aware that, at current market prices, the Booth proposal could result in the Government's obtaining approximately 30 per cent more in royalties than for Elders' best case and at least 200 per cent more than in Elders' worst case? Does the Minister stand by his answer to my question on notice that Mr Yeomans recommended that proposal which would best maximise returns to the Commonwealth through both net payment and royalties, and acted in accord with the Attorney-General's Department's advice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly I stand by that answer. Mr Yeomans was, of course, making an independent assessment. It was not an assessment that was directed by the Government and I thought at the time and still believe that that was the correct procedure. I would not have thought that there would be any real question as to procedure. I think what the senator is questioning, then, is the result of the procedure. It would seem to me that, if the Government agrees that an independent assessor ought to be appointed to perform a task such as the one that Mr Yeomans performed on Christmas Island, it is the responsibility of the Government to get out of the way and allow the assessor to get on with his or her job. In the case of Christmas Island, I am confident that Mr Yeomans performed his task competently, and the Government has seen no reason to regret his recommendation or its acceptance of it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the Minister to reports of recent arrivals of illegal immigrants on the north-west coast of Western Australia. Is the Minister aware of widespread community concern at these developments, particularly in my home State of Western Australia, and can he inform the Senate what his Department is doing about these illegal immigrants?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been two recent landings on the north-west coast of Western Australia. A group of 14 landed on 1 September 1988 and a second group of 11 arrived on 25 April 1989. The first group consisted of Bangladeshis and Indians, and a Lebanese. Several of them had previously applied unsuccessfully to migrate to Australia. They were carrying documents indicating the contact point for legal aid officers in Australia. All but one of the first group were found to be ineligible to migrate to Australia under the refugee or special humanitarian program and were deported from Australia on 7 February. The cost to the taxpayer for detention, processing and deportation of these 14 individuals was in excess of $200,000.

ANSWER.PARA: The second group, consisting of 11 Bangladeshis, included two of the original 14 previously deported. The second group is being detained and questioned in the Broome prison, and deportation is anticipated as soon as travel documents are issued by the Bangladeshi authorities. There are many similarities between the two groups, including the point of embarkation being the Indonesian island of Kupang. My Department is of the view that these arrivals are part of an organised scam to bring illegal migrants to Australia. Australia has been fortunate in many ways not to have experienced the same level of illegal immigration as countries such as Canada and West Germany. Unfortunately, a variety of vested interests in the legal fraternity do seek, under the existing Commonwealth Migration Act, to find loopholes so that such people can stay. I am always a little surprised when I receive letters from them asking me to show my compassion in certain cases. I believe, and the Government believes, that that sort of compassion should be reserved for those who apply legally to come to this country, wait for months and months in a queue and, sometimes disappointingly, have to be refused because they do not qualify. That is where my compassion lies and I am sure that is where the compassion of all honourable senators lies; it is not for the queue jumpers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery to my right of a delegation from the Parliament of Papua New Guinea led by the Deputy Speaker, Mr Christopher Sambre. On behalf of all honourable senators, I extend to you a warm welcome and trust that your visit to Australia will be both informative and enjoyable.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Is the Minister aware of reports that, on present trends, because of the increase in the number of Australians dependent on the age pension, public outlays for this purpose will have to increase from 2.8 per cent of gross domestic product in 1985 to 4.5 per cent by the year 2025? As this trend will increase the pressure on people to provide for their own retirement income through savings plans, what proposals does the Government have to provide an incentive for people to save for their retirement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bjelke-Petersen raises an issue which is very much in the forefront of Government consideration. As she would know, the Government is in the process of preparing its policy on retirement incomes. As a precursor to that policy document, the whole issue of retirement incomes has been discussed and assessed by the Social Security Review, and an issues paper from that review was released on 24 October 1988. In its major conclusions, the review has suggested to the Government a number of issues that should be the cornerstone of any long-term retirement incomes policy. Equity and adequacy are two of those major cornerstone policies. A third one, of course, is certainty. The review has suggested that, in developing a policy, the Government needs to make major changes gradually in view of the long-term expectations, plans and commitments of older people. The Government has also been advised that further improvements in its retirement income arrangements will need to occur within the present dual system of age pension and occupational superannuation. Incentives to work, especially among the aged, and to save, must be maintained and improved. One of the other major conclusions of the review is that arrangements should be as simple as possible, consistent with the need for both equity and effectiveness.

ANSWER.PARA: The review suggested a number of major options in respect of direct payments. Amongst them was a suggestion that, in the longer term, a guaranteed minimum retirement income of 30 per cent of average weekly earnings from a combination of the age pension, occupation superannuation and investment income should be a target, and that an income tested retirement income supplement, restricted to pensioners with very little other income, should also be a target. Rent assistance was also discussed as well as living alone allowances, pensioner bonuses for the older aged, and so on.

The issues that that review raised quite constructively are very much part of the consideration of the Government and will be at the forefront of its consideration when it develops its retirement incomes policy, which the Australian people will receive quite soon.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware of the reports in the media that the Australian Bureau of Statistics production data for March indicates that industry competitiveness has collapsed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of some media comments on the ABS production figures for the month of March. I have been made aware of them partly by comments made by Senator Chaney, the Opposition spokesman on these issues. I must say that Senator Chaney and sections of the media have drawn very erroneous and at times cynical conclusions from the figures.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I used the word `cynical' because it is a word that rolls readily off Senator Chaney's tongue when he speaks about the Government, and I listen to him--
—Why don't you learn if you listen?

—I listen to him. I listen to what he says. I hope from time to time to get some wisdom from Senator Chaney. Let me tell Senator Puplick where I think Senator Chaney is quite wrong about these things. Let me say first that it is good to see that he is following the fortunes of industry so closely. However, he draws a strong and direct link between these production figures for the month of March and the long-term health of Australian industry. He has also over-glorified these figures. In so doing, not surprisingly as the Leader, he falls into the camp of his colleagues sitting behind him who show a complete lack of understanding in relation to the economy and industry.
—How is manufacturing production going?

—That is the same question which the honourable senator asked yesterday. Senator Chaney made a speech in this chamber which I saw on television. I thought he looked good. It was only when I listened to him that I realised how awful the speech was. He asked this rhetorical question, `One might ask what is happening to production under the politics of this Government.' I can tell the honourable senator that the answer to his question is this: Total manufacturing production in real terms has risen by an average of 3.6 per cent a year under this Government, to the highest level in recorded statistics. That is for the December quarter last year. Senator Chaney asked that question which sounds terrific, `What is happening to manufacturing production under this Government?'. That is a beautiful rhetorical question which is left floating around in the air with no answer. He came in here to get the answer.

ANSWER.PARA: By contrast, in the last year of Senator Chaney's coalition Government production fell by 14 per cent after a sluggish performance throughout the 1970s. It is the same old story. We saw it yesterday with Senator Puplick introducing the 1960s show again about science and technology in Australia. Senator Chaney, as Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, is now doing it because he is not prepared to face up to that comparison. He has asked rhetorical questions and I give him the answer now.

When alluding to these issues yesterday Senator Chaney should have taken a slightly closer look at the data and production statistics for March. The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show a trend in decline in production for 13 items out of 27 surveyed in March compared with February. If the honourable senator had looked at the figures available for the last few years he would have seen that those fluctuations are there month to month all the time. This was the decline referred to by the honourable senator and the massacre referred to in some sections of the media, which I do not want to name. I would regard it as derogatory to name them in this context.

What a pity that Senator Chaney, in his press release-trumped up with a full moon in Western Australia presumably-did not refer to the numerous caveats and qualifications made by the Statistician. What are they? The items surveyed in the figures Senator Chaney referred to cover 14 per cent of total manufacturing output in Australia. Senator Chaney draws enormous conclusions, and poses long rhetorical questions, from statistics relating to 14 per cent of manufacturing output in Australia. As the shadow Minister for industry for a long time now, Senator Chaney should know that these figures are highly volatile, the data is preliminary, the items are unweighted, the seasonal adjustment process has been distorted by the presence of Easter in March and, in yearly terms, the picture is reversed.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will have to turn the television off now. You have fixed your collar, now fix your elocution.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. The Minister is debating his answer. Also, in comparing statistics he has not told the Senate that 1982 was a drought year. When he tries to accuse Senator Chaney of unfairness in the use of statistics, he is a hypocrite in that he is guilty of the same offence.
—Order! There is no point of order and I ask Senator Teague to withdraw that comment.
—Is it unparliamentary to draw the Minister's attention to being unfair?
—Order! You called the Minister a hypocrite and I am asking you to withdraw that remark.
—He also called Senator Chaney a hypocrite.
—Order! I heard the honourable senator make the comment and I am asking him to withdraw it.
—I am very happy to withdraw the remark if the Minister also withdraws his accusation of hypocrisy against Senator Chaney.

—Mr President, before I was interrupted I was trying to make the point that it is unkind of Opposition senators to interject, not to attack what I am saying, but to suggest that I have a speech impediment. That is an unkind interjection to say that I mispronounced a word. Senator Teague, in seeking to make a point, said that I did not acknowledge that there was a drought in 1982. That was precisely the point. That was what afflicted this country in 1982 and the 29 years beforehand-intellectual drought in the government of the day; a total drought. That is why we have this problem today. There is nothing in these statistics which Senator Chaney has tried to make so much of to suggest that productivity or competitiveness has slumped in the month of March. There are production item figures which move around as demand fluctuates and firms change their production lines to match these fluctuations. These are not output figures for industry sectors but represent a very small sector of industry.

—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery to my left of a delegation from the Japan-Australia Parliamentarians League, led by Mr Zenko Suzuki. On behalf of all honourable senators, I extend to you a warm welcome to Australia, and Canberra in particular, and trust that you will enjoy your visit.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. I refer to the Government's changes in financial administration requirements and the setting up of corporate plans. Why has the Government stopped there and not insisted that there is a result statement with outcomes of what is to be achieved, with a linkage statement showing how those results meet program objectives and an explanation of the relationship between the level of resources and expected results? What time frame has the Government set for departments to provide adequate performance indicators which show the effective measures of how the outcome is to be measured, and efficiency quantifiers which show relationship of resources used to outputs?
—That is much too difficult a question for me to try to answer off the top of my head. I will get an answer for Senator Watson.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PULP AND PAPER MILLS: USE OF CHLORINE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. In light of the fact that there is enormous public concern about the use of chlorine in the bleaching of paper, is it true that Associated Pulp and Papers Mills has offered to begin manufacturing paper without chlorine bleaching if it can get a contract from the Federal Government, thus making it economically viable? Is the Government prepared to take a tiny but significant step to protect our environment by placing an order for unbleached paper? If so, when? Will the Government take steps to substitute recycled and unbleached paper for present stocks wherever possible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sanders was obviously absent from the chamber when Senator Coates asked me a very similar question a few weeks ago. I said at that stage that I would send the suggestion to Minister West for his consideration. I do not think the honourable senator, even in his wildest fantasy, would expect a reply of that dimension within a week or two. Certainly, the suggestion about going to non-bleached paper wherever possible has some merit. Economies of scale have to be established, and probably only governments initially can establish those. However, the suggestion has some appeal. I will pass the question and the editorial to Minister West, and hope that we will get a response within a reasonable time.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Can he indicate whether the latest labour force figures confirm continued growth in employment in Australia. At the same time, can he expand on the employment position in the various States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since we came into government in March 1983 a top, if not the top, priority of this Government has been the stimulation of employment, high employment growth. We have succeeded spectacularly in that objective. The number of people in employment has grown by more than 1.3 million in a six-year period or, in percentage terms, by a massive 21 per cent. The most recent figures-those for the period March 1988 to March 1989-show that that growth rate is being maintained. In that 12-month period, employment increased by 237,000, or around 3.2 per cent. Across the mainland States, employment growth generally in that 12-month period has been high, ranging from 0.5 per cent to above 6.5 per cent. Once one moves away from the mainland, of course, there is an exception. In the 12-month period Tasmania actually incurred an absolute fall in employment of almost 4 per cent. Of course, Tasmania has performed poorly in the whole six-year period relative to the mainland States. Aggregate employment growth in Tasmania has been just over 11 per cent-not much more than half the national average-over that period. That does not sit at all comfortably with the 1982 policy speech by the present Premier of Tasmania, when he said:

ANSWER.PARA: This election is all about jobs and security. Our first priority will be to restore economic management and to create jobs for Tasmania.

He certainly has not delivered on that promise. Tasmanians are being asked to vote again, but many of them have already voted with their feet. In the 12 months to May 1987-the period for which the most recent figures are available-there was a net migration out of Tasmania of 1,400 young people in the 20- to 24-year age group. Whereas Tasmania was once noted for exporting apples, it seems that, under the Gray Government, it is noted for exporting its future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Will the Minister advise the Senate why his Government is appealing to the High Court of Australia for the protection of the statute of limitations in the claim for compensation by HMAS Voyager survivor Bernard Verwagen, when in 1985 the Government admitted liability to all survivors and agreed to waive the statute of limitations in all applications for compensation? Is the Government aware that current service personnel are watching the Government's cynical treatment of the Voyager survivors and that the issue is yet another that is contributing to the lowering of morale in the Australian Defence Force?
—I will not advise the Senate about that because I know nothing about it. However, I will find out.

—I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to an article in the Australian Financial Review of 12 April, entitled `Australia ``light-years behind in space'' '. In that article the Institution of Engineers called on the Federal Government to start long term planning for a space industry and to establish an independent statutory space authority and national space projects. At a recent conference, the engineers were told that Australia would have to spend large amounts of money-between $370m and $500m by 1995-overseas on space-related activities to maintain our communications satellite systems. Will the Minister inform the Senate of the validity of the claims made in the article and what plans the Government has to encourage the development of an Australian space industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot comment on the validity or otherwise of those figures, but Australia's expenditure on space-related equipment over the next decade will be significant. It is not, in my view, an area in which Australia, bearing in mind the size of its population and the resources available to it, can be in the import-replacement business. We can be in import-replacement as to part, and I think that we can become very sophisticated users of space technology in areas such as remote sensing, which are very valuable to large sectors of the Australian economy.

ANSWER.PARA: In 1986 the Government announced a response to the report commissioned from the Academy of Technological Sciences, which became known as the Madigan report, relating to the possibilities for development of a space industry in Australia. Since then, we have had a small space program, intended to demonstrate the feasibility and benefits of the Madigan report proposals. In the second half of 1988 I asked the Australian Space Office to make a detailed study of the opportunities for an Australian space industry. Working under guidance from the Australian Space Board, and in consultation with industry and the research community, the Space Office is formulating a strategy for the development of Australian space industry activities. I hope to bring recommendations on this issue to the Government shortly.

The estimates of expenditure to which Senator Foreman referred, and on which I cannot comment in detail, are contained in the report entitled The Space Policy for Australia. That report was prepared at the request of the Minister for Science in 1985 or 1986. The more general claims made in the article quoted by Senator Foreman derive from a paper prepared by the national committee on space engineering of the Institution of Engineers. I am not privy to the contents of that paper, but I have seen press reports about it. As far as the Government is concerned, expenditure under the national space program totals $5.4m in 1988-89, with similar levels currently committed for future years, and, of course, some resources devoted to space-related research in other organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to his visit to the Antarctic Division in Hobart this morning. Did he compliment the Division on the running of its organisation, its proficiency and efficiency? Did he announce that it was his first visit to the Division and, in doing so, announce the appointment of Mr Rex Moncur as the new director?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to receive the question. I did compliment the Division on its performance-and rightly so. I did not, however, announce the appointment of Mr Moncur as the Director. As the honourable senator is probably aware, Mr Moncur is the Acting Director. Given that there has been a change of leadership in the Division, I expressed my confidence in Mr Moncur and stated that when that position comes up for appointment it will require somebody very good to beat him. If someone is to defeat Mr Moncur for that position, he will have to be very good indeed. I gave him a vote of confidence, though I did not announce his appointment. Certainly, he has not yet been appointed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked Senator Richardson whether he said this morning that it was his first visit to the Antarctic Division.
—Yes.
—If that is the case, I ask why the Minister misled this Parliament in answer to the following question which I put to him during a hearing of Estimates Committee D on 13 April:

QUESTION.PARA: Have you been down to the Antarctic Division, Minister?
In reply the Minister said:
I have been down to Hobart to the Division, but I certainly have not been to Antarctica. . .
I would suggest that the Antarctic Division and Antarctica are two different places.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators-Resign!

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to resign. I do not recall the exact incident.
—Oh!

—I am sorry to disappoint Senator Hill. What I meant to say, if that is the case, is that I had been down to Hobart to talk to people from the Antarctic Division. If there is confusion, I most humbly apologise but I do not believe it is the end of the world.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Reynolds, to verify changes in outstanding public rental housing applications. I am sorry that I do not have the exact date of the question. The figures cited by Senator Chaney on 9 March are correct. Levels of outstanding rental applications have increased in most States. This includes Queensland, where rental applications increased by a massive 48 per cent to 13,665 in the 18 months to 31 December. Some of this increase was a response to private rental market pressures arising in Brisbane from World Expo 88.

ANSWER.PARA: Movements in waiting list levels over time reflect a number of factors, including general economic conditions, house prices, interest rates and, as exemplified in Queensland recently, private rents. However, the point to highlight is that public housing waiting list data need to be interpreted with great care, particularly when comparing figures between States. It is also important to remember that different eligibility criteria apply to public housing in each State-for example, in Queensland where young single people do not have access.

In addition, State practices differ with regard to other forms of housing assistance such as home purchase assistance and also the availability and standards of public housing stock. A better indicator of State public housing effort is to compare the levels of public rental stock on a population basis. As at 30 June 1987, stock per thousand head of the population ranged from 55.5 in the Northern Territory to 11.1 in Queensland, the lowest in Australia. In Australia the average stock per thousand head of the population is 19.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the Minister's answer.

This answer was sought following an answer given by the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Reynolds, who unfortunately, because of her back injury, is not here to provide the answer herself. I have moved to take note of the answer because I believe that we should come back to the debate when Senator Reynolds is available. The answer which the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) has given, which no doubt was provided for him, is full of holes and does not contain the apology that we were promised by Senator Reynolds if her original statement in this place was wrong, which clearly it has been shown to be.

Honourable senators should remember that Senator Reynolds said in this place that if there was an increase in housing waiting lists around Australia we should be examining the respective records of the States and their ideological commitment to housing and that that would throw up a very interesting pattern. It does. The figures that have just been confirmed as correct show that in those States which have non-Labor governments, the housing lists have either reduced or have grown by a much smaller proportion than the housing lists in those States which are governed by Labor.

It is no answer for the Minister to try to confuse the issue. I do not blame Senator Reynolds directly because I assume that she may have been out of action because of her back. But the answer which has been delivered on her behalf by the Leader of the Government is deceptive and warrants further debate and analysis. If a State is successful in encouraging private home ownership, then having a lower public housing stock is to be expected. If a State, for example, has a large resource industry which provides a great deal of rental housing which might in another State be provided by a State housing authority, again that would affect the ratio of public housing to population.

The important point is that a Minister of the Crown with responsibilities in this area made the direct political point that the nature of a State government, whether Labor, Liberal or National, would have a direct relationship to public housing lists. The figures show that in those States which do not have a Labor government there has been either a reduction in the waiting lists or a much smaller increase than in the Labor States. I await the apology that was promised by Senator Reynolds. She said that she would examine the figures and come into this place and apologise. I trust that before we resume debate on this motion she will deliver the apology she promised. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I do not want to delay the discussion. As I understand it, there was an allegation by Senator Reynolds that Senator Chaney's figures were incorrect. I have now confirmed that Senator Chaney's figures were correct. In the course of giving my earlier answer I meant to apologise for that error. I do not wish to carry the debate further because I think the answer is complex in a sense and should wait.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was asked by Senator Bishop whether I or my Department took any action in response to an alleged request or requests by Senator Graham Richardson to terminate the employment of a former research assistant and speech writer to the Australian Ambassador in Washington, Mr Michael Davis. I replied that I had no knowledge of Mr Michael Davis. Lest there be any lingering anxiety in Senator Bishop's breast that there is some selectivity about that response, may I now, with the benefit of further information, reply also on behalf of my Department.

ANSWER.PARA: My Department has told me that Mr Michael Davis commenced employment with the Embassy in Washington in the locally engaged staff position of research officer to the Ambassador on 25 October 1988. It has no record of any request or requests by Senator Graham Richardson to terminate the employment of Mr Davis. Senator Richardson has assured me-and he is an honourable man-that he made no such request. The services of Mr Davis were not terminated by the Embassy but he submitted his resignation on 21 February 1989 and left the employment of the Embassy on 29 March 1989.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMANDER OF THE MULTINATIONAL FORCES: SINAI

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to Order of the Senate relating to questions on notice, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, Senator Richardson, for an explanation of why a question I asked on 3 March 1989, Question No. 859, concerning the position of Commander of the Multinational Forces in the Sinai, has still not been answered?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Newman, the Department of Defence forwarded to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) an answer for his approval on 21 April. I expect to get any day now the answer to Question No. 859. It is disappointing to note that there are a number of questions from Opposition, Australian Democrat and Independent senators which are outside the 30-day rule. They now number about 15. Senator Newman's question will be the first of those questions answered, along with a question asked by Senator MacGibbon. I can only apologise and say that the answer is with the Minister. I will endeavour to get the answer for Senator Newman tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the Minister's explanation.

Mr President, you would be well aware of concerns that we have expressed over and over again about the slowness of response by the Department of Defence to many questions asked in the Senate and at Senate Estimates committee hearings. But this matter was of particular concern to the defence forces because it goes to the heart of the morale of the forces. Honourable senators would be well aware that the morale of the Australian Defence Force is at an all time low and the losses are at an all time high.

The question that I asked related to the opportunity which Australia had had to appoint a senior Army officer as commander of the multinational force in the Sinai. I asked whether approval had been given for this appointment when the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, stepped in and vetoed the appointment. I also asked whether the appointment had now gone to Lieutenant-General McIver of the New Zealand Defence Force and, if so, whether the Minister could advise whether the Prime Minister had denied an Australian the chance of such valuable experience when it was at no expense to the Australian taxpayer. I further asked whether considerations of Defence Force morale and Australia's international role as a promoter of peace were ignored. There is the nub of the matter. This was not something that would have cost Australia money and it went very much to the morale of the Defence Force. Although those were straightforward and factual questions requiring straightforward and factual answers, it has taken two months to today to get even a basic response from the Minister that a reply is on the way. The Senate does not find that good enough.

Whilst I appreciate that the Minister, Senator Richardson, is merely representing the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), I hope that he will take back to the Minister the Senate's concerns about the constant slow response to questions of all kinds asked of the Department for Defence and the Minister for Defence. However, this is of great symbolic importance to the Defence Force. It is not just a question of whether senators' questions are treated expeditiously by this Department and this Minister. Certainly honourable senators on my side of the chamber are concerned about this. We find quite unacceptable, firstly, the treatment which the Senate has had in relation to the slowness of answers but, more importantly, the effect which the matters enclosed in my question have on the morale of the Australian Defence Force. I expect and hope that the Minister will obtain such an answer before the end of this week in light of the slowness of the response to date.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes that the Western Australian Government paid $175 million to Mr Laurie Connell and Mr Dallas Dempster for a 44 per cent interest in the Petrochemical Industries Company Ltd, which virtually had no real assets other than a paper agreement with the Western Australian Government to supply gas, which was not a specific binding contract;

(b) further notes that both the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) have been highly critical of the proposals by the Premier of New South Wales (NSW) (Mr Greiner) to spend more money on road and sewerage infrastructure in that State to halt the severe run-down of this critical infrastructure;

(c) expresses its concern that the Treasurer has threatened the NSW Government with cuts to Commonwealth funding in general assistance grants at the forthcoming Premiers' Conference as a result of its road funding and sewerage proposals; and

(d) expresses its view that it would be hypocritical and inconsistent for the Federal Government to cut payments to NSW if it did not also treat Western Australia in the same fashion for its reckless and wasteful spending on the Petrochemical Industries Company Ltd.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Button)-by leave-proposed:
That the Senate take note of the Interim Report of the National Companies and Securities Commission to the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities on Rothwells Ltd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated a few minutes ago, the Opposition had intended to bring this matter on for debate by way of a matter of public importance. We have made some small procedural adjustment which I hope will effectively permit a slightly larger number of people to participate in the debate. But the Opposition is anxious to have at least some preliminary debate on the interim report of the National Companies and Securities Commission to the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities on Rothwells Ltd, not least because the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) acknowledged in Question Time today that he has no detailed knowledge of the matters which are contained in it. I think it is important that Ministers in this Government should have some understanding of the scandalous state of affairs in Western Australia which is disclosed by this report which is not a matter which has been hidden away completely in the past because there has been a great deal of newspaper publicity about it. But at least we have a non-political exposition of the facts which have surrounded the Rothwells Ltd debacle. I trust that that will draw it to the attention of the Government in a way which will lead it to understand just what a shameful government we have in Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The report is a sorry tale of dereliction of duty on the part of that Government and its Ministers. I think the report shows clear evidence of the theft of taxpayers' money. I say that because it is quite clear that taxpayers' funds have been misapplied by the Western Australian Government and have been used for purposes which I do not think can be properly described as public purposes. There could be no clearer case of a breach of the duty which a government owes to its taxpayers and its citizens than the events which surround the Rothwells debacle. I believe it is important that in this Senate we draw the attention of the Government, and not least the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) who is at the table, to the facts which are disclosed.

In a debate in which my speaking time is limited to a quarter of an hour I cannot cover a great deal of this voluminous report but I wish to deal with the report enough to demonstrate that there has been a clear breach of the duties of the Government of a kind which no reform of the company law could fix, or remedy, or prevent occurring in the future. This is not a case of the law being inadequate; this is a case where Government Ministers have totally ignored their clear public duty and, in the case of one Minister-Minister Grill-he used his ministerial authority to override the objections of the Western Australian State Electricity Commission to deliver a cheque for $15m which was to be misapplied-that is, not used for the purpose for which it was delivered. A clear, open public scandal is evidenced in these documents and that should be understood at the Federal level. It is important that that should be understood at the Federal level for the reasons that are set out in Senator Tony Messner's notice of motion given just a moment ago.

In the last week we have seen the nonsense of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) saying to the Government of New South Wales that the raising of taxes to meet the essential needs of that State and, in particular, to tackle the serious environmental pollution caused by years of government neglect, for a legitimate and, some would say, essential public purpose, should be the subject of financial penalty at the hands of the Commonwealth. It reflects the views expressed in this place that Queensland should be subject to financial penalty because of what the Government has seen as the misapplication of funds. But in the case of New South Wales the argument is that the proper raising of taxes and expenditure of money on public works should give rise to a reduction in Commonwealth funding. This report shows the expenditure of hundreds of millions of dollars of public money for private purposes. It is a question that has to be addressed by this Government. If it is to attack State governments which legitimately expend money on public purposes, what does this Government intend to do about a State Government which makes clearly illegitimate expenditure?

How does one encapsulate what is contained in this report? The simple facts are set out and I wish to refer in particular to part 8 of the report, on page 42, headed `the PICL Transaction', the petrochemical plant debacle. This was a proposals which was owned by two people, Mr Connell and Mr Dempster. The report tells us that in 1986 Mr Connell bought his half share of the project for $400,000 from Mr Dempster and they became equal shareholders. It was a proposition to build a petrochemical plant in Kwinana. They obtained a mandate from the Government saying that they could build a plant, they got certain letters of intent and put a deposit on a block of land. In the ensuing time, in all the shifting of funds that went on in Western Australia, this project changed hands several times. We find it set out in the report that it changed hands for $30m plus and that a value of $28.5m was put upon it. There are various references to its being shifted about. By 31 January 1988 we find in a statement of assets and liabilities for L. R. Connell and Partners that it was valued at $150m. It just sort of grew up.

Then in the debacle that followed the bail-out of Rothwells by the State Government and the commitment of a guarantee of $150m worth of taxpayers' funds, suddenly Petro-chemical Industries Co. Ltd (PICL) acquired a value in the eyes of the Western Australian Government which led it to purchase about 43 per cent of the project for $175m. What was paid was a total of $400m, of which the Bond interests fronted up with $225m. This involved the Dowding Government, not the discredited Burke Government, and we have heard what Senator Walsh and Mr Dawkins think of Mr Burke, and I join them in their opinion-he is unfit to take part in the political life of this country. But it is not Burke we are talking about. It is Premier Dowding, who handed over $175m worth of Western Australian public funds for an asset which had no value to the State Government because that Government had the capacity, if it wished to have a petrochemical plant of its own, to give itself a mandate to have such a plant. All it was dealing with was a $100,000 deposit on a block of land, some statements of intent entered into, a mandate obtained from the Government and suddenly that was worth $400m. This report says:
. . . the project was still in the planning stage.
That is a direct quote from the report of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC). The following passage appears in the same paragraph, paragraph 8.15:

The most valuable asset possessed by PICL was the government mandate . . . the arrangement between Connell and Dempster was extraordinary and the Commission finds it surprising that Dempster was prepared to accept one-seventh of the price paid to Connell.

It is amazing, is it not? These were equal shareholders, one of whom walked away with $50m of the $400m and the other walked away with $350m. This same report sets out what happened to the $350m. It paid off the State Government's existing liabilities by discharging the National Australia Bank liability, and the rest of the money virtually went back to the Bond interests, which were owed the money by Rothwells. This is all set out in paragraph 8.22. It was a glorious round robin of cheques, with $175m worth of public funds involved-and now the saga continues with the Western Australian Government guaranteeing the development expenditure. It is now in for another $100m. It has loaded this project with this front end cost which will make it uneconomic in the future. It is a financial disgrace, it is theft, and the people of Western Australia are paying for it and will continue to pay.

I turn to a later part of the report. We find in part 9 the disgraceful involvement of Minister Grill. Minister Grill is not some poor trade unionist who has found himself a Minister of the Crown with no educational background-not that there are many trade unionists like that these days as most of them are highly educated people. Grill is a lawyer who practised and who has a strong commercial background. He has been involved in commerce, in mining and in other commercial activities as well as in his law practice. I commend to the Leader of the Government in the Senate an examination of part 9 of this report, where we find that as part of solving yet another part of Rothwells' problem the State Electricity Commission of Western Australia was being asked to prepay Western Collieries for coal yet to be delivered a sum of $15m. Again, a public body was asked to hand over a cheque for $15m-not for a legitimate purpose, but as part of a scheme to divert that money to sustain Rothwells in its extremity. That is the disgraceful role of a Minister who is a qualified lawyer, a man with extensive commercial experience. I quote from paragraph 9.11:
White would not agree to making the payment.
Poor Mr White! He is the man heading the State Electricity Commission of Western Australia. It continues:
Heron then passed the telephone-
