Heron is a bureaucrat, a public servant-
to Mr Julian Grill, who at the time was the Minister assisting the Minister for Economic Development and Trade. The effect of Grill's conversation was to direct White to arrange the payment.

TALK.START.PARA: —What department is Mr Heron from?

—I think Mr Heron was a public servant in the Department of Premier and Cabinet. The point of this debate is that this Government so readily turns a blind eye to chicanery on the part of people with whom it is in the closest political association. It appointed Premier Burke to be this country's representative in Ireland after he had committed $150m worth of taxpayers' funds to the Rothwells bail-out. I put this simple question: When Barry MacKinnon as Leader of the Opposition in that State was being pressed to support that, I said, `Barry, ask for Treasury advice on the subject'. That is the history of Labor in Western Australia-abuse of the trust that the Western Australian electorate put in it, and it is disgraceful.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to the Government that in light of the clearest possible demonstration that taxpayers' money has been stolen by this Government, what is its response when it will threaten the Government of New South Wales with financial penalties for raising taxes for essential public works? What threat does this Government offer the Dowding-Grill, in my view, criminal combination, when it throws the money of the people of Western Australia down the drain, when that Government gives it to selected commercial enterprises which it seeks to rescue? This is a disgraceful saga.

Let me briefly touch on one other matter. One of the unhappy things that happen when people steal as a servant is that the employers often let them off-they let them go away. I remember as a lawyer doing a case where a fellow took $250,000. Earlier he had been dismissed by a bank from which he had stolen a few thousand. The bank did not press charges. In this case the NCSC, in an attempt to avert financial panic, agreed to suspend its inquiries into Rothwells so that the ill-fated rescue promoted by Premier Burke would proceed. I think there is a lesson for those who are administering the company laws of this country that if they see a thief they should not stop investigating him; they should get into it and gaol him as soon as possible. I think that is the lesson to be drawn from what I am sure was the well-intentioned decision of the NCSC to suspend its investigation.

I hope that there will be a later opportunity to debate this matter in greater detail. The sad fact is that the matter we are debating today is just one of a list of examples of where the Labor Party under both Premier Burke and Premier Dowding has paid out taxpayers' money to rescue the people with whom they were closely associated. I refer to the Teachers Credit Society, Rothwells, the Swan Building Society, losses with the Danbury Group, the repurchase of the Perth Technical College site, $30m invested in Spedley's, and so on-the Wild West. Those people in the Labor Party have made Western Australia a laughing stock and have impoverished the people of Western Australia on the way through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that quite a number of people wish to speak on this matter and I will therefore try to be brief. A very large number of aspects come to light in the interim report of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC). It comes at a time when the Parliament has received a report from the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation. Presumably in a week or two this chamber will again be debating that legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: One issue which the Rothwells Ltd debacle clearly illustrates is the need for effective oversight of companies by regulatory authorities. One very important goal of a regulatory authority should be to maintain the confidence of investors in the securities market by ensuring adequate protection for investors from criminal elements or from other activities with the exception of those which are a purely commercial risk.

One of the arguments that have been put about against the proposed new national scheme is the notion that a unified scheme would be more prone to tampering by politicians and that improper practices would be more likely to occur. Having read this report, one sees that there is absolutely nothing magic or automatic about a Federal-State system or a cooperative system providing a proper level of scrutiny of commercial activity. There was always resonating in the background of the recent Committee inquiry the matter of Rothwells, which certainly led me to propose, and the Committee to accept, the notion that we ought to have a standing parliamentary committee to oversee the operations and safeguard the independence and effectiveness of any new Australian security commission. It is an area which is vital to the economic health of the country and to encouraging more Australians to invest in Australian industry.

Paragraph 1.04 of the report raises the use of the title `merchant bank'. I think the use of this title merits some consideration about what precisely is a bank within the Australian context. That is becoming a lot more difficult to determine. This could very well lead to many Australian citizens being dis- abused of their money by the operation of organisations with a variety of titles which seem to give them some support. For example, while our trading banks and savings banks are subject to quite rigid and strict Reserve Bank prudential controls, other organisations do not have that. The purpose of these rigid controls is, first, to ensure that none of our properly constituted banks experiences a liquidity crisis so that depositors are always able to withdraw their funds how and when they wish, and, secondly, to ensure that the banks do not become insolvent. Whether merchant banks using the title of `bank' ought to be subject to these types of controls is an interesting point. The interests of depositors investing with a merchant bank are not protected by the types of protections provided elsewhere for depositors with trading and savings banks. Nevertheless, the unsuspecting public could very well be led erroneously to believe that their investments are safe because they are under Reserve Bank supervision, when clearly they are not.

It may very well be that the use of the title `bank' is misleading to the general public and that we ought either to restrict the use of the term or to force those banks which are not trading and savings banks to state clearly that they are not subject to the safety net of control by the Reserve Bank. I think either of those two methods would be an advance on the current context, which is very confusing to the ordinary Australian who may not be aware of the details of the matter.

The second point I wish to make is about the lemming-like deregulatory thrust of the Hawke Government. Let us look at the items with which the NCSC is particularly concerned. They include the failure of the board of Rothwells to play any practical part in policy or other matters within the company or give any leadership or guidance; grossly inadequate financial control procedures; reckless lending policies; failure to obtain proper securities for loans; failure to enforce interest payments and monitor cash flows; excessive exposure to associated individuals and companies; and failure to institute and enforce proper audit procedures. A list such as that would surely be of benefit to anybody who was interested. The fact that this organisation has flourished for a long time and takes so many funds in makes us wonder whether or not our regulatory system is operating for the protection of the market or for the protection of those elements who wish merely to make profits for themselves at the expense of other Australians and contribute nothing to the general well-being of the community. However, I am not at all sure that when one opens the deregulatory door and lets in the pigs one can get too upset by the mess that they finally make.

I believe that we ought to be looking at the methods and the avenues by which we have sought this deregulatory thrust and question whether or not other comparable economies that consider themselves to be free enterprise economies, ones that see themselves as open, have gone the way that we have. For example, we might be able to come up with an Australian version of the United States Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, thereby guaranteeing that the Australian counterparts of small depositors who lose out in situations such as this within the United States are protected within the Australian context.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can regulation stop theft?

—It can actually insure the depositors in those types of circumstances. It does not stop theft. It actually means that we can invest to insure those people who otherwise would lose their entire life savings. There are many such suggestions floating around at this point in time. I do not want to be tied to any particular one at this stage. We certainly need to be extremely careful, in the light of this report, about where we go with further deregulation. Our financial institutions, in particular, need a strong, vibrant and effective regulatory process. It is a welcome addition, not a burden, because it provides long term stability to our financial markets. It provides security for those people who wish to invest.

SPEECH.PARA: Any other approach is likely in the long term to be damaging while it may in the short term appear to be successful. Damaging the confidence of our investors, as undoubtedly this instance has done, leads to overall damage to the market which most of us here would hope would be able to operate effectively and increase its usefulness to our economy. We are all mindful that the NCSC report is an interim one. The important thing is not the debate in this place or what we say, but rather the ongoing actions of the regulatory authorities in pursuing the points raised in this report so that, where criminal activities, no matter by whom or at what level, no matter whether they be in industry or in politics, that are uncovered are pursued in the proper course and the proper fashion.

It is not for us here to stand as judge and jury; rather it is for us to lend our support to the process which has already commenced and to hope that the suspension of the inquiry will not be a prelude to its disappearing but rather will be a prelude to proper activity through the courts to find what type of relief, if any, might be available for those investors. But, equally importantly, the sign must be given to other people who wish to pursue these types of reckless exercises with other peoples' money that none of the people in the areas of authority intend to allow this to occur and that they will in fact use the law vigorously and to its utmost extent to pursue such people into the courts and obtain convictions of them, so that it serves as a warning to others that the exercises of extraordinary recklessness outlined here will not in fact occur again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate to support the words that have been expressed, in particular by Senator Chaney, and in many respects, too, the comments that have been made by Senator Macklin about Rothwells Ltd, the Interim Report of the National Companies and Securities Commission to the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. It is a report of the utmost significance. I must say at the outset how much of a tragedy it is that this report was not available to the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation, which reported to this Parliament only two weeks ago on the conduct of corporations law in Australia and on the massive legislative package which is now before the Parliament and which was brought in by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to upend and overhaul the whole process and law relating to the regulation of the corporations and securities industries in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: That Joint Select Committee, of which I was Deputy Chairman, sought unsuccessfully, on numerous occasions during its investigations, to obtain a copy of this interim report because we members of the Committee, without having seen the report, believed that it would have very direct relevance to our findings and the analysis that we were making of the Bowen legislative package. Regrettably, the Committee was refused permission to receive that report in time to take it into account. The report that we now have had tabled shows quite clearly how relevant it is and would have been to the work of that Joint Select Committee.

This report deals with an enormous range of matters of the most fundamental importance, going to the whole heart of the integrity of government in this country, to the relationship between government and business and, therefore, to the whole concept of corporatism in this nation. It is a path-which this Federal Labor Government has led us down and which Labor governments in the States, particularly in Western Australia and in my own State of Victoria, have led us down-of big business and big government getting into bed in a way that has resulted, as this report shows without any shadow of a doubt, in the pack rape of the taxpayers of this nation, in the theft of taxpayers' money, in enormous damage to investor confidence in this country and in enormous damage to the perception of the integrity of government in this country. They are very serious matters indeed because they go, in many ways, to the morality of this nation and, certainly, to the morality of corporate activity in this nation.

This report is a saga of corruption, incompetence, maladministration and total disregard for the use of taxpayers' money. It is a report that is so detailed that in the limited amount of time available to us today it is almost impossible to pick the areas that ought to be dealt with. I look forward to further debate on this report and its aftermath, because without any doubt there will be continuing ramifications from this report in the future.

One thing I thought I should do is to read into the Hansard record a couple of paragraphs that are contained in this report, because they give, in stark terms, examples of just what was happening in the relationships between the Western Australian Government and very limited parts-but important parts-of the corporate sector in Western Australia when the question of Rothwells Ltd and its bail-out was being considered. Let me just quote from chapter 9 of the report, which deals with the final collapse of Rothwells. That chapter lists and documents how an attempt was to be made to help the bail-out by getting the State Electricity Commission of Western Australia (SECWA) to put funds into the Rothwells bail-out in a way that had nothing at all to do with the normal commercial undertakings of the State Electricity Commission. The State Electricity Commission was asked by Western Collieries Ltd, which was part of the Rothwells group, to make a payment of $15m for ostensible reasons, the end result of which was to try to ease the liquidity crisis that the Rothwells group was experiencing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Asked by whom?

—It was asked by agents of the Western Australian Government who were in collusion-which is the only word that can be used to describe this-with the partners of the Rothwells operation in attempting the bail-out, against all conceivable odds, of the company and the group. The State Electricity Commission was written to by Western Collieries Ltd which, as I say, at that stage was in the process of being taken over and brought into the Rothwells group. Western Collieries, in a letter dated 10 October 1988, wrote to SECWA seeking payment of $15m. Paragraph 0.09 of the interim report states:

SPEECH.PARA: SECWA did not respond to the letter from WCL.
That is, Western Collieries Ltd. The paragraph continues:
Apart from one telephone conversation between Mr White, Chairman of SECWA, and David Crawford of WCL, it heard nothing further about the matter until 21 October 1988-
that is, 11 days later-

when White was rung from a meeting being held in the office of the Premier of Western Australia and asked whether he would agree to make a prepayment to WCL on that day. The telephone call was initiated by Mr Bill Heron, the Deputy Under-Treasurer for Western Australia. Although the prepayment was to be of funds from SECWA to WCL, everybody at the meeting knew the money was going to be used to aid Rothwells in the difficulties it faced by 5.00 pm that afternoon.
In other words, it had a fundamental liquidity crisis which it had to try to tackle by five o'clock that afternoon. The report continues:
There was no attractive commercial advantage for WCL and White's concern was that SECWA might effectively become an unsecured creditor of Rothwells once its $15 million had gone in that direction.
He was obviously dead right. Paragraph 9.10 of the report states:

On the evidence, the interests of WCL were incidental to this arrangement. It was purely a means of solving yet another Rothwells problem. Payment arrangements between SECWA and WCL had been in place for some time pursuant to a coal supply agreement. A variation required board approval from WCL, but despite some assertions to the contrary, the evidence indicates that the board (or at least the non-Rothwells directors) were not even consulted about, let alone asked to meet to approve, this desperate scheme.
Paragraph 9.11 of the report states:

White would not agree to making the payment. Heron then passed the telephone to Mr Julian Grill, who at the time was the Minister assisting the Minister for Economic Development and Trade. The effect of Grill's conversation was to direct White to arrange the payment. White did so and a cheque was drawn payable to WCL for $15 million and later collected by Lloyd.

Lloyd was a director of Rothwells. In other words, from a meeting in the office of the Premier of Western Australia calls were initiated to the State Electricity Commission of Western Australia which in the end resulted in a direction to that Commission to put money into what everyone at that stage knew was a futile cause.

Another incident-`incident' is the lightest possible term one could use about this situation-involving Mr Grill occurred just a day or so earlier in that month when on 27 October 1988 Rothwells again sought to use Western Collieries, through its facility with the Rural and Industries Bank at Collie, in a separate transaction to meet an urgent problem. The report states:

This time Rothwells approached the bank wanting some $6 million by way of overnight facility for WCL. That amount was to be on-lent to Rothwells which, by now, was in its death throes. The bank refused because it knew of Rothwells position.

Grill was then approached and asked if he would contact the bank to try to persuade them to change their mind. He agreed to do so and specifically asked the bank to consider rendering this further assistance to Rothwells. He was refused. The former head of the Department of Cabinet, Kevin Edwards, then contacted the bank and its position was reversed. The bank was persuaded and the facility made available. Its repayment did not occur until 2 November.

The very day after this repayment, Rothwells was placed in the hands of the provisional liquidators. No clearer example could possibly be given of the way in which the Western Australian Government played fast and loose and illegally and corruptly with the funds and the affairs of the State of Western Australia. I compliment the NCSC on the regulatory and investigatory role that it has undertaken in this exercise. I do so despite some of the criticisms that have been made of it.

The important point, apart from the disgrace to the Government of Western Australia as a result of the actions that were perpetrated, is that that is not the end of the matter. This problem is not confined just to Western Australia. We have exactly the same problem in my own State of Victoria where the Victorian Government is now attempting to wind up a government body, the Victorian Economic Development Corporation because it has become such a corrupt embarrassment to it. With Labor Government connivance, contrivance, encouragement and persuasion, this Corporation was forced into bed with a range of companies in Victoria on the shoddiest of investigations and without proper regard for the use of taxpayers' money. The net result is that the Corporation lost $110m of taxpayers' money.

I say to the Senate that if governments in this country continue down the route of trying to involve themselves with matters which have no earthly connection with the role of government-I am talking about commercial activities-we will pay a very heavy price indeed, not just in terms of the pack rape of taxpayers, but also the inevitable corruption and maladministration that will result. We have seen it par excellence in this interim report on Rothwells. We have seen it in my own State of Victoria. We will see it time and again unless we get government out of this corporatist approach of thinking that something good will come out of working with the private sector in terms of financing arrangements as distinct from the inevitable corruption, maladministration and incompetence that results. The report on Rothwells by the NCSC serves as a more than timely reminder. It is one of the landmarks that will pave the way in the Senate, the Parliament, and, I hope, the nation, for a much greater awareness and consideration of the fundamental issues that are involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also share the concerns expressed by my colleague, Senator Short, about not only the devastating indictment that comes through from the interim report on Rothwells Ltd of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC), but also the lessons that State governments such as the Victorian Government simply refuse to learn. It must be a matter of very great concern that not only is the Victorian Government not prepared to come clean by way of allowing a full and thorough investigation of the $110m loss by the Victorian Economic Development Corporation (VEDC), but also it is in the process of shuffling its accounts across to the Rural Finance Commission so that it will be even more difficult to ge to the bottom of that mismanagement. I do not want to dwell any more on the shield of the Crown concept, but this again is a classic example of a device that is being misused by government to protect the guilty and the incompetent.

SPEECH.PARA: It is Rothwells that we are concerned about today. One has to say, after even only a cursory glance through the interim report, that if ever anything is clear it is that the business of government should not be business. The Western Australian Government has tried to stand the traditional role of government on its head. It has perpetrated what can only be described as a travesty of the free enterprise and free market system because implicit in that notion, which even those recalcitrant learners such as Senator Bolkus have now come to recognise, is the fact that the free market imposes certain disciplines, but one of the requirements of such an approach is that those who fail should be allowed to fail. That is precisely what has not happened here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was the bottom of the harbour scheme part of the free market area?
—The senator will be allowed to fail in due course. He is doing very well, but his colleagues in Western Australia are the ones who should be hanging their heads in shame.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short has very eloquently catalogued the offences clearly committed by Minister Grill. It is incomprehensible that the Western Australian Government's reaction to date has simply been that these matters are in the public arena and therefore do not deserve to be pursued. It is a nonsense and a dishonesty of the highest magnitude.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today they said that they had been misinformed and misled.
—Misinformed, yes. Maybe they want to be misinformed and misled, but I am sure that the Australian community will not allow that to be the case for very much longer.

SPEECH.PARA: For Ministers of the Crown to be up to their necks in arranging transactions that could only have the effect of making taxpayers' money available to private corporations that were sinking fast is nothing short of a scandal and has been quite correctly described by several of my colleagues as nothing other than theft of public money. I have the greatest concern that the way in which this whole matter has been allowed to proceed to date has not caused the Western Australian Government to alter its stance fundamentally. The rhetoric has changed to some extent but there has been no repentance, no contrition, no acknowledgment of wrongdoing and, therefore, no basis for any confidence that these things will improve in the future.

This interim report contains a sordid account of desperate and dishonest Government actions. It is a graphic picture of larceny of public moneys on a grand scale. The first rescue attempt was the result of a package put together by a Mr Aleco Vrisakis who, at that time, was not only a frequent visitor and friend of Laurie Connell, with whom he used to stay most weekends in Western Australia, but also a very well paid legal and financial adviser to the State Government Insurance Commission of Western Australia. It was Vrisakis who put together the so-called rescue package-a corporate plan for restructuring the Connell empire that, on its face, involved Connell in coming up with some $70m of his own money in order to refinance the operations. But what is quite clear now from this report is that that was a mere device and subterfuge, that Connell in fact-and I would suggest aided and abetted by Vrisakis-conned the NCSC. I hope that there is a lesson to be learnt from this exercise and that should be that, where the NCSC suspects that offences have been committed, it should not allow itself to be seduced by the importuning of Government Ministers. Even Mr Henry Bosch, for whom I have considerable regard, acknowledged before the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation that he had kept Western Australian Government Ministers informed of his attempts to keep the Bell-Bond-SGIC deal out of the headlines.

We know for a fact that the same approach was adopted in the Rothwells matter, that indeed the settlement rescue package put together by Vrisakis was part of an agreement that the matter would not be publicised. Indeed, in an affidavit tendered in evidence before the Supreme Court of Victoria, Connell said that it was a precondition of the Western Australian Government's lending its assistance that there be no investigation by the Commission. We know indeed that the Commonwealth Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) was exceedingly reluctant to intervene to conduct any public inquiry into the affairs of Rothwells prior to the Western Australian State election. We now have it sworn on oath by Connell that in fact the Western Australian Government was insisting that the matter be kept quiet, and that is precisely what the NCSC did. It rearranged the deck chairs so that Connell was forced to step down and it put in place, of all people, Lloyd and Vrisakis, one of whom is now on criminal charges, and it kept the matter quiet.

Mr Henry Bosch says that it was necessary to do that in order to maintain investor confidence. I regard it as a very shabby and dishonest basis for not allowing the law to take its course. It is the classic argument that is always put by governments to prosecutors that somehow there are special circumstances that warrant a matter not being proceeded with. That is indeed what happened in this case. If it had not been for that-in other words, if the first rescue package had not been allowed to be put in place and if matters had simply taken their course-we would not have had that disgraceful and dishonest second rescue attempt under which the Western Australian Government colluded with the Bond Corporation to buy out the Petrochemical Industries Co. Ltd for some $400m. If ever there was a charade, that was it. Senator Chaney described it as a round robin. I think he was far too charitable. It was simply a device for bailing out Rothwells on a grand scale with public moneys for which the Government felt no responsibility at all. It was desperately keen to assist the rescue of Rothwells when it was clearly beyond redemption.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a round robbing.

—Yes, it was every bit of that. In merely pointing to the fact that that infamous conversation in which pressure was brought to bear on Mr White of the State Electricity Commission of Western Australia (SECWA) took place in the office of the Premier of Western Australia the report makes it clear that the Premier has a great deal of explaining to do. His discredited predecessor, the former Premier, Mr Burke, who was the architect of this scandalous approach, in my view should be recalled immediately from a position where he is a continuing embarrassment and is no longer fit to hold any public office. The same can be said increasingly for the majority of members of the Western Australian Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a sorry saga. It is not the usual one in which quite often it can be said that people were the victims of their own ignorance or greed. This is a case in which investors in Rothwells had little or no knowledge of what was transpiring and could not have been expected to know simply because the Western Australian Government regarded itself as being above the law. It did not need to invoke the shield of the Crown when it was engaged in this sort of transfer of public funds. It was engaging in activity which cannot be dealt with by the law of the land, is not susceptible to the companies code and is really not something that any regulatory authority can do anything about. The only possible solution to a problem as serious as this is for the Government that perpetrated the offence to be thrown out of office. If that involves the blocking of Supply in the Upper House in Western Australia I am sure that the people of Western Australia will welcome the opportunity to bring in a government that has some honesty and integrity.

So the report does, I think, provide quite a number of lessons. It certainly will not be the last word on this sorry matter but, if it has the effect of making it clear that governments should not be in the business of business, that there is a separate and distinct role for government to play in encouraging a competitive environment in which businesses can prosper and if governments can confine their roles to that sort of stimulation, we will all be the better for it. But if governments are to get their fingers in the till in this manner, if Premiers are to close their eyes to any wrongdoing and somehow pretend that it is all a matter of public relations, and as long as the public does not think that there is anything terribly new about the allegations and nothing needs to be done about them, there is really no hope for us. I hope that this tale of ineptitude and dishonesty will stand as an object lesson for us all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise to join my colleagues--
—You are going to speak about Patrick Partners, are you?

—I acknowledge that interjection because it is typical of the sort of response we have learned to expect from people opposite whose grubby minds remain in the gutter and who are incapable of discussing any matter without personal abuse. I acknowledge that interjection because I believe it is about time that senators of the character, status and style of the honourable senator who just interjected should be exposed for the character, or lack of it, which they display in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I would now like to deal with a matter of direct government intervention in a farce-a disgrace-which simply cannot be justified and which is, to a modest extent, revealed in this sanitised version of the interim report of the National Companies and Securities Commission to the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. There has clearly been an attempt by the Australian Labor Party to cover up for its colleagues in Western Australia who were involved in this, one could say, up to their necks but it may be more appropriate to say up to their pockets. The significance of this report is to be seen particularly in the section dealing with the Petrochemical Industries Co. Ltd (PICL) transaction. This is the element which so clearly demonstrates how taxpayers' money was conveyed totally improperly into a ruin, a structure which, as has been established, had never been successful, whose accounts were totally phoney and which could not be rescued, not simply because there had been a stock market crash but because it was never viable at any stage. Rothwells Ltd did not collapse because of the stock market crash, but failed because--

TALK.START.PARA: —The report simply says that was a catalyst.

—As Senator Stone says, the crash was simply a catalyst because this organisation, so close to the Western Australian Government, was a pack of cards and some Ministers were involved in shuffling them. Let us look at the PICL transaction. As is clearly spelt out in this report, it demonstrates a disgraceful situation in which the Western Australian Government, in conjunction with Mr Alan Bond-who, I understand, is friendly with someone well known to members of the Government and who seems to be continually photographed with him; he is referred to by senior members of the Labor Party as `Bondy' and `My mate Bondy' and other suitable expressions-purchased half of PICL.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole saga of this petrochemical project is an extraordinary one. As this report outlines, the Commission is unable to understand how a value of $400m could have been put on PICL in July 1988. The Commission notes that at the time of the valuation and, indeed, at the time of the sale, the project was still in the planning stage. While considerable work had been done on feasibility studies and the necessary agreements and arrangements, and while a deposit of $100,000 had been put on a block of land-I must say that $100,000 does not seem to rate very highly among these multi-millions of dollars going down the drain-the physical project had not begun. The report says:
The most valuable asset possessed by PICL was the government mandate.
That is the Western Australian Government's mandate to operate. This Government purchased a right which it had, itself, given for this incredibly inflated purchase price--

TALK.START.PARA: —It purchased 43.25 per cent of that right.

—As Senator Stone says, the Government purchased 43.25 per cent of that right. It is unbelievable that $400m should have been spent largely by the Western Australian Government on behalf of the Western Australian people buying something which it had created itself and had the right to re-create. There was nothing specifically limiting about the mandate to start up this petrochemical project. In fact, the Government, had it been a rational government concerned with the assets of the people of Western Australia, could as well have said to another group, `This project will not get off the ground. Let us give the mandate to someone else'. Here we have the Western Australian Government involved in spending $400m to buy part of this project when, as the Commission has stated, it is unable to understand how a value of $400m could have been put on the project, particularly when, I repeat, the most valuable asset possessed by PICL was the Government mandate. Why did the Government do it? We have not yet heard a coherent statement from the Western Australian Government about why it spent good taxpayers' money on buying something which the Government itself had created for nothing. The mandate was a gift from the Government, yet the Government bought back its gift at a total cost of around $400m.
—It had to provide Mr Connell with sufficient funds so that Mr Connell could buy back his Rothwells loans, otherwise a gap would be revealed in the loans as is shown in that report.

—As Senator Stone says, the whole process was simple: it was to provide Mr Connell, the mate of the Western Australian Government, with the money necessary to buy back the crook loans. I will not use the word `crooked' because that might pre-empt any action that may well take place. They were bad loans. They were loans that would not be satisfied. They were loans that could not be met.
—Three hundred and fifty million dollars.

—The honourable senator is from Western Australia and knows only too well what was going on. Three hundred and fifty million dollars of these loans were loans by Rothwells to its boss, Mr Connell. These loans clearly were worth so little that the only person who could buy them back was Mr Connell. They were bought back as a result of this deal with the Western Australian Government. That deal is unjustifiable, unsupportable, disgraceful and exposed by this document. Even though so much of the material on which legal action is likely to take place has been expunged from it, there is enough in this document to dramatise how disgraceful this transaction was.

SPEECH.PARA: For the benefit of the record exactly what happened should be revealed. This is what the report reveals:
During April and May 1988 proposals were afoot within Rothwells whereby a significant portion of its loans portfolio (amounting to $350m)-
that is that sum Senator Knowles spoke of-
was to be sold off. The plan was to rid the company of `non-performing loans'.

I suppose the company would have known perfectly well that they were non-performing because they were to the managing director, Mr Connell. If anyone would have known they were non-performing the company would. This sale was to be to Connell. By July 1988 the purchase of the loan portfolio became public. On 21 July 1988 the Commission asked Rothwells to provide information to its shareholders and to the market generally about the proposal that Rothwells would sell the portfolio to a Connell company. The Commission then considered that the information that had been provided by Rothwells for the proposed meeting with shareholders to approve the transaction under the rules of the Australian Stock Exchange was unsatisfactory.

Following discussions between Rothwells representatives and the Commission, Rothwells released further information to the market. This was when the Western Australian Government stepped in to try to help its mate. An announcement was made of the role of the Western Australian Government and Bond in purchasing the PICL project-the petrochemical project. In those circumstances, the Commission announced that it would take no further action on the matter of the inadequate, inappropriate and unsatisfactory nature of the information being provided to Rothwells shareholders. The Commission having decided to take no further action, assurances were given that the completion of the PICL deal would see Rothwells out of the woods on a permanent basis. Of course, those assurances were empty, just like the coffers at Rothwells. It looks as though the Commission did not believe them either, because it began a further examination.

As the Commission then reveals, the sale of PICL to the Bond group and the Western Australian Government as part of the rescue of Rothwells and as a means by which Connell could extinguish $350m of his non-performing debts was one of the most important aspects of the attempts to save Rothwells. In other words, it is clear that the Government of Western Australia was aware that this was one of the most important parts of the rescue operation, and that it was prepared to risk the money of the taxpayers of Western Australia in this ludicrous and risky venture, particularly recognising that the shares in PICL, which had been sold for $400m, had cost Mr Connell a tiny fraction of that amount. In 1986 Connell purchased his half share of PICL from Mr Dempster for about $400,000, and, effectively, Dempster and Connell became equal shareholders in 1986.

What turned $400,000-worth of assets into $400m-worth? What magic thing suddenly transformed a $400,000 company into a $400m company? There is one simple answer: the Western Australian Government, by giving the company the special opportunity to construct a proposed petrochemical plant at the Perth suburb of Kwinana. Shortly after acquiring his interest in the company, according to the report, Connell negotiated a government mandate with the appropriate Minister of the Western Australian Government, Mr David Parker. I must say that Mr Parker's role in this matter is absolutely incredible, and no doubt that matter will be taken further in the appropriate place and at the appropriate time.

By January 1987, PICL was earmarked to be the company that would construct a proposed plant in the Perth suburb of Kwinana. This was an extraordinary situation. The Government's action was the only reason that $400,000 of investment became worth $400m, yet the Government itself was prepared-but has never fully explained why-to pay that incredible amount. The Western Australian Government was prepared to join Mr Bond in paying Connell 10 times the amount that he had paid for it. This is an absolute scandal. It is incredible that taxpayers' money should be used in this way. One can only hope that those who have been involved and who are culpable will be brought to account for their behaviour. I have been prepared at all times to face any criticism or inquiry for anything I have done, and I have always been totally cleared. I hope that other members of the Senate can say the same.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me start by referring to Senator Michael Baume's last remark. I have been in the Senate for four years and have heard the words `Patrick Partners' thrown at him on several occasions-most unjustifiably, I have always thought. I know the honourable senator well. As far as I am concerned, he is a man of outstanding integrity, and I should have thought that most other people here would agree.

SPEECH.PARA: Arising out of this interim report of the National Companies and Securities Commission, there is an opportunity that we, as a Senate, as a parliament, and as a community, can take. We ought to look at how we, as a nation and as a community, have conducted ourselves in the corporate sector over the last few years-indeed, for longer than that, because this is not an isolated incident in the history of corporate life in Australia. I refer off the top of my head to the Gollin incident of some years ago, and there were other problems as well. It is said that this has some significance because of the part played by the Western Australian Government. From what I have heard so far today, I think the debate has gone down an unfortunate path. It is unfortunate not because the Government of Western Australia, and people in it, have been criticised. They are open to criticism, and if they deserve it, the criticism is properly made. It seems to me that the Western Australian Government, and people in it, have been criticised in a rather unfortunate manner.

On the basis of the material in this report, there is reason for concern as to the part played by the Government. No doubt, that concern ought to be taken further, and relevant matters ought to be investigated. But it does not do that investigation any good for honourable senators to come in here-Senator Chaney led the charge, most unfortunately in my view-and accuse members of the Government of being thieves, of robbing taxpayers. Senator Chaney made emotive appeals, appeals that may sound good and, indeed, may score points in parliamentary debate but, ultimately, do not serve the community or achieve what we here ought to be on about. The reality is that very little, other than allegations, has been put before us to justify in any way what Senator Chaney says. In my view, it is disappointing that that approach should have been taken in the context of a serious report, a report which, unfortunately, has evoked exchanges of a personal nature across the chamber rather than a proper analysis of what we ought to do and where we ought to go-the proper issues raised by the matters set out in this interim report. I think paragraph 4.06 of the report should be looked at. It reads:

For at least three years before the stockmarket crash Rothwells enjoyed a reputation as a high flying and dynamic entrepreneurial company. Although it was never admitted as a member of the Australian Merchant Bankers Association, it was frequently lauded in the media and widely accepted as an aggressive and successful entrepreneur. The attractiveness of depositing with it was actively promoted by many investment advisors and its total loan book rose to in excess of $800 million. Its shares were also actively promoted and rose in value from $1.32 in 1982 to a high point at $3.85 in March 1987.

It may well be that it became central to the Western Australian economy and that in that context the Western Australian Government felt that it was obliged to do something about the fact that Rothwells had begun to fail. The question that arises out of the quoted passages is: how is it that, under the present system of regulating corporations and financial markets in Australia, the reality did not match the cosmetic appearance of what was going on? Clearly, the public and the market thought that Rothwells was operating soundly and well and was on the way to greater things. How is it that, given that appearance, money was apparently squandered and the inevitable collapse of Rothwells was speeded up by the stockmarket crash of October 1987? What is it about our regulation of the corporate sector and the financial markets that caused that situation?

It seems to me that we ought to be facing these issues in this debate. If the Opposition wants to use the Rothwells collapse as a means of scoring political points against its opponents in the west, so be it. The Opposition may wish to concentrate on this issue, but I think this is a great opportunity for us to look at the issues that are ultimately of great concern to the public, to the people who invest and to the corporate sector which, by and large, and in spite of the examples of disaster that have been quoted today, has served this country well. How can we regulate the corporate sector, not so as to destroy the proper market forces but so as to ensure that the shareholders, the people who buy and sell in the market, can operate in an honest context?

Senator Macklin said earlier that this is an opportune time to consider the corporations legislation that will be dealt with soon. It may well be that when this matter is properly brought to the fore it will prove to be considerable reason for the adoption of a scheme controlled solely by the Commonwealth. Under such an arrangement, decisions that ought to be made could be made more quickly than they are under the present Ministerial Council scheme.

I conclude by sounding a warning against the abuse that tends to fly from both sides of this chamber in respect of people's characters. Such attacks are made for political reasons. Although that abuse is part of the cut and thrust of this place, there is always a danger that the more serious and weighty matters will be overlooked and opportunities will be missed for making sure that the collapse of companies such as Rothwells Ltd do not occur and that the many people who have invested in them do not suffer disastrous losses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to pick up a few of the concluding remarks of the last speaker, Senator Cooney. The honourable senator made the very valid point that there must be something wrong with corporate regulation in this country when an event such as that described in the interim report of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) on Rothwells Ltd is the subject of such a catalogue of disasters. The truth is that had it not been for the intervention of the State Government of Western Australia we would not have seen the foul-up in the regulation of the Corporate Affairs Commission that subsequently has transpired. If we go back to the very first stage of the collapse of Rothwells, when the rescue package mark 1 was put into place-I think it was in the last weekend of October 1987 immediately following the stock market crash a week or so before-we find that the Western Australian Government used its aegis, its shield if you like, to give the impression that by its intervention it had created a safe vehicle in which people could invest.

SPEECH.PARA: At that time the Premier of Western Australia was Brian Burke and the present Premier, Mr Dowding, was a Cabinet Minister and party to all the arrangements and agreements that took place. That Government saw fit to interfere with the market place, thereby upsetting the process of corporate regulation.

At the time of the rescue plan, in conjunction with a number of corporate operators in Western Australia and other parts of Australia, Mr Burke, the then Premier of Western Australia, did a deal with the NCSC. He said to the NCSC, `We will not require you to undertake an investigation of the affairs of Rothwells at this time and as compensation we will ensure that the credit of Rothwells will continue.' In other words, the Western Australian Government induced the NCSC not to investigate the affairs of Rothwells any further and bring them to light in return for a deal that it would virtually guarantee the moneys owing by Rothwells to its creditors.

We are not talking about large corporate creditors, although they were certainly part of the scheme. In the main, the people who stood most to lose if that surety failed were the small depositors with Rothwells. They had relatively small sums of money. In many cases they invested their whole life savings in Rothwells because the Western Australian Government had told them that, if they continued to maintain their investment in Rothwells and not withdraw it, all would be well. That is how the Government of Western Australia chose to interfere with corporate regulation. The result was the disaster which is now well chronicled in the report before us.

The involvement of the Western Australian Government in Rothwells in October 1987 was designed to create the feeling that it had given its support to Rothwells, that all was well, that Rothwells could continue trading, operate as normal and--

TALK.START.PARA: —Training.

—`Training' is probably the better word. That involvement was designed to create the feeling that Rothwells could continue its operations and, thereby, eventually repay all its creditors and manage its way out of the problem. As subsequent events have shown, that was a false hope. There was no chance at all of Rothwells surviving, given the enormous mismanagement by its managing director, Mr Connell, and the apparent total abdication of responsibility by the directors of the company. No doubt those matters will be reported upon extensively in the future and no doubt actions will be initiated.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point that has to be made is that at that stage the Western Australian Government, given its involvement to the tune of $150m or more, actually installed its own managers and its own supervisors of the operations of Rothwells. Those people, in particular Mr Lloyd, who previously had been an assistant town clerk in the Nedlands Council, undertook the supervision of a multimillion dollar operation in Rothwells. We know that the NCSC has charged Mr Lloyd since then. We are yet to find out whether that develops into a more serious case. That issue is enough evidence of the total lack of regard and care which the Western Australian Government should have taken to ensure that people were properly protected.

At this point we do not know what the involvement was of those appointees of the Western Australian Government-Mr Lloyd and another person, Mr Edwards. All we know is that, whatever they were doing, they failed to achieve success in that it led to the eventual collapse of Rothwells in the latter part of 1988.

TALK.START.PARA: —All Labor Party involvements.
—Were they all Labor Party involvements? I am certainly not surprised to hear that because they were just as incompetent as the Western Australian Government. This quite clearly demonstrates that.
—Senator Tate is embarrassed.

—Of course, Senator Tate has been most embarrassed by this whole business. Going back over the last six months he has not been able to answer directly questions in the Senate about his matter. I think he would have wished that he could have answered them but he had no opportunity because he knew that an election was pending in Western Australia and, if he opened his mouth and told the truth, it would lead to the collapse of the Western Australian Government and the loss of the election. Of course, he kept quiet.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the points that ought to be made is that this very NCSC report is about four or five months late. It is conveniently late from the point of view of the Federal Government and the Western Australian Government, in that--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, not from the point of view of the Federal Government.

—That might be so but I have information to the contrary. A lot of this information was brought forth in debate as long ago as November last year and the Minister for Justice well and truly knows it. Consequently, he cannot argue that this report and the information that was available to the Government could not have been made public.
—Why did Dowding go to the polls a week before the interim report?

—Of course. It all smacks of some kind of conspiracy by the Government. But we are used to that kind of thing as far as the Hawke Government is concerned. There are a number of other matters, which we will not bore the Senate with, which indicate the lack of probity on the part of the Western Australian Government in this whole matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we should turn to the central point. At the stage that it was obvious that the collapse of Rothwells was inevitable and the Western Australian Government finally decided, after 12 months, that it could not possibly prop up the affairs of Rothwells any longer for whatever reason it wished to do so, it entered into a set of transactions which was designed to get the Western Australian Government off the hook and ensure that Rothwells could not possibly be examined by auditors, receivers or liquidators in any objective way. I refer to the final investment of about $175m of Western Australian taxpayers' money into the Petrochemical Industries Co. Ltd operation at Kwinana. As we all know, this operation consists of a block of land and a few pieces of paper on which agreements have been made, with the Western Australian Government, of course, to supply gas to such a plant. The total value of this operation, which consists of practically no assets at all, is $400m. I notice that the NCSC says in its report that that is a most remarkable price to have been achieved. I think it is outstanding. Turning a lump of land worth a quarter of a million dollars and a few bits of paper with words that really have no binding agreement attached to them into $400m is some financial operation. I am sure that Senator Boswell would be very proud of that if he could ever achieve it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wouldn't we all?

—Wouldn't we all. The Western Australian Government achieved it. We have to ask the question-indeed, the NCSC is asking it: How much is the $175m that the Western Australian Government invested actually worth? The truth is that it is not worth anything. The Western Australian Government has constructed an asset-at this time its value cannot be tested although there is plenty of comment about as to its real value-and it has said that it is worth $175m. So it has created some kind of parking lot for an amount of money that would otherwise have been lost by the Western Australian Government in Rothwells operations. The Western Australian Government has merely created a fictitious asset where this amount of money is recorded pending some kind of operation to retrieve it. Of course, that operation revolves around the establishment of a petrochemical operation at Kwinana which has very dubious chances of success.

SPEECH.PARA: In a nutshell, that shows what the Western Australian Government, under Mr Peter Dowding, is all about. We have also seen that well-celebrated transaction where Government Ministers leant upon the State Electricity Commission to obtain a cheque for $15m at the death knell of the Rothwells operation to keep it from collapsing. That was supposed to be some kind of advance payment in respect of the supply of coal by one of Rothwells' subsidiaries. Of course, that was a hopeless and totally fictitious transaction but, again, it was designed by the Western Australian Government to try to save the collapse of Rothwells.

TALK.START.PARA: —The case of the missing cheque.

—The case of the missing cheque. I understand that it has more endorsements on it than we would find on a bill of sale that had been running since 1825. It is simply an example of the extent to which the Western Australian Government has been involved in this set of transactions.

SPEECH.PARA: Two things are clear: firstly, for some reason or other the Western Australian Government saw fit to get involved in the Rothwells operation right from the start. Secondly, it saw fit to create the shield under which Rothwells could operate for about 12 months and thereby prevent ordinary creditors either from withdrawing their funds or from being paid out by Rothwells. This created a false impression of the security of the investment in Rothwells and was only putting off the evil day. The fact that the Western Australian Government got involved in this matter to this extent demonstrates a lack of probity, a lack of good judgment and a lack of pure common sense on the part of that Government. It demonstrates quite clearly that, even though it just sneaked back into office in the State election, it does not deserve to hold the treasury bench in Western Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make a few remarks about the interim report of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) to the Ministerial Council on Companies and Securities that has been tabled. I make it quite clear that, as far as I am concerned, in any walk of life, whether it is in the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party of Australia or any other party, whether in government or in opposition, no-one is above the law of the land and above investigation to ensure that functions are carried out. If that means embarrassment to the Labor Government in Western Australia, so be it. Some of my Labor Party colleagues have made public their views on some aspects of what has happened recently in Western Australia and the way in which the Western Australian Government became involved in some of these arrangements. The report of the National Companies and Securities Commission deals in part with some of those arrangements. So far as I am concerned as to the consequences of what has happened, I do not think anyone can justify defending actions which subsequently may prove to be outside the laws of the land. The old saying is `Let the dominoes fall where they shall'. People take that responsibility and that is what being in public office is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston got quite excited when speaking on this report. He made the blunt suggestion that Supply in Western Australia should be stopped to bring down the Government and force an election. We all understand the political motive behind Senator Alston and other members of the Liberal and National parties in wishing to defeat the Labor Government in Western Australia. It came as a terrible shock to the Opposition earlier this year that Premier Dowding was able to lead the Australian Labor Party to a third successive victory. One must remember that the Opposition parties in Western Australia made the affairs of Rothwells the major plank in their election campaign, but they were still unable to win that election. That campaign took place only in the early part of the year, and it seems remarkable now that Senator Alston and others salivate at the thought that they can force an election by using their numbers in the upper House in Western Australia. I trust that in future Senator Alston will be consistent.

What was Senator Alston's view in the late 1970s when a whole list of scandals regarding land deals enveloped the Victorian Liberal Government? Ministers in the Hamer Government had to resign, public officials were charged and some actually went to gaol. It was a whole sorry story of public moneys being wasted and deals being done to benefit particular private people. I do not know whether Senator Alston, then a senior member of the Liberal Party in Victoria, called for the upper House in Victoria to stop Supply to force the Hamer Government or the Thompson Government to an early election. I suspect he did not do so. Despite the sorry spectacle of revelations from the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police misconduct, no member of the Opposition parties has called for an immediate election in that State. That has not happened, even though evidence has been tabled pointing to the most sorry kind of corruption in that State, with former Government Ministers admitting that they were misusing public funds. I have not heard Senator Alston calling for Supply to be stopped in Queensland in the Parliament to force an early election. Therefore, if Senator Alston or other members from Western Australia intend to go down that track, I hope that they will maintain their consistency and look back to other sorry circumstances which have come to light and which at times have embarrassed the Liberal and National parties.

There is another aspect of this report which Opposition members have not raised, although I appreciate that they have had only 15 minutes in which to develop their arguments. I would emphasise that this report deals not just with the Western Australian Government's involvement in the so-called rescue of Rothwells, but also with aspects of the operation of public and private companies in Western Australia. In view of the information identified by NCSC, it is clear that in the near future this Parliament, and indeed other parliaments, will have to look seriously at introducing amendments to legislation to ensure that the operation of companies is more rigorously tested. I draw the Senate's attention to chapter 10 of the report which deals with audit responsibility. There is no doubt that if the Australian public is to have confidence in investing in companies, it must have confidence in the fact that annual financial reports published by companies and certified by auditors are true and accurate. Chapter 10 contains severe criticism of the audit procedures carried out by the auditors of Rothwells and associated companies. I believe that this area must be seriously looked at. We shall have to demand more vigorous attention by auditors, otherwise people will not have the confidence to invest in the future. I quote from paragraph 10.03:
Thus, the provision for doubtful debts was reduced from the original assessment by the auditors of $127 million to $70 million. The auditors then signed off the report without qualification.

I am sure everyone would agree that a reduction of $57m in doubtful debts is a significant figure, but that amount was signed off by the auditors without qualification. That is part of the problem we shall have to face up to. I quote from paragraph 10.07:

Rothwells published the consolidated financial statements for the half year ending 31 January 1988 in March. The statements provided no information on the build up of interest receivable or the difference between interest recognised as income and that actually received. Without such information it was impossible to assess the quality of the earnings and assets as reported. The implication in the document that interest income was actually received (as opposed to `receivable') was, in the circumstances, quite mischievous and misleading to those who relied upon it.
Again, weaknesses in the audit provisions have been exposed, which further emphasises my point. Finally, I quote from paragraph 10.10:

In particular, it is astonishing that the auditors had no suspicions about the nature of the transactions which occurred on 31 July 1987. Nor did they look behind them or endeavour to establish whether the transactions were bona fide, properly secured, in breach of the Code and correctly documented.

It can be seen from other chapters in the report that in regard to the running of Rothwells, I would suggest that if a bunch of five-year-old school kids ran a pie table at the local bazaar in the same way in which Rothwells ran its accounts, the teacher would keep them in after school. Accounts were kept in a sorry state, to the detriment of Rothwells itself. Those senators who have read the report will see that some loans were made and were not documented; there was not a proper register of share certificates and of assets held in shares. I believe that Parliament and the Government will have to examine the procedures of companies as a result of this report.

Although the Opposition may be salivating that this document is extremely embarrassing for the Western Australian Labor Party and to the Labor Party generally, we do not escape that responsibility. We do not draw back from the fact that this matter has to be debated and that people who have been responsible for these decisions will have to face the consequences, whatever they may be. This report should also be taken as a basis for understanding that amendments have to be made, for the protection of Australian investors, to the way Australian public companies operate, so that we can have an Australian stock market that is not some variation of the local Totalisator Agency Board gambling operation; so that investors do not face the same sort of risk they face when having a bet on the races. When people are investing money in the stock exchange and public companies with the caveat of buyer beware they should know that the information on which they are basing their decisions has been properly published and documented and audited by public auditors and so on.

I will conclude on those points. I am sure that some members of the Opposition will be looking forward to further reports on this matter. I certainly will follow this matter with interest, as I believe the Australian public should.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had no intention of speaking on the interim report of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) this afternoon, but I cannot resist, particularly having just listened to Senator Schacht's contribution. I think the way in which he has down-played the role of the Western Australian Government on this whole matter is a great tragedy. Very early on in his address to the Senate he made the comment, `Let the dominoes fall where they do and that is what public office is all about'. How sanctimonious can one get? What public office is all about and should be all about is telling the truth. Of course, the Western Australian Government chose not to do that right from the word go on this issue concerning Rothwells Ltd. It chose not to do that throughout the State election campaign in January.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Schacht might well say that the Liberal Party of Australia ran a campaign on Rothwells. That, to a degree, is true. What he failed to say was that the campaign and the election had been called for the week before an interim report on Rothwells was to be brought down. That is a very important factor. What did the Government have to hide if it was not prepared to go full term and have the report on Rothwells brought down? Of course, the Premier, Mr Dowding; the former Premier, Mr Burke; and many of the Western Australian Government Ministers have categorically and unequivocally denied their involvement, when this report quite clearly sets out that they are in up to their eyeballs.

The attempts of the Western Australian Government to rescue Rothwells have been laid out quite clearly in this document. They go right back to the first rescue which followed the stock market crash of Tuesday, 27 October 1987. The Government held secret little meetings with the various people involved. It should also be remembered that many of the people about whom we are talking today just so happen to be members of the Curtin Foundation, which is the major fundraising arm of the Australian Labor Party. Let us not forget that, because many of these people had been given positions by the government as a sinecure and they got into this, well and truly, beyond all shadow of doubt, further than they could possibly handle.

I think it is a great tragedy that the people of Western Australia did not have the benefit of information such as this prior to going to the polls in February. As my colleague Senator Messner has already said, many people who had invested virtually all of their life savings with the Rothwells merchant bank stand to lose all of that money. If this Government or the State Government believe that that is playing fair, I question their ethics as well. Many small operators are very much down the list as far as the concern of the Western Australian State Government goes. If they were not a way down the list, why did that Government choose not to report accurately its involvement in the Rothwells saga, what it had attempted to do and the amount of taxpayers' money it used, which will never be seen again?

Honourable senators on the Government side play down the fact that the amount involved was only $150m, $350m, $70m or whatever. That happens to be a lot of money. More importantly, it is a lot of money for many people who stand to lose their life savings. Let us not forget what this Government did in terms of concealing the State Government role. The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has been questioned on this for many months now. He has hedged the issue non-stop. I suppose I do not blame him to a degree, because he knew exactly what was going on. He knew that the Labor Government in Western Australia had to go to the polls, so I suppose that he had the interest of his Party at heart, but is it not a pity that either the State Labor Government of Western Australia or this Federal Labor Government did not have some concern for the constituents of Western Australia? I note today in this debate that not one Labor senator from Western Australia has made a squeak about this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should think not. They are too embarrassed to be associated with it.

—Precisely. They are far too embarrassed to be associated with it. The outrageous statements that Premier Dowding is making one day after the next on whatever issue he chooses to think of is certainly just cause for Labor senators in this chamber not to be taking his side. But surely Western Australian Labor senators in this place should be concerned about their constituents.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us go back to the deals that have been done, the wheeling and dealing of the Lloyds, the Edwards, the Dowdings, the Connells and the Bonds. How sad it all is in terms of the books being fudged. The executive summary of this report says that the administration, the management-all of those sorts of things-were absolutely appalling. Even when the Commission requested that details be changed and that management and administration be changed, that request was not taken up. Connell's removal as principal of Rothwells was perceived publicly to be his removal, period. In practice, that could not be further from the truth because he still maintained, as this report says, a very powerful influence.

The report then refers to the Petrochemical Industries Co. Ltd (PICL) project and to the State Electricity Commission. How many more examples do we need of government involvement, government manipulation and government rorting to the exclusion of the people of Western Australia? The report refers to the missing cheques for the collieries. The list simply goes on. As I say, I think it is a great shame that the people of Western Australia did not have the benefit of this report and those that are to follow. In hindsight they will be able to see the way in which they have been bluffed into re-electing the Dowding Labor Government. I remind the Senate that the majority of people did not vote for the Dowding Labor Government. The Liberal Party in fact received 52 per cent of the votes, the majority of votes; nonetheless, sufficient preferences in sufficient seats went to Mr Dowding. How many people in Western Australia would like to have another crack at the whole show? It is not a case, as Senator Schacht said, of salivating over the possibility of another election; it is a case of getting a responsible and honest government that can run the affairs of Western Australia, which has not happened over recent years with Mr Burke and now with Mr Dowding. It will be very interesting for the people of Western Australia to see the further developments that will be taking place over the next few weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The debate stands adjourned until the next day of sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I find the 1987-88 annual report of the Australian Safeguards Office totally inadequate as it fails utterly to deal with the reports of flag swapping of uranium that arose during the period covered by this report. Item 41 and annex K assured us that the accounting procedure was consistent with safeguards agreements but what we learned from the Euroscam revelations last year, just about 10 months ago, was that these are only a shuffling of paper and not worth the paper they are written on.

According to a report in the Age on 19 April 1988, Dr Hans Blix, the Director-General of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), agreed that it was impossible to know whether or not Australian uranium was used in nuclear weapons. When asked if Australian uranium could be used in nuclear weapons he replied:
I don't know. We safeguard quantities, not the atoms. Whether those atoms go somewhere else, I don't know.

It is interesting that on page 7 of the report the Australian Safeguards Office also quotes Dr Hans Blix, in an address to the Canberra Press Club on 20 April, as saying in respect of the IAEA safeguards:
. . . during the 25 years it has been operating not one case has been found where nuclear material or equipment under safeguards has been diverted to weapons production.

Of course, that is not the whole story and this is what the Australian people ought to know. Dr Blix also said that the IAEA cannot prove that weapons materials have not been diverted from uranium which is covered by safeguards agreements. It seems to me to be not telling the whole story for the Australian Safeguards Office to quote from Dr Blix in that context in its report.

The IAEA is totally understaffed and it is like the police policing themselves. This was the authority which was set up to promote the nuclear industry but which also finds itself in the position of monitoring the nuclear industry internationally. It does not have adequate staff to do the job efficiently, and when it goes to do its alleged spot checks on various nuclear plants, of course notice is given so that if anything untoward is happening in any plant it can very often be covered up. It is a paper shuffling exercise.

A further report in the Australian for 3 June 1988 confirmed that Australian uranium covered by proper international safeguards entered the same process as material not covered by safeguards. In this particular case Australian uranium going to the French enrichment plant at Tricastin was used for both military and civilian purposes. This was very clearly identified and detailed in this Parliament and outside about a year ago. Yet this report says nothing about that at all. In fact it states that everything is okay in terms of the safeguards agreements. It is just not true.
Australian Safeguards Office

Annex K seeks to explain the accounting procedure but at no point does it state that this is a paper shuffling exercise and that the yellowcake concerned gets physically mixed up with yellowcake from other countries which are not subject to safeguards agreements as soon as it reaches the enrichment facilities in France, the Soviet Union or any- where else. Yet we know that that is the case. Mr Kerin and Senator Cook, the Ministers responsible, were forced to admit exactly that about a year ago. Apparently exactly the same thing happens with uranium from Saskatchewan in Canada which also ends up in France as well as the United Kingdom and the United States. Again there is no guarantee that it does not end up in nuclear weapons programs or somewhere like the nuclear bazaar in Khartoum which we learned about last year as well. There is nothing about that, of course, in this report, which is just giving just part of the story.

In fact, it was about the same time as the Euroscam reports were being published that these reports of a large plutonium and uranium bazaar in Khartoum in the Sudan came out. One article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 7 May 1988 referred to a documentary called The Terror Trade-Buying the Bomb which described deals made as far back as 1980. Libya, South Africa, Argentina, Brazil, Iraq, Iran, Syria, Pakistan, India and the Palestine Liberation Organisation reportedly were involved in the auction style deals with uranium and plutonium apparently filched from nuclear processing plants in western Europe. One reference was to material coming from a nuclear processing plant in Belgium, a country with which we have a bilateral nuclear safeguards agreement, according to paragraph 43 of this report.

I fail to understand how such bland assurances about safeguards in the European Atomic Energy Community can be made in light of some of the scandals going on that I have referred to and, of course, that have been referred to in earlier debates here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSULTATIONS BETWEEN AUSTRALIAN AIRLINES LTD AND ANSETT TRANSPORT INDUSTRIES LTD 1988

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to make a few remarks on the consultations between the Government and Australian Airlines and Ansett Transport Industries Ltd during 1988. This, of course, is very much at the core of what is known in Australia as the two airlines policy, the tripartite arrangement between the Federal Government and the two domestic airlines.
