Of course, the airline industry is one of the most highly regulated industries in Australia. This Government has given notice that the two airlines policy will end in the next few years. In fact, we had to give something like seven years notice to bring this highly regulated arrangement for the air transport industry in Australia to an end. The results of that policy in particular areas have been quite disastrous for the Australian public. Those who use the airline industry regularly and have to pay the fares really do experience airline performance which is very much second rate by world standards.

I wish to talk particularly about something that affects my State of South Australia and some of the other less populous States, that is, the particular practice of parallel scheduling, the so-called duplicated flight departure times that the two domestic airlines, Ansett and Australian Airlines, are notorious for. At so many airports around Australia one can see one plane taking off and another from the other airline taking off within 15 minutes of it. It is a blight on our system. It is an obnoxious practice. It is one that would not be tolerated in any other developed country of the world. It is the bane of people living in South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —And in Western Australians.

—I know from Senator McKiernan that it is a bane in Western Australia. I know particularly from Senator Tate that it is a real problem in Tasmania. I am sure that those senators who are from North Queensland or from the Northern Territory will also agree with me that their choice of flight departures is severely limited by this dreadful practice engaged in by Australia's two domestic airlines. The airlines simply parallel each other right around the country and effectively reduce the choice of flight departure times. The airlines have tried to justify this by saying that they to do it only in peak hour slots, that is, early in the morning and late in the afternoon. That is one of the arguments that I have heard. In fact, if one goes to an airport one can witness this practice all through the day, not just in the morning and evening slots. In the middle of the day one will find both airlines having planes taking off almost in tandem around the country.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like this afternoon to speak particularly about the Adelaide-Canberra route, which is one I am sure is of great interest to Senator Hill. I know it is to me and to the Western Australian senators, such as Senator McKiernan, who come through Adelaide to fly to Canberra. The non-stop travel between Adelaide and Canberra is of vital importance not only to government officials but also to people in business and to those in the trade unions going to national meetings.

TALK.START.PARA: —And tourists.

—Of course. We find in recent years one of the two airlines has pioneered a non-stop flight from Adelaide to Canberra in the evening leaving at 6.40 p.m. We now have the practice where the other airline operates a service at 6.50 p.m. On one evening we have a parallel service between Adelaide and Canberra and yet there is only one other service direct from Adelaide to Canberra in the whole week and that is on a Monday. So that is two of the three non-stop services on that route-I know that Senator MacGibbon of Brisbane is probably eating his heart out that we actually have non-stop flights to Adelaide.

SPEECH.PARA: Australian National Line

In reverse, the other airline pioneered non-stop flights on Tuesday and Thursday afternoons just after 4 o'clock-a great service of enormous benefit to people travelling from Canberra, the national capital, to South Australia and Western Australia. What has happened now? We find in the new airline schedules that the other airline is flying on both days at 4.20 p.m. and has absolutely no other non-stop services from Canberra to Adelaide for the whole week. What a disgrace! This practice would not be accepted in any other developed country in the world. With a highly developed airline system, we have this idiotic, crazy policy where planes chase each other across the sky over Australia on a daily basis. One airline did the right thing with respect to the thin route between Canberra and Adelaide. But the other airline, after finding that the venture was a success, has a service which chases its competitor's plane 10 minutes later. I know that this practice also upsets people travelling to Western Australia and Tasmania and it is time that it ceased.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Equal Employment Opportunity Program Annual Program 1987-88

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This Report summarises the progress by the Australian National Line (ANL) in implementing its equal employment opportunity program during 1987-88. I will not talk much about the very limited progress which has been made in the last financial year. However, I want to refer to the basic problem that ANL has because of the method of employment of ratings for ships' crews, which is one of the major concerns of the shipping industry and is crucial to the development of a proper equal employment opportunities program. In passing, I note that there were two female ANL officers out of a total of 503 at the beginning of that financial year and two female officers out of total of 393 at the end of that financial year, reflecting the decline in size of the ANL. In other words, during the year 1987-88, the ratio of females to males actually increased although the number of female officers had not increased. At this moment, the ANL has no female officers. It had two; now it has none. One left to get married and the other has gone to work for a different shipping line.

Officers are direct employees of the ANL and therefore directly under its control and subject to its equal employment opportunity program. However, ratings and the terminal operational staff are not directly employed by ANL and are therefore outside its control in terms of its equal employment opportunity program. Page 5 of the report states:

Seagoing crew employees are also not directly employed by ANL nor does ANL have a control in their selection. Seagoing crew are employed on an Industry Roster basis and they are contracted by ANL to man our vessels according to their position on the roster at the time.

I want to talk for a couple of minutes about this seaman engagement system or seamen's roster, because it is the root cause of a lot of problems in our shipping industry, not least in our equal employment opportunity program. Seamen and stevedores have a system of industry-wide employment which is unique in Australian industry. Ratings are employed by individual ships from an engagement pool. The number in the pool is determined by the relevant unions and the ship owners and selection of the individuals to make up the crew is made by the unions, not the employers. The cost of administering this system has been borne in the past by the Department of Transport and Communications. However, this is about to change and the cost will be met through direct charges on the ship operators.

In addition to the cost of administration, there is a further cost to ship operators for attendance money to eligible seamen not assigned to a ship. These provisions cost in the vicinity of $2m a year and are financed by levies on the ship operators. The Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) was sceptical about this arrangement and concluded that the attendance payments were a form of unemployment benefit and questioned the need for the industry to provide its own unemployment benefit when the Government provided an economy-wide system quite separately. Submissions from ship operators to the IAC inquiry into coastal shipping expressed a strong preference to move to company employment of ratings because they believe-I am sure they are right-that only in this way can one encourage proper training, proper involvement with the success of their enterprise and, if profit sharing is appropriately introduced, some interest in the efficiency of the organisation they work for. In particular, given that there are more technically advanced ships, the current pooling system effectively ignores the need for skills specific to these vessels and forces shipowners to take on the next seaman in line on the roster, regardless of whether he can do the job.

This is an absurdly out of date system. We must move to company employment so that a proper emphasis is given to things like the equal employment opportunity, training and involvement with the success of an enterprise. Ultimately, we will have to go to enterprise unions in the shipping industry. This is the only way that we will overcome the gross exploitation of the labour monopoly which presently exists on our coastal shipping trade. Without that, there can be no efficiency, no equity and no fairness.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this morning senators were discussing a motion by Senator Hill relating to the reference of a matter to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters concerning a perusal of the Australian Capital Territory election system. I was concluding my remarks by saying that I do not believe criticism of the Electoral Commission's handling of this count has been necessarily well based. That is because it is a complex system and once the d'Hondt system was modified one ran into all sorts of technical problems. If the count is rushed and a mistake is made everything has to go back to square one. I pointed out that the New South Wales Senate election with about 45 candidates and a slightly simpler system, took eight weeks to count. For a start, it takes two weeks to strike a quota. Also, because of the peculiar rules of the d'Hondt system, as the primaries are being checked they are classified into certain categories so as to make the later count much easier. Those who argue that the Electoral Commission should have put on another 20 or 30 staff should have stressed to them that qualified staff are needed to check preferences. I have seen several Senate counts especially since the law was changed to introduce ticket voting. I did not see this one. Anyone who did would have realised the immense complexity of the task. Professionals are needed to do it because a few amateurish mistakes can affect 50, 100 or 200 sets of preferences and when a mistake is made everything goes back to square one.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not all that confident that, given the current nature of the modified d'Hondt system, any better method can be developed by the Electoral Matters Committee or the Electoral Commission so that these votes can be counted better. I doubt that the d'Hondt system, in terms of timing and speed, can be improved. It might be done by excluding candidates or by the electorate taking election matters more seriously than it did on this occasion but, on the whole, I am not confident that the d'Hondt system can be so refined as to make the count quick. Talk of computers is nonsense. The cost is immense and the program saves absolutely no time. It has been suggested from time to time that the Totalisator Agency Board (TAB) be used. Apart from not wanting to disrupt the racing industry--

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some constituencies you won't take on.

—Some I will not take on, Senator Puplick, but TABs are distributed not according to population but according to where the punters live. In New South Wales, many of them are in pubs and we do not want voting in pubs.

SPEECH.PARA: I doubt that we will ever get the answer to the problem but one possibility is to go to a simple electoral system. I favour 17 single member electorates. That is opposed by everyone else because people say that the Labor Party would win the lot. I do not know the Labor Party in the ACT too well but with 17 single member constituencies the Labor Party would not have won a majority. The constituencies are so small with 10,000 people that the voters do not let party loyalty dominate their thinking. They vote according to the quality of the candidates and all sorts of candidates would get up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Revolutionary outrage, that is.
—That is a fact.
—We all came down with the last shower!

—Senator Hill probably believes that Labor would get a majority and I wish he were right, but I doubt it. I say that based on my experience of local politics in the ACT. However, to my mind, that is a more simple system.

SPEECH.PARA: I have always been consistent on this-I have always agreed with preferential voting and single member constituencies for a lower House and proportional representation for upper Houses. The former distributes power and the latter distributes representation. Having only one chamber may be the answer. It may be better to go back and have nine single member constituencies and eight elected by proportional representation. At least it would be a far more simple system. However, I do not know that we can rewrite history.

I do think, however, given the views of the Electoral Commission expressed in the documentation referred to in another debate by Senator Jenkins, and given the fact that there is great public disquiet, the very least we can do as a Parliament is send this off for inquiry, and so we should. The Electoral Matters Committee and its predecessor over the years have a fairly good track record. Their inquiries have produced some very eminent reports. The Committee is not one of those stuffy committees of the Parliament. It is always relaxed because everyone on the Committee knows more than any of the witnesses appearing. That makes it a unique committee in many ways. The fact that Sir John Carrick is no longer on it makes its quality suffer somewhat because he was the all time expert in these matters. Nevertheless, it has a very good collection of individuals on it and I am sure that they will approach their task and try to find the solution rather than engage in political point scoring. As Senator Hill pointed out, it is only three years nine months until the next election and it is absolutely essential that the system be made workable.

I appreciate that Senator Hill had the courtesy to approach the Chairman of the Committee and raise matters with him. That is something that is too often overlooked in this chamber when senators are rushing off on point scoring exercises. The reality is that the Committee probably will not be able to give the reference due consideration this year, given the inquiries that are in train, but certainly it can start off by advertising, by getting submissions in and having the Electoral Commission do preparatory work all in good time for a serious inquiry.

I commend Senator Hill's motion to the chamber. I repeat what I said earlier that, even if this motion goes down, the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) in any event, using his power under the committee system, will refer this matter to the Committee. On being informed that the Senate chamber was more than likely to do that, he withdrew and ceded that responsibility to this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the objectives of Senator Hill's motion and are pleased indeed to fall in with the agreement of a limited debate on this motion, just as I was pleased to greet the Minister's suggestion yesterday of a limited debate on my motion, because the two motions do have the same objective, although there are some differences of emphasis. For the record, when my motion was raised with the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, I had no objection.

SPEECH.PARA: When I put forward my motion I did not know that Senator Hill would bring on a similar motion on the day on which my motion was scheduled for debate. Be that as it may, as the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) says, that is now water under the bridge and I certainly do not intend to retaliate against the Minister for his attack on me by seeking to have my motion debated on the date previously scheduled for that debate. The only thing that matters at this point is that the method and practice of the first Australian Capital Territory election be referred to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters for inquiry and report.

I circulated copies of two proposed amendments to Senator Hill's motion. This morning I gave copies to Senator Hill and to the Government Whip. I should like to flag those amendments at this stage. I sought, first of all, to have removed from the second part of Senator Hill's motion the words, `with a view to recommending changes which might improve the process and expedite the count'. I sought to have those words removed because I believe that in directing the Committee in this way we may be in fact limiting, by expressing this view, the extent to which the Committee would look at the issues raised and, in fact, anyone would be at liberty to make submissions to the Committee raising any issues with the Committee that, in his opinion, the Committee should consider. I am sure that Senator Hill will also do this.

My amendments also seek to remove clause 3 for a similar reason. In clause 3, Senator Hill speaks of two matters. The first is that he wishes the Committee to examine particularly whether the deposit required to be paid by candidates is adequate. Senator Hill has said that he wants the amount raised because, if the deposit were a higher amount, the mischievous might be deterred from nominating. It certainly might deter the mischievous poor but I do not think it would deter the mischievous rich. The question to ask is why so many individuals and parties nominated for the Australian Capital Territory election. I do not think it was out of mischief but more as a means of expressing their dissatisfaction with the electoral system and therefore as a means of protest, and certainly this was the perception of the media during the election campaign. It would be more advisable to find a satisfactory electoral system in order to deter such a protest. In a democracy where all those eligible to stand are entitled to do so it will never be possible to prevent the mischievous from standing. However, an aware electorate will respond to that by its vote.

Another element of our democracy is that one does not need to be wealthy to be a member of Parliament. Indeed, I am happy to say that these days one does not need to be a landowner to be eligible to be a member of Parliament. Of course, a salary is paid; so one does not need an independent income. One of the problems, if there were to be a considerably higher deposit, is that this would be seen to favour bigger, established and more monied political parties rather than smaller parties or community groups and sincere independents. I am sure that Senator Hill would in no way want to deter these people from nominating for election. Besides which, some 63 per cent of voters in the ACT chose not to give the first preference votes to either the Labor Party or the Liberal Party.

The second part of the third aspect of Senator Hill's motion deals with the cut-off level for successful candidates and questions whether that is set at the most appropriate level. I am sure that that will be one aspect at which the Committee will look. Here I presume that Senator Hill is referring to the 5.5 per cent of first votes required by candidates in order for them to be eligible for election. These could be a grave anomaly in that although candidates or parties require that 5.5 per cent to be eligible for election, it could well be that the last candidate in a Party list may well be elected on less than that percentage. I am sure that the Committee will look at that aspect very closely indeed.

The electoral system which the people of the Australian Capital Territory used for their election on 4 March is the very much modified d'Hondt system. It has one thing in its favour, which is that it is a proportional system and certainly the results of the election reflect that. Rather than being dismayed at this election result we should take heed of a letter published in today's Canberra Times which states:

Congratulations to the 17 candidates finally elected! They should realise that they are the servants of the the ACT voters, who demonstrated by their votes that the majority are thoroughly disillusioned by party politics. It is to be hoped that the 17 members, freeing themselves from groups, numerical order in group, and number of votes gained, will act as independents with open minds on each issue raised, seeking only the best interests of the ACT.

When that Assembly meets, which we all hope will be next week, we will see the possibilities of legislation reached by consensus. I suggest that legislation reached in that way may be better quality legislation than that which is simply arrived at because of the numbers. The House of Representatives is a House of Parliament elected on single member electorates. Any legislation put into that House will pass through, and does so usually without amendment, because the Government has the numbers. I was listening to a debate in the House of Representatives yesterday and the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), which is in Western Australia, said that they were wasting their time debating a certain issue. He knew that, like two other pieces of legislation which had passed through the House of Representatives earlier that day, it would come to the Senate, be amended and then have to be debated again with amendments.

We must ask ourselves why it is that it appears to be that only in the Senate can we have proper debate on legislation and have amendments put forward which, on very many occasions, are accepted and change the legislation. It is because the Senate is elected on a proportional representation system. The members of the Senate-the senators here-reflect the diverse wishes of the electors. Indeed, it is up to us all to be accountable to our electors. The author of the same letter in the Canberra Times states:
The new ACT Legislative Assembly can set up a type of non-party administration which might well be the envy of the states and Commonwealth.

It certainly will be very interesting to see what happens. I turn to the proportional representation system that was used in the recent election in the ACT and quote from a letter sent on 18 November 1988 by the Deputy Electoral Commissioner to the ACT Administration. He describes the modified d'Hondt system as, `an electoral system unknown to mankind'. It is known to mankind now, of course, and mankind in the ACT certainly knows what it is all about. The Deputy Electoral Commissioner points out in that letter grave flaws within the system. He describes, for example, the following:

. . . a candidate . . . could have all his first preference votes transferred away from him, and yet win a seat because of the transfer to his party of the votes of other candidates. Many would regard this as absurd.

Let us see what the Electoral Matters Committee comes up with as far as that is concerned. I turn to another point dealt with in a letter written by the Electoral Commissioner himself. He describes the d'Hondt system as follows:

It is also a system which is now so close to the Senate system that critics will ask why the Senate system, which is already familiar to ACT electors, is not being used; and there will be no convincing answer.

The Minister said earlier that it is important that people have a system which is well-tried and well-understood. Certainly single member electorates is one of those systems, but so is the Senate system. We have that system not only used for the Senate but also for the Legislative Council of New South Wales, the Legislative Council of South Australia and, of course, in the House of Assembly in Tasmania we have the Hare-Clark system which is similar to that and deemed by many and acknowledged by experts to be one of the best and most democratic systems available. I hope that the Committee will look at that type of system too. In an article which appeared today in the Canberra Times headed, `Need for referendum to rid us of d'Hondt system', Malcolm Mackerras speaks highly of the Tasmanian Hare-Clark system. He describes it as a system which, if it were to be adapted for the ACT, would mean:
Three multi-member electorates each returning seven members.
Hare-Clark voting and counting.
Ballot papers to employ what is known in Tasmania as `Robson rotation' to prevent parties from regimenting their vote.
Automatic provision . . . that where there are three federal electorates in the ACT the federal and territorial boundaries be the same (as in Tasmania).
Vacancies to be filled by counting back the votes from the previous general election of the member who had died or resigned.

That would eliminate the need for expensive by-elections. It would also mean that by-elections could not be used for party political purposes and the Assembly would simply carry on. In that article Malcolm Mackerras proposes a referendum. Unfortunately, there is a flaw in his argument where he suggests that the referendum should be similar to that held in Tasmania over the location of the dam. As we all know, that referendum had a very different result from that which was expected by the government of the day. We will have to look very carefully, if we are to hold a referendum, at the types of electoral systems that are proposed, and to be sure that all feasible systems are offered to the people of the ACT.

In conclusion-I do not want to overrun my time-I should like to give the opinion of the Proportional Representation Society of Australia of the d'Hondt system, which is, of course, a proportional system. The Society describes it as follows:

. . . the Machiavellian d'Hondt scheme, fully operational preferential voting applied for the first time in the ACT. However, each vote was deemed to be cast either for one of the nine independent candidates or, in the case of party candidates, for the party, regardless of whether the first preference mark was placed in the square against the party's name or in a square against one of its candidates' names.

That is another of the flaws in this system. We should certainly move very vigorously to put this matter before the Committee. It is true that the Committee is busy, but the sooner it has notification that this matter is to be looked at, the sooner it will be able to get on with it and rearrange its business accordingly. At this stage I will move my amendments to Senator Hill's motion in order that the Committee may have a broad perspective and not feel that it is in any way limited by parts of the motion. I move:
(1) Paragraph (2), leave out all words after `election process'.
(2) Paragraph (3), leave out the paragraph.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In effect, the Senate is debating Senator Hill's motion to refer to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, for inquiry and report, the method and practice of the first Australian Capital Territory election. As a member of that Committee, I should like to say a few words, some of which will have been said in this debate already. As honourable senators will know, the Committee has a very full plate. As I think the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) said, it cannot be expected that this reference will be satisfied this year. Because of the nature of the reference, and because of its implications, it will certainly require considerable effort on the part of Committee members and probably on the part of those who are going to make submissions to the Committee. I refer, for example, to the third paragraph of the motion:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) That Committee particularly examine whether the deposit required to be paid by candidates is adequate and whether the cut-off level for unsuccessful candidates is set at the most appropriate level.
That will open up the whole aspect of deposits, which is one of the questions before the Committee, presumably perennially. The second paragraph of the motion reads:
(2) That the Committee review the electoral system and the election process with a view to recommending changes which might improve the process and expedite the count.

That will take considerable time. Inherent in it is the question whether the system can be salvaged at all. That might relate to the question whether the electoral system, as distinct from the voting system, is appropriate.

That, of course, opens up a great can of worms-it opens the matter up to political considerations. I am not sure whether the Senate wants the Committee to involve itself in the appropriateness of the electoral system-that is, the number of members in the Assembly; how the numbers are to be distributed; and whether there should be single-member electorates, a proportional system, or whatever. Is it the intention of the Senate that the Committee should engage in such political considerations, or is it the Senate's intention to say to us, `Look, a decision was made by the Parliament in respect of the electoral system. Have a look at the voting system and see whether it is appropriate to be used for the purpose of achieving the result set down by the Parliament.'? That narrows the matter a little and introduces some sort of technical approach.

It may well be that, at the end of the day, the Committee will say that the electoral system is inadequate for the purpose of fulfilling the task of electing members in accordance with what was determined by Parliament. Under those circumstances, of course, it would be up to the Parliament itself to decide whether to change the system of voting or whether to change the basis of the electoral system itself. I agree with all those who have said that some consideration has to be given to this matter. I am sure that if it is referred to the Committee, as proposed by Senator Hill, the Committee, under the chairmanship of Mr Lee, will pursue that task with the vigour and objectivity-not to say the laid-back approach, as the Minister suggested-that we have adopted in other areas. The informality with which the Committee conducts its proceedings is beneficial. We all know what we are about. We have been around the place for a few years now, and I think we understand each other. That cuts out a lot of wasted talk. Having said that, I will not waste any more words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I should like to say that we will oppose both amendments, although I understand that the first will be passed. The reason we oppose the first is that we believe that it is better to give this inquiry some focus-a focus in relation to the existing system, much along the lines of what Senator Harradine has outlined, to see whether, in the words of the motion, changes might be made that could `improve the process and expedite the count'. There is no doubt that, by deleting those words, the Senate is making it clear that the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters is invited to look at all possible alternative systems for the Australian Capital Territory. To me, that simply takes the debate back by years and touches on issues raised by the Australian Democrats today and by the Government this morning. The Democrats said, `We still favour a proportional representation system and we want to have another go at it'. Senator Ray said that the first preference of the Government remained a single-member electorate system. All that I can see is that the debate will not be advanced because, ultimately, it will come down to a political decision that has to be made in the Parliament-a decision that was made, after a lot of agony, late last year.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that the better procedure would have been to accept, as we do, that there is no magic in this particular electoral system. But, presumably, it can be improved with expert advice. With the efforts of Senator Harradine's experienced Committee, it no doubt can be improved. We would be looking for a constructive and worthwhile contribution towards better government in the Australian Capital Territory. That is our preferred position and that is why we prefer the words that we have set out in our motion.

We oppose the second paragraph of the Democrats' motion because we think that the two specific matters raised in the third paragraph of our motion-that is, the deposit level to be paid by candidates and the appropriate cut-off level for unsuccessful candidates-are important questions that should be specifically addressed. We see that as being in no way restrictive but rather simply guiding the Committee on two issues upon which the Parliament can reasonably expect advice from the Committee. For that reason we therefore oppose the second part of the Democrats' amendment.
Amendment No. 1 agreed to.
Amendment No. 2 negatived.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration for inquiry and report: The administration of the tax file numbers system, and in particular:

(a) the extent to which the Australian Taxation Office, in its implementation of the tax file numbers system, has failed to abide by the provisions of both the Privacy Act 1988 and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Act 1988 by:

(i) disregarding its privacy obligations to the citizens of Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory in February 1989 by sending an admitted 55 000 to 77 000 tax file numbers letters to people who were either deceased or had changed address,

(ii) disregarding its privacy obligations to the citizens of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory in March 1989 by sending an admitted 29 000 to 58 000 tax file numbers letters to people who were either deceased or had changed address,
(iii) disregarding its privacy obligations by sending out a large number of tax file numbers letters during March 1989 in unsealed envelopes, and

(iv) extending the deadline for employee declarations beyond 31 March 1989 as set by section 202c (4) (a) of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Act 1988, yet failing to obtain a Proclamation from the Governor-General for this extension as stipulated by section 202c (4) (b) of the Act; and
(b) any other matter which was not in strict accord with the tax file numbers-related legislation.
(2) That the Committee present its final report to the Senate on or before 30 June 1989.

(3) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Committee has completed its report, the Committee may provide the report to the President, or, if the President is unable to act, to the Deputy-President and, in that event:
(a) the report shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate,
(b) the publication of the report is authorised by this Resolution,
(c) the President or the Deputy-President, as the case may be, may give directions for the printing and circulation of the report, and
(d) the President or the Deputy-President, as the case may be, shall lay the report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.

The implementation of the tax file number system, which as we all know was the subject of legislation passed by the Parliament about six months ago, was a matter of great contention in this place. After a prolonged period of examination by the Opposition and negotiation between the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Neil Brown, and the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, certain agreements were entered into in regard to privacy legislation. That privacy legislation was enacted at the same time as the Bill was brought in for the establishment of the system. At that time the Opposition agreed only to the implementation of the Bill and of the tax file number system on the basis of the safeguards which were incorporated into that privacy legislation. That must be regarded as absolutely fundamental to the position of the Liberal and National parties and their support for this legislation.

At the time that the Bill was being discussed in the Senate, the spokesman for the Liberal and National parties on this matter made it quite clear that notwithstanding the passage of the privacy legislation and the adequacy, as it was regarded at the time, of that legislation, the Liberal and National parties would continue to monitor the legislation and its administration by the Australian Taxation Office to see that privacy was protected and that the rights of individual taxpayers and individuals generally within the community were properly safeguarded. This system has been in operation, in official terms, only since 1 March this year, a little over two months ago. We have come to the conclusion that those privacy conditions have not generally been adequately adhered to by the Government. We have had evidence of this in recent times and this has been the subject of considerable press report and comment by Opposition senators and Opposition members of the House of Representatives. We have seen examples of mishandling of highly confidential matters by the Taxation Office which has allowed highly confidential tax file numbers to fall into the hands of those persons who have no entitlement to that information.

We have instanced cases of the Taxation Office forwarding to deceased taxpayers details of tax file numbers. It is not likely that deceased parties would receive tax file numbers but it is quite possible that living persons who wished to obtain a duplicate identity and a duplicate tax file number could use such a tax file number to establish a separate identity, thereby escaping the penalty provisions of the tax file number law. As we know, a tax rate of 50.25 per cent is applied to any income which is not the subject of a declaration of a tax file number. It follows that if a person could utilise a false number and declare it to an employer or use it for declaring interest or some other income, no tax would be paid.

This example of the way in which the system could be abused was brought to the attention of the Senate during debate six months ago; it was the subject of more general discussion in the prelude to the period during which the Australia Card was also the subject of debate. One of the concerns that we have is that numbers can be distributed to people and other persons can gain access to those numbers. This flows directly to the lack of application by the Commissioner of Taxation to his duty to ensure that a high degree of confidence, which should be the subject of his concern, is maintained.

We have seen examples of as many as 77,000 tax file number letters being sent to people in Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory who have changed their addresses. Quite clearly, these letters were not marked `highly confidential' or as private information in any way, yet they could quite easily have been picked up by people who could have utilised them for their own purposes-quite apart from the lack of privacy that that would offer any taxpayer who had been forwarded one of these letters. As many as 58,000 letters have been sent to people in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory in a similar way. The people to whom these letters were addressed either had changed their addresses or had died. Again, ordinary people had access to the private, highly confidential information of people's tax file numbers which could then be used or misused for other purposes.

That is the essence of the complaint of the Liberal and National parties so far. We have seen other examples that also justify our concern. A large number of tax file numbers were sent out-the total number cannot be estimated unless the Tax Commissioner can advise us in the course of this debate-in March this year in unsealed envelopes. Privacy provisions could easily be evaded in that way. People could find out tax file numbers and use them for whatever nefarious purpose they might have in mind simply by opening the unsealed envelopes, taking out the letters inside, recording the tax file numbers, slipping the letters back into the envelopes, leaving them as they were, and sending them on their merry way to the taxpayers. The essence is that privacy can be offended and violated and, as a result, a taxpayer's personal information in the tax system could be at risk. A person applying to the Australian Taxation Office, with the benefit of somebody's tax file number, could find out the affairs of that taxpayer.

I put it to honourable senators that this has occurred within the first few months of the history of the tax file system. We have seen, therefore, a collapse of the agreement that the Liberal and National parties made with the Government in supporting its legislation last year. That is why we have sought to bring this matter to the attention of the Senate and the public generally in recent weeks. That is why we now seek to refer the matter to a Senate standing committee where it can be further examined, where perhaps other cases can be found and where a line of action can be recommended to the Parliament whereby we could correct this matter. The matter is raised by us as it goes to our fundamental support for the legislation. We see it as being vital to the future development of the legislation that we ensure that people's rights are properly protected by the privacy legislation.

No doubt numerous other matters have come to the attention of Government senators-they have certainly come to the attention of Opposition senators-which concern the operation of the system itself. It seems to me to be quite reasonable for those matters to be brought into the open in the discussions of the Committee that we are now seeking to establish. It is not just a question of whether superannuants, for instance, should be the subject of this kind of legislation; and it is not just that people on very low incomes, such as widows or older people, may have had no experience whatsoever in dealing with the voluminous forms that are required to be completed in relation to the tax file number system. It is really the overriding concern that people feel that Big Brother appears to be looking over their shoulders in the everyday administration of their personal financial affairs. That concern needs to be expressed most in the course of the deliberations of the Senate Committee. It is something which needs to be balanced. We in the Liberal and National parties understand full well that the Government's intention with the introduction of the tax file number system was to stop tax evasion. But, as we warned at the time, that has to be balanced with the privacy rights of individual Australians as well.

This matter of Big Brother and the operations of the Taxation Office has been thrown into sharp relief in recent times. One concern that has come to our attention is the fact that people are required by law to start using the tax file number that has been designated to them by 1 April this year. Given that the law stipulates quite clearly that that use needs to have been commenced the Taxation Commissioner, in his press release dated 30 March 1989, said, `It does not matter if you do not comply with it in the first few weeks or so. We will not be too hard on you'. Apparently, that is the kind of flexibility that the Commissioner of Taxation has deemed he has in dealing with people who are retired or people who have received pensions notwithstanding the fact that the Parliament has made a law which states that it is mandatory that the system operate from 1 April.

When the Commissioner of Taxation has been challenged as to whether he has powers greater than the Parliament has granted him, he has turned round and said, `There is a rather more general provision in the law which allows me to exercise that power'. He has referred us to section 3a of the Taxation Administration Act which states, `The Commissioner has the general administration of this Act'. The Taxation Commissioner is saying, `I have been clothed with the power by the Parliament to administer generally the Income Tax Assessment Act. Therefore, if there is another Act which stipulates certain conditions as to time and terms, I need not concern myself about that because I can then vary those arrangements under this more general provision of the taxation Act and act according to my own discretion'. That is a matter of the greatest concern to taxpayers, and should be to all members of this Parliament. An unelected official is acting outside the Parliament's Acts which are specifically designated to him by the Income Tax Assessment Act. He chooses to vary the conditions because of what in the end is a very vague clause of the Taxation Administration Act which he claims clothes him in absolute power.

I believe that this reduces Parliament to an utter farce. Why do we sit here passing legislation and debating such matters as this if the Taxation Commissioner can merely vary his approach according to his own interpretation of some other sections of the Act? Who will challenge those powers, once having been exercised? Who will take on the Commissioner in the courts? Certainly superannuants and retirees will not have the resources to fight the Taxation Commissioner in the courts on such issues. It raises the most general fears, concerns and alarms in the community to see such powers exercised by the Taxation Commissioner. That is the reason for our concern. We will remain vigilant on this matter until we have appropriate responses. As we do not see such a response coming from the Government, we believe that the only way in which this matter can be properly resolved is by conducting a Senate inquiry as laid down in the motion.

It is also of concern, as more and more examples of the lack of concern for privacy become evident, that such powers are extending into wider and wider sections of the community. We know now, some time after the legislation was commenced, that those who receive social security and veterans' pensions are required to submit tax file numbers and to subject them to the normal provisions of the law. Their failure to declare that tax file number will result in their being taxed on pensions to the extent of 50.25 per cent. Clearly pensioners, be they social security or veteran pensioners, would be people who would not be in the most opulent of circumstances. Therefore, a loss of income of over 50 per cent would mean a great deal to them in terms of their weekly survival. The Government has been unfair in its treatment of that class of people.

We must remember that people in their older age, and particularly women, have not had the experience in business that many younger people may have and certainly members of parliament may have. As a result people in their seventies and eighties are bewildered by the mass of paper with which they have to deal. This is a penalty upon such people and could easily mean serious loss of income during particular periods that could cause them undue hardship. As I understand it, one of the most disturbing aspects of this matter concerning superannuants and retirees is that this was publicised by the Tax Commissioner only towards the starting date of 1 April, rather than much earlier to give people plenty of notice so that they could prepare themselves for these things.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said that if people were late, he would give them an extension of time.

—Yes, he then said that there would be an extension of time, and that was in breach of the strict wording of the law. Our concern is that the Government has acted with undue haste and has sought to rush in this tax file number system without properly taking into account all the concerns that were likely to occur in the course of its implementation. There are much wider concerns about which we should like to hear more. The Senate Committee certainly could judge the affairs of pensioners and veterans more effectively than could the Senate as a whole. As this Committee supervises the affairs of finance and public administration, I believe that it would be the proper body to look into these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me touch on a couple of other examples. We understand that some of the Federal Government's own retired public servants had no notification of their tax file numbers from the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office until 26 or 27 April-only three days or so before they were due to have their payments affected by the 50.25 per cent deduction.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are about three months out on that. They will not be affected until, I think, about the end of June.

—That has not been made clear by anybody, and I would like to see the Minister's explanation of it. The information that we have had is that there are 20,000 or 30,000 people in this category and that the letters were dated March. Those people will be suffering the effects of not being able to comply with the conditions involving the mailing back of their employment declarations before the application of the deduction on 1 May or thereabouts. I do not know what is the Minister's point about a period of three months. It does not seem to apply.
—Communication has been a major problem with the introduction of the tax file number.

—It certainly has. That is the vital point that we are seeking to expose. One wonders whether it is by Government intention or otherwise. Coming back to the example of 20,000 to 30,000 of the Government's own former Federal employees, I would point out that those people, in the last week or so of April, that, having had this matter brought to their attention, applied for an employee declaration form from the Taxation Office which they intended to complete and send in in order to avoid the tax. However, they found that no forms were available. Therefore, they were unable to complete the required duty and as a result are montes to have the tax applied at 50.25 per cent on their superannuation.
—They are hopping mad.

—They certainly are hopping mad. These people are not the Bonds or the Holmes a Courts. They are the people who, generally speaking, are earning a very low level of income. They will suffer most as they are at the bottom of the Government's level of concern. These issues are of great concern to us, the community and the media. These issues need to be exposed in a fundamental way in the course of the Committee's investigations.

SPEECH.PARA: These days no quarter appears to be given by the Taxation Commissioner, or if he does give quarter it is only at his own discretion. Apparently he resents the right of any parliamentarian to take on these questions in order to determine the privacy rights of individuals. I suppose Senator Walsh would seek to paint the Liberal and National parties as the friends of the tax avoiders as he normally does, and he no doubt will again. It introduces the view to the fair-minded person that we need a means by which the rights of taxpayers can be protected. I am interested to see that my colleague Senator Watson recently gave notice that he proposes to introduce a Bill which allows tax deductability for proper legal and accounting advice where tax audits occur in individual cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fairness and equity.
—It is an issue of fairness and equity. It will certainly deliver fairness to people who are badly handled by the Commissioner of Taxation and will allow them some opportunity of redress.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the arrogance of this Government in dealing with these issues that concerns us most of all. That was evident in the debate in the House of Representatives. The Government gagged the debate after one speaker on our side had spoken and, in the course of Mr Porter's introductory remarks on the subject, cut him off at the knees. It was not even prepared to listen to the debate or to the issues being raised. This arrogance demonstrates quite clearly the lack of concern by this Government for these issues. The Government was not even prepared to ensure that the envelopes enclosing the tax file numbers of individuals went out to taxpayers marked `Highly confidential', `Confidential', or even `Private'. They were sent out as ordinary mail so that anybody could gain access and misuse that information. It is just as well that we have a balance of numbers in the Senate where we can raise these issues, whereas in the House of Representatives the Government can use its numbers to close down any debate it wishes.

The Government is totally ignorant of the concerns of individuals in this community. We keep hearing about hands on levers and how the Government can manage the economy better than anyone else since Federation, yet we end up being in a bigger and bigger mess with greater debt every month that goes by. This comes from the great array of geniuses who sit on the other side. Amongst them there is total ignorance on the question of the issues that concern ordinary individuals. The issue that is before us tonight is one of them. It is about privacy, the interference of government in the ordinary affairs of individuals and the concern that government is somehow bigger than all of us. It is that total abdication of concern for people that the people of Australia are worried about. It is something which we in the Liberal and National parties are concerned and worried about, and it is something that this Senate should be worried about. I call on all members of my Party and the Australian Democrats to support this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is generally cold comfort after the event to be able to say, `I told you so', but, cold comfort or not, that is what has to be said in relation to this matter. The fact is that the Australian Democrats said last year that the tax file number legislation would not work; that the safeguards were more apparent than real; and that members of the Opposition were being conned by the Government, and allowing themselves to be conned for reasons that were never made clear to us. They paid no attention when we pointed out to them anomalies; loopholes; gaps in the legislation; clauses that were not going to work; and whole sections of the legisation that left people unprotected in a variety of ways from bureaucrats, from information falling into the wrong hands, from information being released without their knowledge and from information being contained on files that was neither up to date nor accurate. This, of course, is the result.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Messner has pointed out, in February and March of this year letters were sent to all States addressed to people who were dead or who had changed address, in envelopes that were not sealed; there have been innumerable instances where information as sensitive as an individual's tax file number could fall into the hands of somebody for whom it could be useful indeed but was never intended; and we have seen the arbitrary extension of the deadline.

Senator Messner has made a great deal out of his horror, his shock and his distress that all of this has happened, yet we signalled in the debates last year that this was likely to occur. Absolutely no notice was paid to our concerns or to our cautioning at that stage. Of course, the Democrats will be supporting the reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. We are concerned enough about the matter raised by Senator Messner to agree to his proposition, but his proposition amounts to a litany of the mess that has occurred as a result of the deal that was done last year by the Liberal and National parties with the Government on the tax file number legislation and the Privacy Bill. And it was a deal. It was a pretty shoddy deal at that, because what we finished up with were two pieces of legislation which were quite inappropriate for the times, which were not necessary when other steps could have been taken, and which did nothing to protect individuals from the invasion of privacy and other potential problems of the sort that has been raised in Senator Messner's motion.

I have some difficulty at times coping with the blatant, not to say breathtaking, hypocrisy of the Liberal and National Party coalition, which I presume is what it still is as of today. In 1986-87 those two parties, along with the Democrats, the Australian Privacy Foundation, various civil liberties groups and the odd right wing tax rorter, I will admit, opposed for very different reasons the Australia Card legislation. In 1988 when the Labor Government modified its plans by removing the need for a piece of plastic with a photograph on it to be imposed on all and sundry, members of the Opposition fell over themselves in their eagerness to support the Australia Card Bill. What caused the change of mind, I do not know. What made them think that the simple omission of a piece of plastic with a photograph, name and address and a magnetic strip on the back would make such a difference, I do not know. What we have, to all intents and purposes, is what the Australia Card Bill set out to do minus the card. That is an easy enough element to include in the system sometime down the track if a government of that mood gets control of both Houses of Parliament.

As a smokescreen the Opposition parties huddled in a corner with Government Ministers and worked out that they could save a bit of face and get a trade-off for the passage of the tax file number legislation by having some ineffectual, half-hearted privacy legislation introduced. That privacy legislation does not even cover the private sector. It covers only the public sector and, as we have seen because of the events that have led to today's motion to send this matter to a committee for investigation, that does not essentially protect anybody from anything. It is privacy legislation which is ineffective and is not doing what it should do. It does not protect anybody at all from the private sector incursions, because they are not included in the Bill, and it does not adequately protect people from the bureaucracy, particularly at the Federal level.

When the Democrats pointed out, in the debate and during the committee stage of the Bill, that the tax file number was a dangerous piece of legislation, leaving the way open for abuse by government departments, and that the Privacy Bill was a legislative colander, we got little support for our concerns from the Opposition parties. Indeed, so anxious were they that the tax file number legislation should go through and that the privacy legislation should go through that in the end they did not care how inadequate those pieces of legislation were and at one stage they took the extraordinary step, on the part of the Liberal and National parties, of actually voting against one of their own amendments because the Government said that it was not prepared to accept it. That was one of the more extraordinary things that happened in a fairly extraordinary debate last year.

Nevertheless, the Opposition cannot say that it was not given due warning of where this little exercise on the part of the Government was heading. In my second reading stage speech in November last year I said:

. . . as a result of the passage of this legislation . . . instead of being given a new number, an existing number, namely, the tax file number (TFN) will be used-it will make it very easy indeed for governments to control, manipulate, if not actually tyrannise, groups and individuals in society.

I know that there are those . . . who say that if people have nothing to hide they have nothing to fear. They say, `I do not care who knows what my tax file number is. I will put it at the top of this article that I am writing on this legislation'. That is fine. I suppose that if one has nothing to hide one has nothing to fear, so long as the situation exists where one knows what it is that one has to fear. If one does not know that, I guess one does not really know what it is that one ought to be hiding.
I repeat a point that I made in that speech last year:
Our society is not based on a system of legislation hinged on the idea that if one has nothing to hide one has nothing to fear. Our system is hedged about with protections of people's privacy.

I say now that, whenever we move to put an impediment in the way of their privacy being maintained, we should move also to hedge that impediment about with the elements of protection that are needed so that information cannot get into the wrong hands and cannot be misused, misallocated or collated and collected in some wrongful manner. That means ensuring that personal details, of course, such as our tax file number, should not fall into anybody's hands other than those who are authorised to have it. It is not just a matter of its not falling into the wrong hands. We do not know whose the wrong hands are likely to be. What we do know is that, if we have a piece of legislation as intrusive and as potentially damaging as this, we ought to make sure that nobody has access to the information other than those who under the legislation are entitled to have it.
Later on in my second reading stage speech I made this point:

The worst of it all is that, since the original Australia Card legislation met its doom, the Australian Taxation Office appears to have done nothing of any consequence to improve the integrity of the tax file number. The integrity of the tax file number does not mean spreading it around to all and sundry. It means improving its credibility. At the moment it has less credibility than a passport number. The cosy deal that was done between the Opposition and the Government to pass this legislation has achieved nothing except to get their rich mates off a hook.

That point bears further consideration. Had the Australian Taxation Office put aside its gung ho consideration of imposing a tax file number on millions of Australians and concentrated first on giving that number the same integrity as the passport number has, we would not have been faced with the situation of these tax file numbers being posted out in sealed or unsealed envelopes with `Confidential', `Very Confidential' or `Private' or nothing at all written on the top. Dead people would not have had numbers sent to their previous addresses. People would not have had these things sent to homes they no longer lived in. The onus would have been on the individuals to take documentation to the Tax Office to prove they were who they said they were, or to lose out by paying the top marginal tax rate as a consequence. This whole fuss and bother could have been avoided by a much simpler procedure.

Senator Messner complained today that pensioners have to pay 50.25c in the dollar if they do not comply with this requirement. He all but burst into tears at the thought of those people being penalised like this. I point out that that was his idea; this 50.25c in the dollar penalty for failing to provide the tax file number to the Australian Taxation Office was the Opposition's way of saying, `If you don't want to provide the details, you don't have to; but you will suffer by having to pay the top marginal tax rate'. All that did was to allow people on very high incomes to get away with whatever they had been doing and to have a choice in whether they provided the information.

At the time we moved an amendment which would have genuinely given everybody, whatever their income, whatever their status in life, whatever their age, a choice about whether to supply their tax file number to the relevant private sector institution. It involved providing them with information if they chose to or giving them a much better choice, giving them the opportunity, for example, of having 30 days in which to let the Tax Office know that they were working at a particular place and what their name and tax file number were or whether they had money invested in a particular institution and what their name and tax file number were. `Complete the triangle', we said at the time, `between the Tax Office, the individual and the income source. But don't make it a one way street and don't penalise little people'-in the way the Opposition was prepared to do by putting on the very financial impost that Senator Messner has just complained about.

Then we came to the privacy legislation-a piece of law for which the Democrats had been arguing for years. But it was introduced into this place in a form which was extremely deficient. We pointed that out at the time, and Senator Messner's motion indicates that we were right. We said in November of last year:
Worst of all, it will not be an effective protection against misuse or abuse of the tax file number or the legislation behind it.

We noted that the information privacy principles needed to be strengthened and that there needed to be a provision to sue for damages for breach of privacy. The Opposition in fact moved an amendment concerning the right to sue for damages for breach of privacy, and we supported that amendment. It moved an amendment regarding the Administrative Appeals Tribunal's review of a decision of the Privacy Commissioner, and we supported that. We supported a number of amendments and we moved others. The Bill went back to the lower House and was sent back here with some of those amendments classified as unacceptable to the Government. One of them was the major Opposition amendment with regard to the right to sue. What did we see happen? The Opposition voted against its own amendment. I find it extraordinary, given that situation, that Senator Messner should get up here and argue that it is somehow the Australian Taxation Office's fault for not properly using an ineffective, loophole-ridden piece of legislation.

This whole sorry mess has occurred as a result of the collusion that occurred last year between the coalition parties and the Government. It was inevitable from the beginning of that little deal that we would end up where we are today. It is a messy, unworkable system. Privacy protection is almost non-existent. It certainly has not been sufficient to prevent the abuses listed in the motion from occurring. There is an urgent need to take steps to ensure that an individual's tax file number is not sent to the wrong address, that it does not fall into the wrong hands or that it does not disappear in the postal system thus leaving him liable to a deduction of 50.25c in the dollar for everything he earns. I hope that at the end of the exercise, when the Committee has looked at this, it will come back with some recommendations and suggestions on how both the tax file number legislation and the privacy legislation can be amended in order to ensure that the right number goes to the right person; that ordinary individuals in society are not penalised unnecessarily; that information contained in departmental records is up to date and accurate; and that people know what has been written about them and to whom information is being released.

TALK.START.PARA: —It can never be up to date; don't be ridiculous.
—The Minister just cheerfully said that the information will never be up to date.
—Those who believe in fairies at the bottom of the garden might believe it can be, but as a practical matter it cannot be.

—An awful lot of people out there now believe in ogres that they never believed in and never had any reason to believe in before. There is absolutely no reason for people to have to confront the difficulties they are currently faced with as a consequence of the mismanagement of this legislation caused by the Government's incompetence in drafting and the Opposition's unwillingness to plug the loopholes last year. There is no reason why the many thousands of tax file number holders who have been disadvantaged over the last couple of months should have been placed in that position. There was no reason for any of this to happen. If people cannot be at least partly assured that the Government and the bureaucracy are doing everything they can to make sure that the files are accurate, up to date and not abused, ill-used or released improperly, one wonders just exactly what sort of society we are living in. This is not a dictatorship. This is not the sort of society in which people have to put their thumb prints all over things, and I hope it never becomes that. I did not expect even Senator Walsh, in his fiendish run for cost-cutting measures, to claim that it is not only unreasonable but probably unlikely that information will ever be up to date.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Messner has indicated, it is certainly true that the Australian Taxation Office has not fulfilled its obligations. It is certainly true that letters have been sent to the wrong addresses; that letters have been sent inappropriately; that letters have been sent in unsealed envelopes; and that there has been no indication of confidentiality on the front of letters. But the real culprit in all this is not simply the operating habits of the Australian Taxation Office; it is the system and its architects on both sides of this chamber.

It is very unfortunate indeed that we have to face up to the sort of motion that we are debating today, which seeks to refer the question of these infringements to a committee. That Committee will be asked to investigate the administration of the tax file number system and to inquire and report on the extent to which the Australian Taxation Office in its implementation of the tax file number system has failed in a variety of ways to abide by the provisions of both the Privacy Act 1988 and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Act 1988. Maybe at the end of this exercise both the Government and the Opposition will have the grace to admit that there was not only some other way of catching the rorters and the tax cheats in the community, but that even this way could have been improved so that we are not faced with the debacle that we have seen happening over the last two months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last year a number of the more irresponsible, time-serving mediocrities of the Parliament, especially of the Senate, had some success in selling to a few gullible or lazy journalists a conspiracy theory about the Australian Bureau of Statistics household expenditure survey and, of course, big-noted themselves in the process. The theory which they peddled then was backed up by a legal opinion from, would honourable senators believe, an anonymous QC and some pseudo-legal advice from one of the Senate Clerks. However, their limited success in that bit of self-aggrandisement has encouraged the same sorts of people to try on another stunt; hence this motion. Its purpose is the self-aggrandisement of those who support it. Its effect will be to feed conspiracy theories about the tax file number and, in the process, squander quite a considerable amount of taxpayers' funds. If the Senate carries this motion it will have shown itself to be following the lead of the Peter Sawyers of this world and the League of Rights, as well as providing for every other ratbag in the country a privileged forum in which they can run their wild allegations and conspiracy theories.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make a couple of comments about the speeches of Senator Messner and Senator Haines. First, I provide a straight bit of factual information. Senator Messner asked how many notices had been posted since 20 March. I have been informed that 3.8 million notices have been sent out since 20 March; I am not sure how many were sent before that. I earlier interjected in regard to comments made by Senator Messner about the Commonwealth's superannuitants. That matter was also raised by his Liberal Party colleague, the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser), whose comments were published in the West Australian some day last week. The honourable member for Forrest alleged that Commonwealth superannuitants, unless they had their papers in order by the end of April, would have 50.25 per cent deducted from their pay. The honourable member for Forrest, of course, did not bother to check any facts before he rushed off to the newspapers to big note himself. The fact is that the Commissioner for Superannuation has sought and obtained an exemption, until 30 June 1989, from the requirements to impose those taxation arrangements. I signed a letter to Mr Prosser today telling him that.

Another point about Senator Messner's comments that I want to make is that he criticised the Australian Taxation Office for not sending out information in envelopes marked `private and confidential', while simultaneously running the theory that a significant number of people out there are eager to get their hands on this information so that they can misuse it. If there are such people, would they not be much more likely to intercept an envelope marked `private and confidential' than an envelope not marked `private and confidential'?

Senator Haines referred to `the Liberal Party's alleged breathtaking hypocrisy'. I find that hard to take from a senator who has delivered sermon after sermon about the inviolable principle of non-retrospectivity in taxation legislation but who last year moved an amendment, which was supported by the Opposition, which imposed retrospectively a liability for capital gains tax on totally innocent people and who, on previous occasions, allowed crooks such as the Kelly brothers to walk away with literally millions of dollars that they had pinched from the taxpayers of Australia through fraudulent pseudo-superannuation scheme arrangements.

I shall now deal with the substance of the motion, if it can be said to have any substance. The points are designated with roman numerals (i) to (iv). Points (i) and (ii) refer to envelopes containing tax file numbers or tax file information being sent to people who were dead or had changed their addresses and those points were supported, backed up or supplemented by a number of wild allegations about the consequences. Taxation assessments have always gone out to people who are dead or have changed their addresses, and taxation assessments have always-if not always, certainly since I have known anything about them-had the tax file number on them. Admittedly, they went out to fewer people.

While I am on this point, let me say that I am astounded that even the Democrats could believe that it is possible for the Tax Office to have a totally up to date set of records of all persons who are still living and where they live. Surely even the Democrats could work out that if the Tax Office posts a letter with, let us say, a tax assessment in it on the same day that somebody dies, the letter will not be delivered until maybe several days or several weeks later. It is functionally impossible for the Taxation Office to have a totally up to date record of all surviving taxpayers and their addresses. It is as impossible to have that as it is to turn back time. I would have thought that even the Democrats would have been able to work that out.

Letters including notices of assessment will continue to be posted by the Tax Office to people who are dead or have changed their addresses, a fact which the Privacy Commissioner has acknowledged in discussions with the Taxation Office. The Privacy Commissioner has set, as a standard, that such errors should not exceed 1 per cent of the tax file numbers posted out since 20 March. I understand that the error rate has been contained within that 1 per cent. It is functionally impossible to have in the Tax Office, no matter how many resources are devoted to it, the names and addresses of taxpayers completely up to date. So points (i) and (ii) are essentially fatuous.
Point (iii) refers to allegedly unsealed letters. Apparently, some letters went out from the Adelaide office with faulty gum on the envelopes. That appears to be the reality.

Point (iv) criticises the Taxation Commissioner for not getting a proclamation from the Governor-General to extend to some later period the 1 April date for producing a tax file number. Senator Messner has semi-conceded that that is trivial as well, because the Taxation Commissioner does not need such a proclamation. He relies not only on the discretion afforded him by the Taxation Administration Act but also by section 221 (d) of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

As my colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) pointed out in the House of Representatives today, what we have from the Opposition is the latest instalment in an ongoing campaign against the Commissioner of Taxation. I do not wish to be too uncharitable but I have a suspicion that the real reason for the Opposition's hostility to the Commissioner of Taxation results from his cracking down effectively on some of their tax-dodging mates, in stark contrast to the dark and negligent Howard years during which a number of people got away with grand larceny in the area of tax evasion.

The Privacy Commissioner could deal, and indeed to some extent has dealt, with the sorts of complaints contained in this motion. The motion seeks to duplicate that function in the Senate. It is no surprise to me that the Democrats would go along with such a proposition heedless of any resource constraints. After all, if they believe that it is possible to have a completely up to date record of the names and addresses of taxpayers, if they believe in the fairies at the bottom of the garden, if they believe that the Government has a magic pudding, or if they believe in the existence of a cargo cult, it is not surprising that they would be heedless of the cost of undertaking any activity at all.

The Liberals, however, are supposed to be hard-headed, economic rationalists pursuing a deep and fundamental commitment to parsimony with public money. That parsimony is automatically suspended when it comes to the operation of the Senate. The rule that takes over then is self-important extravagance and self-indulgence. Because I do not think it is worth spending too much time on this matter, the final word I want to say on it is that appropriations for the Senate have increased in real terms by nearly 30 per cent since 1984-85 and by 17 per cent in real terms since 1985-86. In that same period, Commonwealth outlays in total have fallen by about 6 per cent. Those are the figures after adjustments for one-off items. A pattern of extravagance and self-indulgence has been followed here and is being continued tonight in proposing this motion which, it is clear, will be carried but, of course, as could have been deduced from what I have said, it is not supported by the Government.
Question put.
That the motion (Senator Messner's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
