upon which Senator Hill had moved by way of amendment in respect of the Copyright Amendment Bill 1988:
At end of motion add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that:
(a) upon the commencement of Part Vc of the Bill, or as soon thereafter as may be practicable, the Government should refer the following matters to the Copyright Tribunal for inquiry and report:
(i) the extent to which audio tapes purchased in Australia are purchased with the intention of using them to record copyright material and non-copyright material respectively;
(ii) whether the blank tape royalty scheme set out in Part Vc of the Bill is the most practical means of implementing a blank tape royalty scheme;

(iii) whether the blank tape royalty scheme set out in Part Vc of the Bill is the most effective blank tape royalty scheme for providing compensation to Australian performers whose material is recorded domestically on audio tapes in breach of copyright;

(iv) whether the proposal in proposed subsection 135zzs (3) of the Bill for a statutory declaration entitling the purchaser of a blank audio tape to a refund of the royalty paid on that tape is the most effective means of effecting a refund or waiver of the royalty when the tape is not used for recording copyright material; and

(v) whether the proposal in proposed subsection 135zzu (3) for the rules of the collecting society to make provision for the distribution of amounts collected by it is adequate to ensure that a reasonable proportion of the amounts collected is passed on or distributed to those whose own work has contributed to the making of the eligible sound recording or eligible work; and
(b) upon receipt of the report of the Copyright Tribunal on these matters, the Government should propose such amendments to the Copyright Act as may be necessary or desirable''

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Copyright Amendment Bill and the Circuit Layouts Bill are being considered cognately. In relation to the Circuit Layouts Bill, I note that both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats have indicated their support for that legislation. That is certainly appreciated and it is consistent with what I understand to be industry support, if not enthusiasm, for this legislation. That goodwill is even permeating the chamber. The Government is committed to fostering the development of the Australian computer chip industry and this Bill is an important part of that development. The Government is hopeful that the Bill can be passed before the conclusion of the World Intellectual Property Organisation Diplomatic Conference on the draft treaty on this topic which commences in Washington on 8 May 1989. We would be pleased if we could give our delegates to that important international conference the information, the message, the missive, the electronic epistle, that this Parliament has agreed to the passage of that Circuit Layouts Bill. I am sure that, with the support of the Opposition and of the Democrats, that can readily be achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already indicated that, for all the reasons that I outlined at length yesterday, the Government will not support the Opposition's second reading amendment. The Democrats' second reading amendment is acceptable, so long as the preambular words are altered in such a way that the Government takes responsibility for preparing the report that Senator Macklin seeks. He wants the Attorney-General's Department to be required, as a matter of urgency, to prepare a report. That would be inappropriate, as it would require consultation between several departments. However, I have given him an undertaking that the Government, calling on all its resources and departmental officers who are relevant to the exercise, will prepare a report along the lines he wishes. For those reasons, I commend the Copyright Amendment Bill 1988 and the Circuit Layouts Bill 1988 to the Senate. As I said, the Government will oppose the Opposition's second reading amendment, but will support the Democrats' second reading amendment in a slightly amended form.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -Mr Deputy President, in my speech during the second reading debate I foreshadowed an amendment in respect of the Copyright Amendment Bill. I wish to move that amendment, which is now worded slightly differently from the amendment which has been circulated. The difference is in the preamble, which now reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . but the Senate is of the opinion that, as a matter of urgency, the Government should examine and report upon . . .

Paragraphs (a), (b), (c), and (d) follow, as in the circulated amendment. The reason is that the Designs Act and the Patents Act do not come under the Attorney-General's Department, whereas the Copyright Act does. In respect of the Copyright Amendment Bill, I move:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that, the Government should examine and report upon:
(a) the implications for industrial designs of the provisions of the Copyright Amendment Bill 1988;
(b) the desirability of protection for industrial designs and the form such protection should take under either the Designs Act or the Patents Act;
(c) the adequacy and appropriateness of the present design registration system and the need for changes under that system to complement changes made to the copyright law; and
(d) the need for, and form of, any transitional provisions in the designs system following changes to copyright law which affect industrial designs''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill, do you wish to move your amendment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do. But now that Senator Macklin has changed his amendment, I might change my amendment slightly. I am seeking to move an amendment to the motion for the second reading to the effect that the Senate is of the opinion that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs should address these matters because I think the Senate might do so more effectively than the Government. Therefore, I move as an amendment to Senator Macklin's proposed amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out ``the Government should examine'', insert ``the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs should examine''.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 5 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Radiation Health Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) set standards for radiation exposure levels in Australia.
(2) What are the present recommended levels for both workers and the general public on an annual and lifetime cumulative basis.
(3) Does the Department or the NHMRC carry out regular tests of workers in susceptible industries; if so, what have been the results of tests of radiation exposures recorded in Australia.

(4) Will the Minister comment on a recent report by the Radiation Effects Research Foundation on the effects of radiation on the victims of the Nagasaki and Hiroshima atomic explosions which indicates that the predicted fatal cancer risk associated with radiation exposure has been raised by a factor of 2.
(5) In the light of this new information, what steps are being taken to review standards for exposure levels in Australia to ensure that workers are protected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Radiation Health Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) prepares recommended public and occupational radiation exposure limits for application under State and Territory radiation control legislation.
(2) Australia's Recommended Radiation Protection Standards require that:
no practice leading to radiation exposure should be adopted unless it produces a positive net benefit;
all exposures should be kept as low as reasonably achievable; and

dose equivalents to individuals should not exceed 50 millisieverts per year for radiation workers or 1 millisievert per year for members of the public. For the latter, this translates to a lifetime cumulative exposure limit of 70 millisieverts, or about one half of the natural background. These limits exclude exposures arising from natural background or exposures incurred in medical diagnosis or treatment.

(3) Neither the Department of Community Services and Health nor the NHMRC carry out regular monitoring of radiation workers, as this is a function carried out in all of the States and Territories by their own relevant health authorities. However, many radiation workers are monitored through the Australian Radiation Laboratory's personal radiation monitoring service, and average annual exposures have been derived for most occupational groups from this source. These averages differ from industry to industry and the average across all radiation workers is 0.5 millisievert per year, with a range from zero to 3.6.

The mining industry is not included in this summary, as miners are monitored in a different way. However, for the very high grade uranium mine at Nabarlek, the Australian Radiation Laboratory found that average exposures through the mining phase were approximately 3 millisieverts for the total of both external radiation and internal exposure arising from radon and its decay products. Averages for other mines are likely to be lower.

(4) During the past two years, much new research work on radiation risks has emerged, based on a re-evaluation of the exposures experienced by the Japanese atomic bomb survivors and on extended studies of their medical histories. This work is being closely examined by the international scientific community, and it is now generally considered that the radiation risk associated with severe exposure is about three times higher than earlier estimates.

(5) Information about the Japanese atomic bomb survivors is a very important component in the setting of radiation exposure standards, and the new studies have been reviewed in detail by the Radiation Health Committee. In view of the fact that exposures in Australia are very low, the Committee prepared for the NHMRC a Recommendation, which was promulgated in December 1988 and which does not advise a change in limits at this stage. Instead it draws attention to the new information and to the existing requirement that exposures should be kept as low as reasonably achievable. In particular, it advises that managers of workplaces in which employees regularly receive exposures which are a significant fraction of the recommended limits, should exercise particular care.

It is anticipated that the International Commission on Radiological Protection will publish revised Recommendations in 1990, which take into account this new information. When this occurs, they will be examined by the Radiation Health Committee and appropriate revisions of the Australian standards will follow.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 7 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On 13 February 1989 did the Minister issue a certification for emergency recall on unsafe goods in relation to Neroa Skinless Skin condoms and Harmony Skinless Skin condoms.

(2) Did this action result from tests conducted by the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health which showed that an unexpectedly high proportion of the condoms identified as batch 6018 burst under test after being filled with 12 litres of air under pressure and 300 millilitres of water.
(3) Were these tests conducted by an operative who had been trained to conduct such tests for only 11 days prior to the tests.
(4) Is it a fact that there is no approved testing laboratory for condoms in Australia.

(5) Has the Minister been informed of other perfectly satisfactory tests on these condoms conducted by Birks-Chemists Pty of Adelaide and by the chemical inspection and testing institute in Japan in accordance with Australian standards.
(6) Does the Minister consider these laboratories adequate for the purposes of testing condoms for the Australian market.

(7) Has the Minister taken into account advice dated 10 February 1989 from Fuji Latex Co Ltd to Mr Trevor McPherson, acting Assistant Secretary, medical devices and dental products branch of the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health that the testing procedure upon which the Minister has relied is `far from any satisfaction and was precarious and unfinished when compared with the system of European testing'.
(8) What account did the Minister take of the comments recorded by the Trade Practices Commission in its hearing in 1988 into this matter.
(9) What personal inquiries did the Minister undertake to ensure his mandatory recall was soundly based on proper testing procedures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 13 February 1989 I signed Gazette notices requiring the emergency recall of Neroa Skinless Skin condoms and Harmony Skinless Skin condoms under Section 65L and 65F (1) of the Trade Practices Act 1974. These notices were published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette of 21 February 1989.

(2) This action resulted from tests conducted by the Department of Community Services and Health (DCSH) which did show that an unexpectedly high proportion of condoms of Batch 6018 failed the freedom from holes test under the Australian Standard for condoms. Following a conference conducted by the Trade Practices Commission the Commission advised that `Batch 6018' was not really a batch at all but a number stamped on a proportion of the affected condoms. The Commission advised that the mandatory recall should therefore be extended to all Neroa Skinless Skin condoms and Harmony Skinless Skin condoms.

The action also relied upon the results obtained by the organisation, Enersol Consulting Engineers, which is another testing organisation recognised as competent by the DCSH. Tests by this organisation showed that Harmony Skinless Skin condoms failed the 12 litre burst test specified in the Australian Standard.
The action was supported at a later date by the rejection by US authorities of a consignment of condoms from the same manufacturer because they failed the US `freedom from holes' requirements.

It was found that Batch 6018 was used for both Neroa and Harmony condoms and administratively there was no way that they could be distinguished. That other tests showed the Harmony product to be inferior also made the extension of the recall a reasonable action.
(3) Yes. However, the test procedure is straightforward and the tests were supervised by fully qualified personnel.

(4) There are no National Association of Testing Authorities (NATA) approved Australian testing facilities specifically for condoms, although testing facilities can be registered with NATA. The absence of NATA approval does not mean that a laboratory is unable to perform the necessary tests competently.

(5) I was informed of test results for these condoms by Birks-Chemists of Adelaide and in Japan. It could not be established if these tests were related to the same batch of products subject to the mandatory recall.

(6) Condoms are therapeutic goods and the mandatory recall of Neroa Skinless Skin condoms and Harmony Skinless Skin condoms has been based on advice from and requests by the Minister for Housing and Aged Care.
It is a matter for the Department of Community Services and Health to assess the adequacy of laboratories for the purpose of testing condoms to the Australian Standard.

(7) The letter from Fuji Latex Co. Ltd to the Department of Community Services and Health was not forwarded to me and I cannot comment on this matter. However, I am advised that the comments in the letter never did apply to the DCSH facility and no longer apply to the Enersol facility.
(8) The Trade Practices Commission's comments and conclusions were fully taken into account.
(9) I was satisfied that the mandatory recall was soundly based having relied on advice from the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, the Trade Practices Commission and my own Department.

(2) What is the current estimate of the number of alleged war criminals resident in Australia, and how many are under investigation.
(3) Are any Australian or allied servicemen under investigation; if so, how many.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) No attempt has been made to estimate the number of alleged war criminals resident in Australia, and indeed it would not be possible to make such an estimate. The SIU however has received a number of allegations from various sources that there are war criminals resident in Australia. As a result of those allegations the SIU has opened a total of 564 investigative files as at 10/4/89 relating to individual persons, of which 275 remain in various stages of investigation, 211 having been suspended and a further 78 which relate to deceased persons. It is anticipated that as a result of a review shortly to be conducted by the Director of the SIU, Mr R. F. Greenwood QC, a significant further number of investigations will be suspended.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 9 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Australian pension recipients reside in the United Kingdom, Greece, Italy, Yugoslavia, France, United States of America.
(2) Which of the Australian Consulates/Embassies located in countries listed in (1) above have a Pension Section.
(3) Are the explanatory leaflets issued at Social Security offices following each pension review also forwarded to each overseas-based Australian pension recipient.
(4) Are pension cheques posted from Australia to each individual or are they bulk posted to the Consulates/Embassies and then mailed to recipients.

(5) Have those Australian pension recipients who were resident overseas prior to the recently-introduced departmental conditions for Australian pension recipients, been informed of where and how they go about making pension inquiries from those countries where Australia does not maintain a Pension Section.
(6) What is the average time taken in dealing with inquiries regarding pensions from Australian pensioners residing overseas where there is not a Pension Section.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The numbers of Australian pension recipients living in the specified countries are as follows:
United Kingdom ...
Greece ...
Italy ...
Yugoslavia ...
France ...
USA ...

(2) None of the Australian Consulates/Embassies located in the countries listed in (1) above has a Pension Section. Consular staff in all the countries are trained to answer basic enquiries and refer more difficult assessment matters to International Operations Branch in Hobart.

(3) Following a pension review or any adjustment which results in a variation in the rate of pension paid to a pensioner, the Department of Social Security sends written advice to the pensioner giving full details of the changes and of the pensioner's obligation to notify the Department of any change in their circumstances. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Joint Defence Facilities: Civil Defence Implications

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Federal Government have any civil defence measures in place to protect the population centres near the Joint United States-Australian facilities at Pine Gap, Nurrungar and North West Cape in the even of an attack on, or accident, at these facilities: if so, are they publicly available; if not, why has the Federal Government not put in place civil defence measures.
(2) What are the major features and contingency plans of any civil defence measures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Federal Government has had discussions with the relevant State and Northern Territory authorities to examine the civil defence implications of an attack on the joint defence facilities and the areas where Federal resources may be needed to supplement local emergency services. These discussions are continuing. The decision to release the contingency plans to the public, when they are finalised, is entirely a matter for the States and the Northern Territory.

(2) The Federal Government does not have responsibility for detailed contingency planning, nor would it be practical for it to have this responsibility. This is properly a task for State and Territory authorities utilizing local knowledge and employing the emergency services units under their control. However, I can state that in each case associated with the joint facilities, the State and Territory authorities have based their plans on evacuation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, upon notice, on 5 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What details are available about the method by which containers holding bulka-bags of monazite are stowed on board vessels used in the overseas transport of monazite.
(2) What levels of gamma radiation are harbour personnel and ships' crews exposed to during loading and shipping.
(3) How are gamma radiation levels (referred to in (2) above), measured.
(4) Are records kept of radiation exposure levels for harbour personnel and ships' crews; if so, where; if not, why not.
(5) Are harbour personnel and ships' crews subject to regular medical examinations in regard to exposure to gamma radiation from monazite and xenotime cargoes; if not, why not.
(6) Are records kept to radon gas and thoron gas levels in ships' holds which are loaded with mineral sands concentrates.
(7) What regulations exist in connection with radiation exposure of harbour personnel and ships' crews.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The majority of containers holding Bulka-bags of Monazite are stowed on cellular container ships using shore portainer cranes. A small number are stowed on roll on-roll off ships using fork lift trucks.
Containers may be stowed on or under deck segregated from accommodation, regularly occupied working spaces and certain other classes of dangerous goods.
(2) Radiation dose rates up to 22 micro Gray per hour have been measured at one metre from a container.

(3) Fremantle Terminals Ltd, and the Fremantle Port Authority are involved in loading consignments of containerised Monazite. Measurements of the cargo are taken by Radiation Safety Officers of these organisations using radiation survey meters.

(4) No. Waterside workers engaged in loading Monazite consignments have been monitored in the past. The methods employed have included the use of film badges, radiation survey meters and integrating electronic dose meters. In all cases the radiation doses received by individuals were within the limits of the Federal Code of Practice for the Safe Transport of Radioactive Substances 1982.

(5) No. I am advised that harbour personnel and ships' crews would not receive sufficient radiation from Monazite and Xenotime cargoes for them to be subject to the provisions of State legislation requiring regular medical examinations.
(6) No. The Regulations of the International Atomic Energy Agency do not require radon and thoron gas levels to be monitored and recorded.

(7) With regard to harbour personnel in Western Australia the appropriate regulations in connection with radiation exposure are those made under the WA Radiation Safety Act. This is a matter which comes under State jurisdiction. With regard to ships' crews the appropriate regulations are the International Atomic Energy Agency's Regulations for the Safe Transport of Radioactive materials. These regulations are implemented through the International Maritime Dangerous Goods Code and Marine Orders Part 41 (Cargo and Cargo Handling-Dangerous Goods).
